10767||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Barcelona's trams</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem A: Barcelona's trams">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Barcelona's trams</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p0.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="239" HEIGHT="202" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10767.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p0.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Quite recently the City of Barcelona has included trams
to its ``efficient'' public transport.
As expected, the result has been a nice set of accidents
of outstanding originality and beauty.
Diminishing aesthetic reasons,
the Major of Barcelona
has decided to reduce the delay caused by the accidents.
After a thorough study the following model has been established:

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Every tram must go from an initial point <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>0</SUB></SPAN> to a final point <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>n</SUB></SPAN>
visiting the intermediate points <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>, ..., <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>n - 1</SUB></SPAN> in this order.
For every <!-- MATH
 $1 \le i \le n$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10767.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>i</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10767.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>n</I></SPAN>,
let <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>S</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN> be the section going from <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>i - 1</SUB></SPAN> to <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>.
Every such section must be traveled at uniform speed <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>v</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>,
which is chosen by the driver at <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>i - 1</SUB></SPAN>.
Let <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>M</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN> be the maximum possible speed of the tram at <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>S</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>,
and assume that the chosen speed is <!-- MATH
 $0 < v_i \le M_i$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>v</I><SUB>i</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10767.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>M</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>.
Then the probability of crashing in <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>S</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN> is <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>v</I><SUB>i</SUB>/<I>M</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>.
When a crash happens,
the tram uses an efficient recovery system that lasts only 10 seconds.
Afterwards, the tram reaches <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN> using an auxiliary (slow but safe) engine,
which provides a speed of 5 meters per second
and guarantees no more crashes in <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>S</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
For instance, assume that the section length is 300 meters,
and that the current maximum speed is 25 meters per second.
If the driver chooses to travel at <!-- MATH
 $25 \enspace m/s$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">25&nbsp;<I>m</I>/<I>s</I></SPAN>,
the tram will crash for sure.
Since the crash can happen anywhere between <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>i - 1</SUB></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>,
for the sake of computation
we can assume that it will take place exactly in the middle point
(after 150 meters).
Therefore, on the average
the tram will spend 6 seconds to reach the middle point,
10 seconds to recover from the crash,
and 30 seconds to reach <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>,
for a total of 46 seconds.
By contrast, if the tram starts traveling at <!-- MATH
 $15 \enspace m/s$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">15&nbsp;<I>m</I>/<I>s</I></SPAN>,
with probability <SPAN CLASS="MATH">0.6</SPAN>
it will crash and spend <!-- MATH
 $10 + 10 + 30 = 50$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">10 + 10 + 30 = 50</SPAN> seconds,
and with probability <SPAN CLASS="MATH">0.4</SPAN>
it will reach <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN> after 20 seconds without any crash.
The average time in this case is thus
just <!-- MATH
 $0.6*50 + 0.4*20 = 38$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0.6*50 + 0.4*20 = 38</SPAN> seconds.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
When the tram reaches every <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>, it stops for a few seconds
regardless of having had a crash in <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>S</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN> or not;
these few seconds (for simplicity we consider them to be 0)
are enough to (almost) repair the tram:
the maximum speed reduces by <!-- MATH
 $1 \enspace m/s$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1&nbsp;<I>m</I>/<I>s</I></SPAN> after every crash.
If we call the initial maximum speed <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>M</I><SUB>0</SUB></SPAN>,
then we have <!-- MATH
 $M_i = M_0 - C_i$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>M</I><SUB>i</SUB> = <I>M</I><SUB>0</SUB> - <I>C</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>,
where <!-- MATH
 $0 \le C_i \le i-1$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10767.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>C</I><SUB>i</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10767.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>i</I> - 1</SPAN> is the total number of crashes
suffered in <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>S</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>, ..., <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>S</I><SUB>i - 1</SUB></SPAN>.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Write a program that prints the optimal average travel time
given the initial maximum speed and the length of every section.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Input consists of zero ore more test cases.
Each test case consists of a line
with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>M</I><SUB>0</SUB></SPAN> (a real number between 5 and 25),
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> (an integer number between 1 and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>M</I><SUB>0</SUB> - 1</SPAN>),
and the length of every section (each a real number between 100 and 1000).

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For every test case,
print the optimal average travel time with four decimal digits.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
25 1 900
25 2 900 900
25 2 305.15 980.76
5 1 1000
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
102.0000
205.0303
150.0000
210.0000
</PRE>

<P>

<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Author: Salvador Roura
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10768||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Planarity</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem B: Planarity">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Planarity</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
A graph is called <SPAN  CLASS="textit">planar</SPAN> if it can be drawn in the plane without any
crossings. In a drawing of a graph, nodes are identified with points in the
plane, and edges with lines connecting the corresponding end nodes. No edge
is allowed to cross another edge or node in the drawing.

<P>

<P>
<BR>

<P>
Recall that Kuratowski's theorem provides an easy test for determining
planarity: A graph is planar if and only if it is not homeomorphic to any
graph that contains the subgraph <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>K</I><SUB>3, 3</SUB></SPAN> or the subgraph <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>K</I><SUB>5</SUB></SPAN>.

<P>

<P>
<BR>

<P>
The figure on the left depicts <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>K</I><SUB>3, 3</SUB></SPAN> and the one on the right <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>K</I><SUB>5</SUB></SPAN>:

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p1a.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="601" HEIGHT="204" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10768a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p1a.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
The simplest graph homeomorphic to a given one can be obtained by repeating the
following procedure while possible:

<P>

<UL>
<LI>Remove a vertex of degree&nbsp;1 and its incident edge.

<P>
</LI>
<LI>Remove a vertex <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>v</I></SPAN> of degree 2 and its two incident edges, and replace
them by a new edge that joins the two nodes adjacent to <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>v</I></SPAN>. For instance,

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p1b.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="371" HEIGHT="115" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10768a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p1b.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
would be reduced to

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p1c.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="358" HEIGHT="115" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10768a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p1c.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Note that if edge <SPAN CLASS="MATH">{<I>u</I>, <I>w</I>}</SPAN> was already in the graph, it would not be added
again.

<P>
</LI>
</UL>

<P>
Write a program that determines whether a given undirected graph is planar or
not.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Input consists of zero or more test cases. Each test case consists of a graph. 

<P>

<P>
<BR>

<P>
A graph is given in the following way: First, a line contains two integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>
and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN>, where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> denotes the number of vertices of the graph,
and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> denotes its number of edges
(<!-- MATH
 $1 \le n \le 20$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10768a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>n</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10768a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">20</SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10768a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>m</I></SPAN>). Then follow <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> lines, one for every edge
of the graph, each containing two integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>u</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>v</I></SPAN> (with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>u</I> <IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="32" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10768a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \neq$"> <I>v</I></SPAN>) meaning
that the graph contains the edge <SPAN CLASS="MATH">{<I>u</I>, <I>v</I>}</SPAN>. Vertices in the graph are labelled
from 1 to <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>. There are not repeated edges.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each test case, print a line with the string <TT>YES</TT> if the graph is
planar or with the string <TT>NO</TT> otherwise. 

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
7 10
    5 7
    7 4
    3 1
    5 1
    2 4
    2 1
    2 6
    5 6
    3 4
    3 6
4 6
    1 2
    1 3
    1 4
    2 3
    3 4
    2 4
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
NO
YES
</PRE>

<P>

<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Author: Jordi Petit
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10769||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Pillars</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem C: Pillars">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Pillars</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
The world-famous architect Mr.&nbsp;Fruí from Reus
plans to build a colossal pillar <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>H</I></SPAN> units high.
Mr.&nbsp;Fruí has <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> black pieces with heights <!-- MATH
 $b_1, \dots, b_n$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I><SUB>1</SUB>,..., <I>b</I><SUB>n</SUB></SPAN>
and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> white pieces with heights <!-- MATH
 $w_1, \dots, w_m$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>w</I><SUB>1</SUB>,..., <I>w</I><SUB>m</SUB></SPAN>.
According to his design the pillar must have four pieces:
a black piece on its bottom, a white piece above it,
another black piece above,
and finally a white piece on the top of the pillar.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Mr.&nbsp;Fruí wishes to know which of the combinations of four pieces
with total height <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>H</I></SPAN> is the most stable.
Given two combinations <!-- MATH
 $A = [a_1, a_2, a_3, a_4]$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I> = [<I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>, <I>a</I><SUB>2</SUB>, <I>a</I><SUB>3</SUB>, <I>a</I><SUB>4</SUB>]</SPAN>
and <!-- MATH
 $B = [b_1, b_2, b_3, b_4]$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I> = [<I>b</I><SUB>1</SUB>, <I>b</I><SUB>2</SUB>, <I>b</I><SUB>3</SUB>, <I>b</I><SUB>4</SUB>]</SPAN>
(where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN> denotes the height of the bottom (black) piece of the pillar <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN>,
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN> denotes the height of the second (white) piece of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN>, and so on),
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN> is more stable than <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN> if <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB> &gt; <I>b</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>,
or if <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB> = <I>b</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN> but <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I><SUB>2</SUB> &gt; <I>b</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN>, etc.
(In other words, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN> is more stable than <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN> if and only if
the sequence of heights of the pieces of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN> is lexicographically larger
than the sequence of heights of the pieces of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN>.)

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Write a program such that,
given the desired height <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>H</I></SPAN> of the pillar,
the heights of the black pieces and the heights of the white pieces,
computes which pillar (if any) of height exactly <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>H</I></SPAN> would be the most stable.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Input consists of zero ore more test cases.
Each test case has on the first line <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>H</I></SPAN>,
an integer between 1 and <SPAN CLASS="MATH">4*10<SUP>8</SUP></SPAN>.
The second and third lines of each test consist respectively
of the sequence <!-- MATH
 $b_1, \dots, b_n$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I><SUB>1</SUB>,..., <I>b</I><SUB>n</SUB></SPAN> and of the sequence <!-- MATH
 $w_1, \dots, w_m$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>w</I><SUB>1</SUB>,..., <I>w</I><SUB>m</SUB></SPAN>.
A blank line separates two consecutive test cases.
You can assume <!-- MATH
 $2 \le n \le 100$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">2<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10769img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>n</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10769img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">100</SPAN> and <!-- MATH
 $2 \le m \le 100$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">2<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10769img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>m</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10769img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">100</SPAN>,
and that no piece has a height larger than <SPAN CLASS="MATH">10<SUP>8</SUP></SPAN>.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For every test case, print one line
with the sequence of heights of the pieces of the most stable pillar.
If no solution exists, print <TT>"no solution"</TT>.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
100
20 20
30 10 30 50
 
100
20 10 4
50 30 45
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
20 50 20 10
no solution
</PRE>

<P>

<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Author: Salvador Roura
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10770||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Sokoban</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem D: Sokoban">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Sokoban</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Sokoban is a popular computer game  originally created in 1982 by Hiroyuki
Imabayashi at the Japanese company Thinking Rabbit, Inc. ``Sokoban" is Japanese
for ``warehouse keeper".  The idea is that you are a warehouse keeper trying to
push boxes to their proper locations in a warehouse. The following picture
depicts the game.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p3.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="340" HEIGHT="375" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10770.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p3.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
The goal of the game is to help the warehouse keeper to push the boxes to their
correct destinations in a crowded warehouse, for which a top-view map is
available. The drawback is that our friend is not strong enough to lift one box
over another and he isn't strong enough to pull them either. He can only push
one box at a time, two boxes at once are already too heavy. Moreover, a passage
is just as narrow as a box, so if a box is blocking a path, he cannot go
``around'' it just by squeezing himself through between the box and the wall,
he'll need to find a clear path to reach the other side. And of course, our
friend cannot climb over boxes, either.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Therefore, in order to win this game, a player needs to guide the warehouse
keeper to move the right way through the labyrinth of walls and boxes and to
push all the boxes to the intended target spots in the warehouse.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Sokoban maps with different levels of difficulty are available on the Internet.
For instance, the  above figure is given by the following map:

<P>
<PRE>
####
# .#
#  ###
#*@  #
#  $ #
#  ###
####
</PRE>

<P>
The meaning of each character in this map is the following:
`<TT>#</TT>' denotes a wall,
 space  denotes an 	empty square,
`<TT>.</TT>'  denotes an empty 	goal square,
`<TT>$</TT>'  denotes a box on a square (a yellow box in the picture),
`<TT>*</TT>'  denotes a box on a goal square (a red box in the picture),
`<TT>@</TT>'  denotes the warehouse keeper position on an empty square,
`<TT>+</TT>'  denotes the warehouse keeper position on a goal square.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
On these maps, these are the actions that our little friend can perform:

<P>

<UL>
<LI>Move to an adjacent empty square (left, right, up, down, but not in
diagonal). Each of these actions is called a ``move".

<P>
</LI>
<LI>Push an adjacent box to an empty square (left, right, up, down, but not
in diagonal). Each of these actions is called a ``push". Remark that in order
to push a box in some direction, the destination square must be empty.

<P>
</LI>
</UL>

<P>
For instance, a possible way to solve the previous puzzle with 8 pushes is
given in the following 9 diagrams (read them from left to right,
and observe that only pushes are shown, moves are not displayed).

<P>
<PRE>
    ####      ####      ####      ####      ####      ####      ####      ####      ####   
    # .#      # .#      # .#      # .#      # .#      # .#      # .#      # .#      # *#   
    #  ###    #$ ###    #$ ###    #$ ###    #$ ###    #@ ###    #  ###    # $###    # @### 
    #*@  #    #+   #    #.   #    #.$  #    #.@$ #    #* $ #    #*$@ #    #*@  #    #*   # 
    #  $ #    #  $ #    # $@ #    # @  #    #    #    #    #    #    #    #    #    #    # 
    #  ###    #  ###    #  ###    #  ###    #  ###    #  ###    #  ###    #  ###    #  ### 
    ####      ####      ####      ####      ####      ####      ####      ####      ####
</PRE>

<P>
In fact, there is no way to solve this sokoban map in less than 8 pushes.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Your task is to write a program that, given  an integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> and a sokoban map,
indicates whether or not it is possible to solve the game with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> or
less pushes (the number of moves is not taken into account).

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
Input consists of zero or more test cases. Each test case consists of a line containing an integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> followed by a sokoban map.
You can assume that <!-- MATH
 $1\le k\le 30$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10770.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>k</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10770.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">30</SPAN> and that the size of the map is equal or
smaller than <!-- MATH
 $16\times16$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">16&#215;16</SPAN>. All lines may not have the same length.
A blank line separates two consecutive test cases.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For every test case, use a separate line to 
print <TT>YES</TT> if the map can be solved with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> or less pushes, or print
<TT>NO</TT> otherwise.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
7
############
#  $  @  . #
############

8
####
# .#
#  ###
#*@  #
#  $ #
#  ###
####
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
NO
YES
</PRE>

<P>

<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Author: Jordi Petit
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10771||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Barbarian tribes</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem E: Barbarian tribes">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Barbarian tribes</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
In a lost land two primitive tribes coexist: Gareds and Kekas.
Every summer solstice they meet and compete to decide
which tribe will be the favorite of the gods for the rest of the year,
following an old ritual:

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
First, a local guru chooses three numbers at random: <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>.
Afterwards, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> Gared maids (in the positions <!-- MATH
 $1, 2, \dots, n$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1, 2,..., <I>n</I></SPAN>)
and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> Keka maids (in the positions <!-- MATH
 $n+1, n+2, \dots, n+m$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> + 1, <I>n</I> + 2,..., <I>n</I> + <I>m</I></SPAN>)
are placed in a circle looking inwards.
Then the guru begins to count <!-- MATH
 $1, 2, \dots, k$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1, 2,..., <I>k</I></SPAN> starting at the first Gared maid.
When the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>-th maid is reached, she is immediately sacrificed to the gods.
The guru then counts again <!-- MATH
 $1, 2, \dots, k$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1, 2,..., <I>k</I></SPAN>
starting at the maid following the one just sacrificed.
Again, the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>-th maid reached this way is sacrificed.
After every two sacrifices,
the second sacrificed maid is replaced by a new maid.
In order to decide the tribe of the new maid,
the guru looks at the heads of the two maids just killed
(nothing else remains of them).
If both heads are of the same tribe, the guru calls a Gared maid.
If the heads are from different tribes, the guru calls a Keka maid.
The process then begins again
(counting and sacrificing twice and replacing once)
starting to count at the maid following the new maid
just added to the circle.
Since the number of maids reduces by one after every step
(of two sacrifices and one replacement),
after <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> + <I>m</I> - 1</SPAN> steps only one maid remains.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
According to the tradition,
the tribe of the last maid will be the favorite of the gods.
(What the guru does to the last maid is something you don't want to know.)
Anyway, write a program such that,
given <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>, writes the name of the fortunate tribe.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
For example, this is what happens for <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> = <I>m</I> = 3</SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I> = 2</SPAN>
(a ``G'' denotes a Gared maid and a ``K'' denotes a Keka maid;
the subindexes mark the order the maids enter the circle):

<OL>
<LI>Initial content of the circle: G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN> G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN> G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>3</SUB></SPAN> K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>4</SUB></SPAN> K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>5</SUB></SPAN> K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>6</SUB></SPAN> 
<BR>
Starting to count at G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>.
First sacrifice: G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN>.
Second sacrifice: K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>4</SUB></SPAN> (replaced by K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>7</SUB></SPAN>).
</LI>
<LI>Content of the circle: G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN> G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>3</SUB></SPAN> K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>7</SUB></SPAN> K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>5</SUB></SPAN> K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>6</SUB></SPAN> 
<BR>
Starting to count at K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>5</SUB></SPAN>.
First sacrifice: K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>6</SUB></SPAN>.
Second sacrifice: G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>3</SUB></SPAN> (replaced by K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>8</SUB></SPAN>).
</LI>
<LI>Content of the circle: G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN> K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>8</SUB></SPAN> K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>7</SUB></SPAN> K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>5</SUB></SPAN> 
<BR>
Starting to count at K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>7</SUB></SPAN>.
First sacrifice: K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>5</SUB></SPAN>.
Second sacrifice: K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>8</SUB></SPAN> (replaced by G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>9</SUB></SPAN>).
</LI>
<LI>Content of the circle: G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN> G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>9</SUB></SPAN> K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>7</SUB></SPAN> 
<BR>
Starting to count at K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>7</SUB></SPAN>.
First sacrifice: G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>.
Second sacrifice: K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>7</SUB></SPAN> (replaced by K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>10</SUB></SPAN>).
</LI>
<LI>Content of the circle: G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>9</SUB></SPAN> K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>10</SUB></SPAN> 
<BR>
Starting to count at G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>9</SUB></SPAN>.
First sacrifice: K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>10</SUB></SPAN>.
Second sacrifice: G<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>9</SUB></SPAN> (replaced by K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>11</SUB></SPAN>).
</LI>
<LI>Final content of the circle: K<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><SUB>11</SUB></SPAN> 
<BR></LI>
</OL>

<P>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Input consists of zero ore more test cases.
Each test case consists of a line
with three positive integers: <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>.
You can assume <!-- MATH
 $1 \le n + m \le 2000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10771img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>n</I> + <I>m</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10771img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">2000</SPAN> and <!-- MATH
 $1 \le k \le 1000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10771img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>k</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10771img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">1000</SPAN>.
A test case with <!-- MATH
 $n = m = k = 0$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> = <I>m</I> = <I>k</I> = 0</SPAN> ends the input and must not be processed.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For every test case, print either <TT>"Gared"</TT> or <TT>"Keka"</TT> as convenient.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
3 3 2
4 2 2
0 1 7
0 0 0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
Keka
Gared
Keka
</PRE>

<P>

<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Author: Salvador Roura
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10772||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Rose windows</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem F: Rose windows">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Rose windows</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Mr.&nbsp;Arnold Gerald Nostik is in charge of the design of the main rose window
of the new cathedral in his town.
The rose window is circular, <SPAN CLASS="MATH">2<I>r</I></SPAN> units wide.
Since Mr.&nbsp;A.&nbsp;G.&nbsp;Nostik knows little about Virgins, Saints and Angels,
he is thinking about a geometric pattern:
Let <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> be an even integer number, at least 4.
Mr.&nbsp;Nostik plans to pick <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> points,
each at distance <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I></SPAN> of the center of the window,
these points being the vertices of a regular polygon.
(The next page shows an example with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> = 8</SPAN>.)
These points are to be joined with straight lines,
and the resulting regions colored as shown in the example.
(The colors of the example are arbitrary.)
Note that for <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> = 8</SPAN> there are four regions.
We number these regions 1, 2, 3 and 4
starting to count from the center of the rose.
In general, there are <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I>/2</SPAN> regions.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Write a program to help Mr.&nbsp;Nostik
to know how much glass of every color
he needs in order to build a given rose window.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Input begins with one integer <!-- MATH
 $0 \le m \le 100000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10772img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>m</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10772img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">100000</SPAN>;
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> lines follow, each with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I></SPAN>
(a real number between 1 and 100),
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> (an even integer number between 4 and 40),
and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le k \le n/2$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10772img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>k</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10772img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>n</I>/2</SPAN>).

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For every combination of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>,
print the area (in square units) of the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>-th region
of a rose window with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> points and radius&nbsp;<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I></SPAN>,
rounded to four decimal digits.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
4
50 8 3
9.238794 8 2
10 4 1
20 4 1
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
2928.9322
100.0000
200.0000
800.0000
</PRE>

<P>

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p5a.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="626" HEIGHT="279" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10772img1.png" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p5a.eps}">
</DIV>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">A regular octagon inside a circle <SPAN CLASS="MATH">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</SPAN> <SPAN CLASS="MATH">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</SPAN> A rose window with 8 points

</DIV>

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p5b.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="634" HEIGHT="281" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10772img1.png" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p5b.eps}">
</DIV>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">First region of the rose above <SPAN CLASS="MATH">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</SPAN> <SPAN CLASS="MATH">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</SPAN> Second region of the rose above

</DIV>

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p5c.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="626" HEIGHT="278" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/10772img1.png" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p5c.eps}">
</DIV>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">Third region of the rose above <SPAN CLASS="MATH">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</SPAN> <SPAN CLASS="MATH">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</SPAN> Fourth region of the rose above

</DIV>

<P>

<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Author: Salvador Roura
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________

"urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" xmlns:w = 
"urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:word"><HEAD><TITLE>Back to Intermediate Math</TITLE>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<META content=FrontPage.Editor.Document name=ProgId>
<META content="Microsoft FrontPage 5.0" name=GENERATOR>

P.MsoNormal {
	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-style-parent: " ; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; margin-left:0in; margin-right:0in; margin-top:0in; margin-bottom:0pt

LI.MsoNormal {
	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-style-parent: " ; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; margin-left:0in; margin-right:0in; margin-top:0in; margin-bottom:0pt

	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-style-parent: " ; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; margin-left:0in; margin-right:0in; margin-top:0in; margin-bottom:0pt
}

	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; MARGIN-LEFT: 0in; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0in; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; mso-margin-top-alt: auto; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto
}

	FONT-SIZE: 10pt; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Courier New"; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Courier New"; tab-stops: 45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt

<BODY lang=EN-US style="tab-interval: .5in" bgColor=white>
<DIV class=Section1>
<P class=MsoNormal align=left><B><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 24pt"><I><U><font color="#008000">
Back to Intermediate Math</font></U></I></SPAN></B><BR><B><font color="#800000">Input:</font></B> standard input<BR><B><font color="#800000">Output:</font></B> standard output<BR><B><font color="#800000">Time 
Limit:</font></B> 1 second</P>
<P class=MsoNormal><SPAN 
style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold"><o:p><br>
</SPAN></P>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto" align="justify"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial"><font color="#000080">
Umm! So, you claim yourself as an intelligent one? Let me check. As, computer 
science students always insist on optimization whenever possible, I give you an 
elementary problem of math to optimize.</font></span><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto" align="justify">&nbsp;<p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto" align="justify">
<font color="#000080">Y<span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial">ou 
are trying to cross a river of width <b><i>d</i></b> <b>meters</b>. You are given 
that, the river flows at <i><b>v</b></i> <b>ms<sup>-1</sup></b> and you know 
that you can speed up the boat in <i><b>u</b></i> <b>ms<sup>-1</sup></b>. </SPAN>
There may be two goals how to cross the river: One goal (called fastest path) is 
to cross it in fastest time, and it does not matter how far the flow of the 
river takes the boat. The other goal (called shortest path) is to steer the boat 
in a direction so that the flow of the river doesn't take the boat away, and the 
boat passes the river in a line perpendicular to the boarder of the river.</font><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial"><font color="#000080"> 
Is it always possible to have two different paths, one to pass at shortest time 
and the other at shortest path? If possible then, what is the difference (Let<b><i>&nbsp; P </i>
s</b>) between the times needed to 
cross the river in the different ways?<P class=MsoNormal style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN 
style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold">&nbsp;</span></font></SPAN></o:p></P>
<span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial"><font color="#000080">
<P class=MsoNormal style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><B><SPAN 
style="FONT-SIZE: 18pt"><U><font color="#008000">Input</font></U></SPAN></B></P>
<P class=MsoNormal 
style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></P>
<P class=MsoNormal align="justify">The first line in the input file is an integer representing
the number of test cases. Each of the test cases follows below. Each case
consists three real numbers (all are nonnegative, <i><b>d</b></i> is positive) denoting the value of <i><b>d</b></i>, <i><b>v</b></i> 
and <i><b>u</b></i> respectively.<br>
<br>
<br>
</font><b><u><font color="#008000"><span style="font-size: 18pt">Output</span></font></u></b></P>
<P class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</P>
<P class=MsoNormal align="justify"><font color="#000080"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: Times New Roman; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold">For
each test case, first print the serial number of the case, a colon, an space and then print 
&quot;<i><b>can't determine</b></i>&quot; (without the quotes) if it is not possible to find different 
paths as stated above, else print the 
value of <b><i>P </i></b>corrected to three digits after decimal point.
Check the sample input &amp; output.</span></P>
<P class=MsoNormal><SPAN 
style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold">&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>
<P class=MsoNormal style="mso-layout-grid-align: none"><B><SPAN 
style="FONT-SIZE: 18pt"><U><font color="#008000">Sample 
Input</font></U></SPAN></B><BR><BR>
</font>3</P>
<P class=MsoNormal style="mso-layout-grid-align: none">8 5 6</P>
<P class=MsoNormal style="mso-layout-grid-align: none">1 2 3</P>
<P class=MsoNormal style="mso-layout-grid-align: none">1 5 6<font color="#000080"><SPAN 
style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt"><font color="#000000"><br>
<br>
</font></SPAN><B><SPAN 
style="FONT-SIZE: 18pt"><U><font color="#008000">Sample Output</font></U></SPAN></B><BR><br>
</font>Case 1: 1.079<br>
Case 2: 0.114<br>
Case 3: 0.135</P>
<P class=MsoNormal style="mso-layout-grid-align: none">&nbsp;</P>
<font color="#000080">
<DIV class=MsoNormal>
<HR align=left width="100%" SIZE=2>
</DIV><PRE><B><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: 'Times New Roman'">Problem setter: Anupam Bhattacharjee, CSE, BUET</SPAN></B></PRE>
<PRE><font size="3"><span style="font-family: Times New Roman">Thanks to Adrian for alternate solution and clarification</span></font></PRE>
<PRE><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></PRE>
<P class=MsoNormal 
style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; tab-stops: 45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt" 
align=center><span style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: Monotype Corsiva">&quot;</span><B><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: 'Times New Roman'">~~ 
Learn from yesterday, live for today, hope for tomorrow.</SPAN></B></P>
<P class=MsoNormal 
style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; tab-stops: 45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt" 
align=center><B><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: 'Times New Roman'">
The important thing is to not stop questioning. ~~<o:p></o:p></SPAN></B><span style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: Monotype Corsiva">&quot;</span><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></P>
</span>
</DIV></BODY></HTML>

<body bgcolor="white" lang="EN-US">
<div class="Section1">
<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span style="font-size: 24pt;"><i><u><font
 color="#008000">Repeated Josephus</font></u></i></span></b><br>
<b><font color="#800000">Input:</font></b> standard input<br>
<b><font color="#800000">Output:</font></b> standard output<br>
<b><font color="#800000">Time Limit:</font></b> 1 second</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="justify"><span style=" ><o:p><br>
</o:p></span><font color="#000080">No, </font><span style=" ><font
 color="#000080">
I don't want you to waste important time reading boring introduction.
At first, there are <i><b>n</b></i> people numbered <i><b>1</b></i>
to <i><b>n</b></i> around a circle and every second remaining person
will be eliminated until only one survives. Let the number of the
survivor be <i><b>x</b></i>. The process is then repeated with <i><b>x</b></i>
number of people and let the survivor number is <i><b>y</b></i>. The
process then starts with <i><b>y</b></i> number of people and so on.
The repetition ends when the survivor is in the last position in the
circle.<br>
Example with n = 5:<br>
After the first elimination round, the survivor is person 3. Because
this is is not the last person in the circle, a new elimination round
with 3 people is started.<br>
Now person 3 survives, so we can stop.<br>
</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style=" ><font
 color="#000080">&nbsp;</font></span></p>
<span style=" ><font color="#000080">
</font>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><font color="#000080"><b><span
 style="font-size: 18pt;"><u><font color="#008000">Input</font></u></span></b></font></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><o:p><font
 color="#000080">&nbsp;</font></o:p></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="justify"><font color="#000080">The first
line in the input file is an integer representing
the number of test cases. Each of the test cases follows below. Each
test case consists of an integer representing <i><b>n ( 0 &lt; n &#8804;
30000 )</b></i>.<br>
<br>
</font><b><u><font color="#008000"><span style="font-size: 18pt;">Output</span></font></u></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="justify"><font color="#000080"><span
 style=" >
For each test case, print the serial number of the case, a colon, an
space, total number of repetitions (the number of times the elimination
process is done after the initial elimination round with n people), an
space and the position of the survivor at last</span>.<span style=" >
Check the sample input &amp; output.</span></font></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=" ><font color="#000080">&nbsp;</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" ><font color="#000080"><b><span
 style="font-size: 18pt;"><u><font color="#008000">Sample Input</font></u></span></b><br>
<br>
</font>2</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >13</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" ><font color="#000080"><span style=" ><font
 color="#000000">23403<br>
<br>
</font></span><b><span style="font-size: 18pt;"><u><font color="#008000">Sample
Output</font></u></span></b><br>
<br>
</font>Case 1: 2 7<br>
Case 2: 8 1023</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >&nbsp;</p>
<font color="#000080">
</font>
<div class="MsoNormal">
<hr align="left" size="2" width="100%"></div>
<pre><font color="#000080"><b><span
 style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">Problem setter: Anupam Bhattacharjee, CSE, BUET</span></b></font></pre>
<pre><font size="3" color="#000080"><span style="font-family: Times New Roman">Thanks to Adrian for alternate solution.</span></font></pre>
<pre><font color="#000080">&nbsp;</font></pre>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span
 style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: Monotype Corsiva;"><font
 color="#000080">"</font></span><font color="#000080"><b><span
 style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">~~ Simple
matters in the world need not always be simple ~~<o:p></o:p></span></b><span
 style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: Monotype Corsiva;">"</span><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></font></p>
</span>
</div>
</body>
</html>

	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-style-parent: " ; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; margin-left:0in; margin-right:0in; margin-top:0in; margin-bottom:0pt

	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; MARGIN-LEFT: 0in; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0in; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; mso-margin-top-alt: auto; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto
}
PRE {
	FONT-SIZE: 10pt; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Courier New"; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Courier New"; tab-stops: 45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt
}
TT {
	FONT-FAMILY: "Courier New"; mso-fareast-font-family: "Courier New"; mso-ascii-font-family: "Courier New"; mso-hansi-font-family: "Courier New"; mso-bidi-font-family: "Courier New"
}
SPAN.GramE {
	mso-style-name: " ; mso-gram-e: yes
}
DIV.Section1 {
	page: Section1
}
</STYLE>
<!--[if gte mso 10]>
<style>
 /* Style Definitions */
 table.MsoNormalTable
	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";
	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;
	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;
	mso-style-noshow:yes;
	mso-style-parent:" ;
	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
	mso-para-margin:0in;
	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman"}
</style>
<![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]--></HEAD>
<BODY lang=EN-US style="tab-interval: .5in" bgColor=white>
<DIV class=Section1>
<P class=MsoNormal align=left><B><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 24pt"><I><U><font color="#008000">
Mystical Matrix</font></U></I></SPAN></B><BR><B><font color="#800000">Input:</font></B> standard input<BR><B><font color="#800000">Output:</font></B> standard output<BR><B><font color="#800000">Time 
Limit:</font></B> 1 second</P>
<P class=MsoNormal align="justify"><SPAN 
style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold"><o:p><br>
</SPAN><font color="#000080">It was rumored that the first person who solves the 
Mystical Matrix will get a free Mystical Chicken dinner from the Mystical 
Restaurant. Of course, Jack is eager to get that Mystical Chicken dinner. <br>
<br>
The Mystical Matrix is a matrix with <i><b>3</b></i> rows and <i><b>N</b></i> 
columns, with <i><b>1,2,..,3N</b></i> each occupying one cell. Furthermore, all 
rows have the same sum and all columns have the same sum. Help Jack construct 
such a Mystical Matrix.</font><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial"><font color="#000080"></P>
<P class=MsoNormal style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><SPAN 
style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold">&nbsp;</span></font></span></o:p></P>
<span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial"><font color="#000080">
<P class=MsoNormal style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify"><B><SPAN 
style="FONT-SIZE: 18pt"><U><font color="#008000">Input</font></U></SPAN></B></P>
<P class=MsoNormal 
style="TEXT-ALIGN: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none"><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></P>
<P class=MsoNormal align="justify">The input contains several lines. Each line 
contains a single positive integer <i><b>N</b></i>. You may assume <i><b>N</b></i> 
is a multiple of <i><b>3</b></i> and it is less than <i><b>1000</b></i>. The 
input is terminated by a single integer <i><b>0</b></i>.<br>
<br>
</font><b><u><font color="#008000"><span style="font-size: 18pt">Output</span></font></u></b></P>
<P class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</P>
<P class=MsoNormal align="justify"><font color="#000080"><span style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: Times New Roman; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial; mso-ansi-language: EN-US; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold">
Output a valid Mystical Matrix. If non-exists, output <i><b>IMPOSSIBLE</b></i> 
(without quotes). A valid Mystical Matrix should take <i><b>3</b></i> lines, 
with each line consisting of <i><b>N</b></i> integers separated by spaces. For 
example, a 3 x 9 matrix should look like:<br>
A1 A2 A3 A4 A5 A6 A7 A8 A9<br>
B1 B2 B3 B4 B5 B6 B7 B8 B9<br>
C1 C2 C3 C4 C5 C6 C7 C8 C9</span></P>
<P class=MsoNormal><SPAN 
style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold">&nbsp;</o:p></SPAN></P>
<P class=MsoNormal style="mso-layout-grid-align: none"><B><SPAN 
style="FONT-SIZE: 18pt"><U><font color="#008000">Sample 
Input</font></U></SPAN></B><BR><BR>
<SPAN 
style="mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt"><font color="#000000">3<br>
0<br>
<br>
</font></SPAN><B><SPAN 
style="FONT-SIZE: 18pt"><U><font color="#008000">Sample Output</font></U></SPAN></B><BR><br>
</font>8 1 6<br>
3 5 7<br>
4 9 2</P>
<P class=MsoNormal style="mso-layout-grid-align: none">&nbsp;</P>
<font color="#000080">
<DIV class=MsoNormal>
<HR align=left width="100%" SIZE=2>
</DIV><PRE><B><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: 'Times New Roman'">Problem setter: Yin Zhao (aka Bugz Podder)</SPAN></B></PRE>
<PRE>&nbsp;</PRE>
<P class=MsoNormal 
style="TEXT-ALIGN: center; tab-stops: 45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt" 
align=center><span style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: Monotype Corsiva">&quot;</span><B><SPAN style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: 'Times New Roman'">~~ 
When time turns on you, turn time around&nbsp; ~~<o:p></o:p></SPAN></B><span style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: Monotype Corsiva">&quot;</span><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></P>
</span>
</DIV></BODY></HTML>

  <title>Determine the combination</title>

 content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">

</head>
<body bgcolor="white" lang="EN-US">
<div class="Section1">
<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span style="font-size: 24pt;"><i><u><font
 color="#008000">Determine The combination</font></u></i></span></b><br>
<b><font color="#800000">Input:</font></b> standard input<br>
<b><font color="#800000">Output:</font></b> standard output<br>
<b><font color="#800000">Time Limit:</font></b> 1 second</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="justify"><o:p><span style=" ><br>
</span><font color="#000080">Jahir is a student of <i><b>NSU</b></i> (
<b><i>Nice Students' University</i></b> ). He hates the chapter
Permutation
&amp; Combination of the subject Discrete Math. But his teacher give
him a assignment to generate all the r combination of a string. But he
is too busy with his new girlfriend to do the assignment himself. So he
went to Shabuj, a student of <i>
<b>CSE ( Calculation Science and Engineering )</b></i> in <i><b>BUET (
Bangladesh University of Extraordinary Talents )</b></i>. He asked him
to make a program to generate the combinations. But Shabuj is always
lazy. He wants your help.</font></o:p></p>
<p align="justify">
<o:p><span style=" ><font color="#000080">Your task is to print all
different <i><b>r</b></i> combinations of a
string <i><b>s</b></i> (a <span style="font-weight: bold;">r</span>
combination of a string <span style="font-weight: bold;">s </span>is
a
collection of exactly <span style="font-weight: bold;">r</span>
letters from different positions in s).<br>
There may be different permutations of the same combination; consider
only the one that has its <span style="font-weight: bold;">r</span>
characters in non-decreasing order.<br>
The string consists of only lowercase letters. Any letter can occur
more than once.</font></span></o:p> </p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style=" ><font
 color="#000080">&nbsp;<b><span
 style="font-size: 18pt;"><u><font color="#008000">Input</font></u></span></b></font></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><o:p><font
 color="#000080">&nbsp;</font></o:p></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="justify"><font color="#000080">The input is
consist of several test cases. Each test case consists of a string <i><b>s</b></i>
( the length of <i><b>s</b></i> is between <span
 style="font-weight: bold;">1</span> and&nbsp; <i><b>30</b></i> ) and
an integer <i><b>r</b></i> ( <i><b>0 &lt; r &lt;= length of s</b></i>
).<br>
<br>
</font><b><u><font color="#008000"><span style="font-size: 18pt;">Output</span></font></u></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="justify"><font color="#000080"><span
 style=" >
For each test case you have to print all different r combinations of s
in lexicographic order in separate line. You can assume there are at
most 1000 different ones.<br>
</span><span style=" >&nbsp;</span></font></p>
<font color="#000080"><b><span style="font-size: 18pt;"><u><font
 color="#008000">Sample Input</font></u></span></b><br>
<br>
<span style=" ><font color="#000000">abcde 2<br>
abcd 3<br>
aba 2<br>
<br>
</font></span><b><span style="font-size: 18pt;"><u><font color="#008000">Sample
Output</font></u></span></b><br>
<br>
</font>ab<br>
ac<br>
ad<br>
ae<br>
bc<br>
bd<br>
be<br>
cd<br>
ce<br>
de<br>
abc<br>
abd<br>
acd<br>
bcd<br>
aa<br>
ab<br>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >&nbsp;</p>
<font color="#000080">
</font>
<div class="MsoNormal">
<hr align="left" size="2" width="100%"></div>
<pre><font color="#000080"><b><span
 style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">Problem setter: Hasan Shihab Uddin, CSE, BUET</span></b></font></pre>
<pre><font size="3" color="#000080"><span style="font-family: Times New Roman">Thanks to Adrian &amp; Anupam for alternate solution and clarification.</span></font></pre>
<pre><font color="#000080">&nbsp;</font></pre>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span
 style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: Monotype Corsiva;"><font
 color="#000080">"</font></span><font color="#000080"><b><span
 style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">~~ No matter
wherever you go, bad luck will follow you ~~<o:p></o:p></span></b><span
 style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: Monotype Corsiva;">"</span><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></font></p>
</span>
</div>
</body>
</html>

  <title>God! Save me</title>
  <meta http-equiv="Content-Type"
 content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
  <meta content="FrontPage.Editor.Document" name="ProgId">
  <meta content="Microsoft FrontPage 5.0" name="GENERATOR">

  <link

 rel="Edit-Time-Data">

P.MsoNormal {
	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-style-parent: " ; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; margin-left:0in; margin-right:0in; margin-top:0in; margin-bottom:0pt

}

	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-style-parent: " ; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; margin-left:0in; margin-right:0in; margin-top:0in; margin-bottom:0pt
}

	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; MARGIN-LEFT: 0in; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0in; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; mso-margin-top-alt: auto; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto
}
PRE {
	FONT-SIZE: 10pt; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Courier New"; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Courier New"; tab-stops: 45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt
}

	FONT-FAMILY: "Courier New"; mso-fareast-font-family: "Courier New"; mso-ascii-font-family: "Courier New"; mso-hansi-font-family: "Courier New"; mso-bidi-font-family: "Courier New"

 /* Style Definitions */
 table.MsoNormalTable
	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";
	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;
	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;
	mso-style-noshow:yes;
	mso-style-parent:" ;
	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
	mso-para-margin:0in;
	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;

	font-family:"Times New Roman"}
  </style>
<![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->
</head>
<body bgcolor="white" lang="EN-US">
<div class="Section1">
<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span style="font-size: 24pt;"><i><u><font
 color="#008000">God! Save me</font></u></i></span></b><br>
<b><font color="#800000">Input:</font></b> standard input<br>
<b><font color="#800000">Output:</font></b> standard output<br>
<b><font color="#800000">Time Limit:</font></b> 1 second</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=" ><o:p><br>
</o:p></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="  align="justify"><span style=" ><font
 color="#000080">
Let there be <i><b>n</b></i> doors in a mine contained room. If you
choose <i><b>i</b></i><sup>th</sup> door, it either takes you to a
safe place after <i><b>x<sub>i</sub></b></i> hours or it returns you
to the same room after <i><b>x<sub>i</sub></b></i> hours traveling.
What is the expected length of time (in hours, let <i><b>P</b></i>)
until you can move to the safe place?</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="  align="justify"><span style=" ><font
 color="#000080"><span style=" >&nbsp;</span></font></span><span
 style=" ><font color="#000080"></font>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><font color="#000080"><b><span
 style="font-size: 18pt;"><u><font color="#008000">Input</font></u></span></b></font></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><o:p><font
 color="#000080">&nbsp;</font></o:p></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="justify"><font color="#000080">The first
line in the input file is an integer representing
the number of test cases. Each of the test cases follows below. The
first line of each case
consists an integer denoting the value of <i><b>n ( 0 &lt; n &lt; 100 )</b></i>.
Each of the next <i><b>n</b></i> lines contains the value of <b><i>x<sub>i</sub>
, </i></b></font><span style=" ><font color="#000080"><i><b>0 &lt; |x<sub>i</sub>
|&lt; 25</b></i></font></span><font color="#000080"><b><i> </i>
</b>(if positive it takes you out, if negative it returns you)<i><b></b></i>
and <i><b>p<sub>i</sub></b></i> denoting the probability to choose the
<i><b>i</b></i><sup>th</sup> door. You can assume that the sum of all </font><span
 style=" ><font color="#000080"><i><b>p<sub>i</sub></b></i></font></span><font
 color="#000080"> equals 1. There may be arbitrary number of spaces
between the values.<br>
<br>
</font><b><u><font color="#008000"><span style="font-size: 18pt;">Output</span></font></u></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="justify"><font color="#000080"><span
 style=" >For
each test case, first print the serial number of the case, a colon, an
space and then print "<i><b>God! Save me</b></i>" (without the quotes)
if you can't expect to be in the safe place, else print the value of <b><i>P
</i></b>corrected to two digits after decimal point.
Check the sample input &amp; output.</span></font></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=" ><font color="#000080">&nbsp;</font></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" ><font color="#000080"><b><span
 style="font-size: 18pt;"><u><font color="#008000">Sample Input</font></u></span></b><br>
<br>
</font>2</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >3</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >2 0.33</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >-3 0.33</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >-5 0.34</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >3</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >2 0.34</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >-3 0.33</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >-5<font color="#000080"><span style=" ><font
 color="#000000"> 0.33<br>
<br>
</font></span><b><span style="font-size: 18pt;"><u><font color="#008000">Sample
Output</font></u></span></b><br>
<br>
</font>Case 1: 10.15</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >Case 2: 9.76</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" >&nbsp;</p>
<font color="#000080">
</font>
<div class="MsoNormal">
<hr align="left" size="2" width="100%"></div>
<pre><font color="#000080"><b><span
 style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">Problem setter: Anupam Bhattacharjee, CSE, BUET</span></b></font></pre>
<pre><font size="3" color="#000080"><span style="font-family: Times New Roman">Thanks to Robin for the alternate solution.</span></font></pre>
<pre><o:p><font color="#000080">&nbsp;</font></o:p></pre>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span
 style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: Monotype Corsiva;"><font
 color="#000080">"</font></span><font color="#000080"><b><span
 style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">~~ What I
want, I find them mistakenly. I don't want what I find ~~<o:p></o:p></span></b><span
 style="font-size: 14pt; font-family: Monotype Corsiva;">"</span><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></font></p>
</span>
</p>
</div>

10778||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN">
<HTML>
<HEAD>
	<META HTTP-EQUIV="CONTENT-TYPE" CONTENT="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
	<TITLE></TITLE>
	<META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Microsoft FrontPage 5.0">
	<META NAME="AUTHOR" CONTENT="Yin Zhao">
	<META NAME="CREATED" CONTENT="20041002;16372400">
	<META NAME="CHANGEDBY" CONTENT="Yin Zhao">
	<META NAME="CHANGED" CONTENT="20041003;17362463">
	<STYLE>
	<!--
		@page { size: 8.5in 11in; margin-right: 1.25in; margin-top: 1in; margin-bottom: 1in }
		P { margin-bottom: 0.08in; direction: ltr; color: #000000; text-align: left; widows: 0; orphans: 0 }
		P.western { font-family: "Times New Roman", serif; font-size: 12pt; so-language: en-US }
		P.cjk { font-family: "Lucida Sans Unicode"; font-size: 12pt; so-language:  }
		P.ctl { font-family: "Tahoma"; font-size: 12pt; so-language:  }
	-->
	</STYLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="de-DE" TEXT="#000000" DIR="LTR">
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=LEFT><B><U><I><FONT SIZE=6><FONT COLOR="#008000">Mathemagicland</FONT></FONT></I></U><BR><FONT COLOR="#800000">Input:</FONT> </B>standard input<B><BR><FONT COLOR="#800000">Output:</FONT> </B>standard
output<B><BR><FONT COLOR="#800000">Time Limit:</FONT> </B>1 second</P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY style="text-align: justify"><FONT COLOR="#000080">Jack
has been abducted by a man in black suit to Mathemagicland. 
Fortunately, he met a friend Donald Duck.  Donald Duck will help him
escape only if he first finds all <i><b>n</b></i>-tuple  solutions:</FONT></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10778a.gif"  NAME="Object1" ALIGN=LEFT width="25%" height="11%"></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>&nbsp;</P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY style="text-align: justify"><BR CLEAR=LEFT><FONT COLOR="#000080">after
Donald Duck gives Jack n rational values</FONT><BR>
</P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=LEFT STYLE="margin-bottom: 0in">
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10778a.gif"  NAME="Object2" width="25%" height="15%"></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=LEFT STYLE="margin-bottom: 0in">
<FONT COLOR="#000080">where</FONT></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10778a.gif"  NAME="Object3" ></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY style="text-align: justify"><BR CLEAR=LEFT><FONT COLOR="#000080">are
called the elementary symmetric polynomials.
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY style="text-align: justify"><BR CLEAR=LEFT><FONT COLOR="#000080">For
example: if n=1, then
<p><IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10778a.gif"  NAME="Object3" ></P>

<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY style="text-align: justify"><BR CLEAR=LEFT><FONT COLOR="#000080">If
n=2, then
<p><IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10778a.gif"  NAME="Object3"></P>

<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY style="text-align: justify"><BR CLEAR=LEFT><FONT COLOR="#000080">If
n=3, then
<p><IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10778a.gif"  NAME="Object3"></P>

<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY style="text-align: justify"><BR CLEAR=LEFT><FONT COLOR="#000080">If
n=4, then
<p><IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10778a.gif"  NAME="Object3"></P>

<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY style="text-align: justify"><BR CLEAR=LEFT><FONT COLOR="#000080">However,
since most irrational numbers are impossible to represent exactly using a computer, you are only required to output the rational components of  in numerical order.


<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR="#008000"><U><B>Input</B></U></FONT></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=LEFT STYLE="margin-bottom: 0in; text-align:justify">
<FONT COLOR="#000080">There are less than <B>1001</B> test cases. 
For each test case, the first line contains two integers <B>n </B><SPAN STYLE="font-weight: medium">and</SPAN><B>
k, </B><SPAN STYLE="font-weight: medium"> </SPAN><B>n&gt;0, |k|&gt;0,
n&lt;101, |k|&lt;1001.</B></FONT></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=LEFT STYLE="margin-bottom: 0in; text-align:justify">
<FONT COLOR="#000080">The second line contains <B>n</B> integers
separated by a single space,</FONT></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=LEFT STYLE="margin-bottom: 0in">
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10778a.gif"  NAME="Object4" width="30%" height="13%"></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY style="text-align: justify"><FONT COLOR="#000080">After
the last test case, a single integer of 0 is given.<BR><BR></FONT><B><U><FONT SIZE=5><FONT COLOR="#008000">Output</FONT></FONT></U></B></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY style="text-align: justify"><FONT COLOR="#000080">Each
<i><b>n</b></i>-tuple solution should be outputted in exactly one line and in the
form of:</FONT></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10778a.gif"  NAME="Object5" width="29%" height="15%"></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY><FONT COLOR="#000080">Such
that</FONT></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10778a.gif"  NAME="Object6" width="236" height="54"></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=JUSTIFY style="text-align: justify"><FONT COLOR="#000080">Two
<i><b>n</b></i>-tuple solutions are said to be the same if they have the same
output.  Two  solutions are said to be distinct if they are not the
same.  Output all distinct solutions in lexicographical order, one in
each line.  If there is no solution
(ie there are no rational elements in any of the valid n-tuples x<sub>1</sub>,x<sub>2</sub>,...,x<sub>n</sub>)
, output &ldquo;<i><b>No solution.</b></i>&rdquo;
without quotes.  Print a blank line between each test case.</FONT></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" style="text-align: justify"><i><b><FONT COLOR="#000080">
Note: All inputs/outputs will fit into a standard 32-bit signed integer.</FONT></b></i></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" STYLE="margin-bottom: 0in"><B><U><FONT SIZE=5><FONT COLOR="#008000">Sample
Input</FONT></FONT></U></B><FONT COLOR="#000080"><BR></FONT>
</P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" STYLE="margin-bottom: 0in">2 1</P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" STYLE="margin-bottom: 0in">2 1</P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" STYLE="margin-bottom: 0in"><FONT COLOR="#000000">0<BR><BR></FONT><B><U><FONT SIZE=5><FONT COLOR="#008000">Sample
Output</FONT></FONT></U></B><FONT COLOR="#000080"><BR><BR>1 1</FONT></P>
<P LANG="en-US" STYLE="margin-bottom: 0.2in; border-top: none; border-bottom: 1.10pt double #808080; border-left: none; border-right: none; padding: 0in">
<BR>
</P>
<P LANG="en-US" STYLE="margin-bottom: 0.2in"><FONT COLOR="#000080"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman, serif"><FONT SIZE=3><B>Problem
setter: Yin Zhao (aka Bugz Podder)</B></FONT></FONT></FONT></P>
<P LANG="en-US" CLASS="western" ALIGN=CENTER style="text-align: center"><FONT COLOR="#000080">
<FONT FACE="Monotype Corsiva" SIZE="4">&quot;</FONT><B><FONT FACE="Times New Roman, serif">~~
A man in a black suit will come and take you away at 1:42...and you
will be abducted to Mathemagicland (where you will meet Donald Duck).
~~</FONT></B><FONT FACE="Monotype Corsiva" SIZE="4">&quot;</FONT>&nbsp;</FONT></P>
</BODY>
</HTML>

  <title>Collector's Problem</title>
  <meta http-equiv="Content-Type"
 content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">

	font-family: Monotype Corsiva;
}
@page Section1 {size: 595.45pt 841.7pt; margin: 1.0in 1.0in 1.0in 1.0in; mso-header-margin: .5in; mso-footer-margin: .5in; mso-paper-source: 0; }

	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-style-parent: " ; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; margin-left:0in; margin-right:0in; margin-top:0in; margin-bottom:0pt

	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-style-parent: " ; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; margin-left:0in; margin-right:0in; margin-top:0in; margin-bottom:0pt
}

	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-style-parent: " ; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; margin-left:0in; margin-right:0in; margin-top:0in; margin-bottom:0pt
}
P {
	FONT-SIZE: 12pt; MARGIN-LEFT: 0in; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0in; FONT-FAMILY: "Times New Roman"; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; mso-margin-top-alt: auto; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto
}
PRE {
	FONT-SIZE: 10pt; MARGIN: 0in 0in 0pt; FONT-FAMILY: "Courier New"; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-fareast-font-family: "Courier New"; tab-stops: 45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt
