* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Prime Frequency</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Prime Frequency">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Prime Frequency</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Given a string containing only alpha-numerals (<TT>0-9</TT>,
<TT>A-Z</TT> and <TT>a-z</TT>) you have to count the frequency (the number of times
the character is present) of all the characters and report only those
characters whose frequency is a prime number. A prime number is a number, which
is divisible by exactly two different integers. Some examples of prime numbers
are <B>2</B>, <B>3</B>, <B>5</B>, <B>7</B>, <B>11</B> etc.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10789.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="479" HEIGHT="383" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10789.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10789.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
The first line of the
input is an integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>T</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $0 < T < 201$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>T</I> &lt; 201</SPAN>) that indicates how many sets of inputs are there. Each of the next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>T</I></SPAN> lines contains a single set of input.

<P>
The input of each test set is a string consisting
alpha-numerals only. The length of this string is positive and less than <B>2001</B>.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each set of input produce one line of output. This line contains the serial of output followed by the characters whose frequency in the input string is a prime number. These characters are to be sorted in lexicographically ascending
order. Here ``lexicographically ascending" means ascending in terms of the <B>ASCII</B>
values. Look at the output for sample input for details. If none of the
character frequency is a prime number, you should print `<TT>empty</TT>'
(without the quotes) instead.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
3
ABCC
AABBBBDDDDD
ABCDFFFF
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
Case 1: C
Case 2: AD
Case 3: empty
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Miguel Revilla
2004-12-10
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10790||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>How Many Points of Intersection?</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="How Many Points of Intersection?">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
How Many Points of Intersection?</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
We have two rows. There are <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I></SPAN> dots on the top
row and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I></SPAN> dots on the bottom row. We draw line segments connecting every dot on the top row with every dot on the bottom row. The dots are arranged in such a way that the number of internal intersections among the line segments is maximized. To achieve this goal we must not allow more than two line segments to intersect in a point. The intersection points on the top row and the bottom are not included in our count; we can allow more than two line segments to intersect on those two rows. Given the value of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I></SPAN>, your task is to compute <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I>(<I>a</I>, <I>b</I>)</SPAN>, the number of intersections in between the two rows. For example, in the following figure <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I> = 2</SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I> = 3</SPAN>. This figure illustrates that <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I>(2, 3) = 3</SPAN>.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10790.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
  BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10790.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10790.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Each line in the input will contain two positive integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I></SPAN>
(<!-- MATH
 $0 < a \le 20000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>a</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10790.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">20000</SPAN>) and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $0 < b \le 20000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>b</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10790.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">20000</SPAN>).
Input is terminated by a line where both <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I></SPAN> are zero. This
case should not be processed. You will need to process at most 1200 sets of inputs.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each line of input, print
in a line the serial of output followed by the value of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I>(<I>a</I>, <I>b</I>)</SPAN>. Look at
the output for sample input for details. You can assume that the output for the  test cases will fit in <B>64-bit</B> signed integers.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
2 2
2 3
3 3
0 0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
Case 1: 1
Case 2: 3
Case 3: 9
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR>
<hr>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Md. Bahlul Haider<br>
Special Thanks: Shahriar Manzoor
</ADDRESS>

<HR>
<ADDRESS>
Miguel Revilla
2004-12-10
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10791||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Minimum Sum LCM</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Minimum Sum LCM">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Minimum Sum LCM</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10791.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="right" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10791.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10791.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
<B>LCM</B> (Least Common Multiple) of a set of integers is defined as
the minimum number, which is a multiple of all integers of that set. It is
interesting to note that any positive integer can be expressed as the <B>LCM</B> of a set of positive integers. For example <B>12</B> can be expressed as the <B>LCM</B> of <B>1</B>, <B>12</B> or <B>12</B>, <B>12</B> or <B>3</B>, <B>4</B> or <B>4</B>, <B>6</B> or <B>1</B>, <B>2</B>, <B>3</B>, <B>4</B> etc.


<P>
In this problem, you will be given a positive
integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>. You have to find out a set of at least two positive integers
whose <B>LCM</B> is <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>. As infinite such sequences are possible,
you have to pick the sequence whose summation of elements is minimum. We will
be quite happy if you just print the summation of the elements of this set. So,
for <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> = 12</SPAN>, you should print <B>4+3 = 7</B> as <B>LCM</B> of <B>4</B> and <B>3</B>
is <B>12</B> and <B>7</B> is the minimum possible summation.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input file contains at most <B>100</B> test cases. Each test case consists of a positive integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le N \le 2^{31}-1$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10791.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10791.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">2<SUP>31</SUP> - 1</SPAN>).

<P>
Input is terminated by a case where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> = 0</SPAN>. This case should not be processed. There can be at most <B>100</B> test cases.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Output of each test case should consist of a line starting
with `<TT>Case <SPAN CLASS="MATH">#</SPAN>: </TT>' where <SPAN CLASS="MATH">#</SPAN> is the test case number. It should be
followed by the summation as specified in the problem statement. Look at the output for sample input for details.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE> 
12
10
5
0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE> 
Case 1: 7
Case 2: 7
Case 3: 6
</PRE>  

<P>


<P>
<BR>
<hr>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Md. Kamruzzaman<br>
Special Thanks: Shahriar Manzoor
</ADDRESS>
<HR>
<ADDRESS>
Miguel Revilla
2004-12-10
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10792||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Laurel-Hardy Story</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="The Laurel-Hardy Story">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
The Laurel-Hardy Story</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10792a.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="left" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10792a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10792a.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Laurel and Hardy are two famous movie characters of the 50's. They are well known for their differences in weight as
you can see in the picture on the left. In case you dont know them I should
add that Laurel was the lighter guy. In their younger days Laurel and Hardy
used to play with a strange seesaw and when the seesaw was at a stable position Hardy was always nearer the ground. 
We will now investigate a two dimensional version of their seesaw.


<P>
The seesaw that Laurel Hardy used can be considered as part of a circle
of radius <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I></SPAN>, as shown in the
picture on the right (Filled gray and having the shape of a D). Hardy sat on
point B (rightmost point of the seesaw) and Laurel sat on point A (Leftmost point of the seesaw top AB). <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>d</I></SPAN>=EF is the distance
between the midpoint of line AB and arc AFB. So E is the midpoint of
line AB and F is the midpoint of arc AFB. MN is the ground of the
seesaw, which is horizontal with the plane. BD=<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>h</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN> is the distance of Hardy from the ground. Your job is to find out the
distance of Laurel (denoted by <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>h</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN>=AC) from the ground.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10792b.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="center" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10792a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10792b.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
First line of the input file contains an integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>
(<!-- MATH
 $0 < N \le 1000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10792a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">1000</SPAN>), which indicates how many sets of inputs are there. Each of the next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> lines contains a single set of input. The description of each set is given below:

<P>

<P>
<BR>
Each line contains three integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $10 \le r \le 100$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">10<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10792a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>r</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10792a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">100</SPAN>), <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>d</I></SPAN>
(<!-- MATH
 $5 \le d \le r$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">5<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10792a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>d</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10792a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>r</I></SPAN>), <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>h</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $5 \le h_{1} \le d$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">5<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10792a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>h</I><SUB>1</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10792a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>d</I></SPAN>). The
meanings of these integers are given in the problem statement above.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each set of input produce one
line of output. This line contains the serial of output followed by a
floating-point number, which indicates the value of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>h</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN>. This
floating-point number should be rounded up to four digits after the decimal point. Look at the output for sample input for details.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
2
10 10 10
10 7 6
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
Case 1: 10.0000
Case 2: 8.0342
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR>
<hr>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Shahriar Manzoor<br>
Special Thanks: Monirul Hasan
</ADDRESS>

<HR>
<ADDRESS>
Miguel Revilla
2004-12-10
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10793||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Orc Attack</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="The Orc Attack">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
The Orc Attack</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10793a.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="left" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10793a.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Gar'dal Grimsight, the hero of the Orc
horde, is planning a massive attack on the human stronghold. But to overcome
the stiff resistance of the humans, Grimsight would need an army of mammoth
size. Realizing this, he wastes no time - all his five buildings start to
produce units on his command. The Altar of Storms, the Barracks, the Beastiary,
the Spirit Lodge and the Tauren Totem - these are his five unit producing buildings.
These buildings are strategically placed in different locations but can have a
rally point where the units are sent as soon as they are produced. This gives Grimsight
a good coverage of the territory as well as the flexibility of unit movement.

<P>

<IMG
 ALIGN="middle" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10793b.eps}">

<P>
Now before Grimsight wages the war, the units produced need
to meet at this rally point in the map. This point should be chosen
in a way that the <EM>shortest distance</EM> from the five unit producing
buildings to this location is equal. If there are multiple such spots,
the units would gather in a place from where the <EM>shortest distance
to the farthest point</EM> in the map is the minimum. Your task is to help
the belligerent hero in determining this minimum shortest distance of
the farthest point.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10793c.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="left" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10793c.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
However, a small problem remains. The shortest distance between two points in the map is not necessarily the straight line distance between them. Trees, hills and water sheds can act as obstacle for the free movement of the units. So the units may need to go through different locations to get to the point where they are intended to go. If the distances between all these locations in the map are given, then it is possible to compute the shortest distance traveled by the units. The rally point is one such location in the map that we need to find. To keep it simple, we can treat the buildings as locations in the map as well. You may be relieved to know that in Grimsight's world all the units move from one
location to another in the shortest possible ways only.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10793d.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="right" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10793d.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Here is a sample scenario. The locations 1 through 5 are the
five unit producing buildings. Apart from those, there are five more locations
in the map. As we can see, the locations 9 and 7 are equidistant from the five
unit producing buildings. So they are the candidates for the rally point. But
we would choose location 9 over location 7 as the farthest location from 7 has
a cost of 51 whereas the farthest location from 9 would incur a cost of 40. So
the cost that Grimsight wants to measure is this distance cost 40.

<P>
Please note that the sample input/output section
does not include the example shown here.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
There can be multiple test cases. The first line of input gives you the number of test
cases, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>T</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le T \le 20$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>T</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">20</SPAN>). Then <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>T</I></SPAN> test cases follow. The first line of each input gives you
the number of locations, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>L</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $5 < L \le 100$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">5 &lt; <I>L</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">100</SPAN>), followed by the number of distance information between
the locations, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>D</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le D \le 1000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>D</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">1000</SPAN>). Each of
the next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>D</I></SPAN> lines would contain three integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>U</I></SPAN>
(<!-- MATH
 $1 \le U \le L$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>U</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>L</I></SPAN>), <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>V</I></SPAN>
(<!-- MATH
 $1 \le V \le L$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>V</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>L</I></SPAN>) and C
(<!-- MATH
 $1 \le C \le 1000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>C</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10793a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">1000</SPAN>) indicating a distance of
cost <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>C</I></SPAN> between the locations <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>U</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>V</I></SPAN>. There may be multiple occurrences of the same <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>U</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>V</I></SPAN> pair in the
input - it is up to you to decide which one to use. You should remember that a
unit does not need to cover any distance if it remains static. We would
consider the locations 1 through 5 to be the five buildings of our interest.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each of the test case, you
need to print one line of output. The output for each test case should start
with the serial number of the map, followed by the minimum possible distance
from the farthest point. This distance, as we have already mentioned, has to be
measured from the rally point which is equidistant from the five buildings. It
is implied that all the locations in the map should be reachable from this
point. When such a point does not exist you should print a `<TT>-1</TT>' instead.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
2
7 11
1 7 2
2 7 2
3 7 2
5 7 2
6 7 1
1 6 1
2 6 1
3 6 1
4 6 1
5 6 1
7 6 1
6 1
1 2 3
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
Map 1: 1
Map 2: -1
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR>
<hr>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Monirul Hasan<br>
Special Thanks: Shahriar Manzoor, Md. Kamruzzaman
</ADDRESS>
<HR>
<ADDRESS>
Miguel Revilla
2004-12-10
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10794||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Deadly Olympic Returns!!!</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="The Deadly Olympic Returns!!!">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
The Deadly Olympic Returns!!!</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10794.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="right" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10794.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10794.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
It is now <B>10000 AD</B>. In this problem we will talk about the resumption of a World wide gaming festival named Olympic, which used to take place long ago in the twentieth century. The game of Olympic upheld the desire for peace (missing now a days), friendship and many other good things among nations. But it itself was also a contest  a desire to win, a desire to outplay the opponent. As time
has passed by, man has become more aggressive or cruel for success. So the
newly formed <B>International Olympic Committee (IOC)</B> has decided to
encourage such desires by including <B>wrestling like game</B> which
had its origin some <B>9,000</B> years ago from today and its brutality enjoyed
the patronage of many royal houses. But <B>IOC</B> has introduced some
technological changes in the game. They have decided to follow the format of <B>dogfight</B>
used in war. Both the opponents will bring their best possible aircrafts
(provided by their own country's air force) loaded with missiles. At some point
one of them will throw a missile to another player. At the same time the other
player will also throw a missile to stop the opponent's one. If both of them
survive, the game will continue. The commentators want to predict the result of
the game (as they always do) before it happens. So, they are aided with a
computer to calculate the minimum possible distance between the thrown
missiles. You are appointed to write the necessary program for it.


<P>
To make things easier,
it is assumed that the missiles used here always travel in a straight line
until they are hindered by another missile. Here all positions are considered
in three-dimensional space. You can ignore any effect of the existence of the
aircrafts.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Input
starts with an integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>T</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le T \le 500$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10794.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>T</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10794.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">500</SPAN>) denoting the number of
test cases to follow. Each test case has three lines. First line has a positive
integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>time</I></SPAN>. Second line of a test case has six integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>y</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>z</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>,
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>y</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>z</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN>. <!-- MATH
 $(x_1, y_1, z_1)$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>x</I><SUB>1</SUB>, <I>y</I><SUB>1</SUB>, <I>z</I><SUB>1</SUB>)</SPAN> is the current position of the first player
from where he throws the missile and <!-- MATH
 $(x_2, y_2, z_2)$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>x</I><SUB>2</SUB>, <I>y</I><SUB>2</SUB>, <I>z</I><SUB>2</SUB>)</SPAN> is the position of the
missile after <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>time</I></SPAN> seconds. The third line contains the same set of
information for the second contestant. All values are less than <B>10000</B>.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
There should be one line of output for each test case. At
first print `<TT>Case <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I></SPAN>: </TT>'
(without the quotes) where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I></SPAN> is an integer denoting the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I></SPAN>-th
test case starting from one. Then print the minimum possible
distance between the two missiles in the same line with four
digits after the decimal point. See
the sample output below for exact formatting.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
2
1
0 0 0 1 0 0
0 -1 0 0 -2 0
4
0 0 0 1 0 0
-1 0 0 -2 0 0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
Case 1: 1.0000
Case 2: 1.0000
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR>
<hr>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Mohammad Sajjad Hossain<br>
Special Thanks: Shahriar Manzoor
</ADDRESS>
<HR>
<ADDRESS>
Miguel Revilla
2004-12-10
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

10795||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>A Different Task</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="A Different Task">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
A Different Task</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10795a.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10795a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10795a.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
The (Three peg) Tower of Hanoi problem is a popular
one in computer science. Briefly the problem is
to transfer all the disks from
peg-<B>A</B> to peg-<B>C</B> using peg-<B>B</B> as intermediate one in such a
way that at no stage a larger disk is above a smaller disk. Normally, we want
the minimum number of moves required for this task. The problem is used as an
ideal example for learning recursion. It is so well studied that one can find
the sequence of moves for smaller number of disks such as <B>3</B> or <B>4</B>.
A trivial computer program can find the case of large number of disks also.

<P>

<P>
<BR>
Here we have made your task little bit difficult by
making the problem more flexible. Here the disks can be in any peg initially.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10795b.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10795a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10795b.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
If more than one disk is in a certain peg, then they will be in a valid arrangement (larger disk will not be on smaller ones). We will give you two such arrangements of disks. You will
have to find out the minimum number of moves, which will transform the first
arrangement into the second one. Of course you always have to maintain the
constraint that smaller disks must be upon the larger ones.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The
input file contains at most <B>100</B> test cases. Each test case starts with a
positive integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le N \le 60$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10795a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10795a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">60</SPAN>), which means the
number of disks. You will be given the arrangements in next two lines. Each
arrangement will be represented by <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> integers, which are <B>1</B>, <B>2</B>
or <B>3</B>. If the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I></SPAN>-th (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le i \le N$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10795a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>i</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10795a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I></SPAN>)
integer is <B>1</B>, you should consider that <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I></SPAN>-th disk is on
Peg-<B>A</B>. Input is terminated by <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> = 0</SPAN>. This case should not be
processed. 

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Output
of each test case should consist of a line starting with 
`<TT>Case <SPAN CLASS="MATH">#</SPAN>: </TT>' where <SPAN CLASS="MATH">#</SPAN> is the test case number. 
It should be followed by the minimum number
of moves as specified in the problem statement.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
3
1 1 1
2 2 2
3
1 2 3
3 2 1
4
1 1 1 1
1 1 1 1
0
</PRE>   

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
Case 1: 7
Case 2: 3
Case 3: 0
</PRE> 

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Md. Kamruzzaman<br>
Special Thanks: Derek Kisman (Alternate Solution), Shahriar Manzoor (Picture Drawing)
</ADDRESS>
<hr>

<ADDRESS>
Miguel Revilla
2004-12-10
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10796||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Right Hand Rule</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Right Hand Rule">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Right Hand Rule</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Mazes
are one of the most popular forms of puzzles. The numerous branches and dead
ends of intricately constructed mazes can put the patience and problem-solving
skill of the solver to a challenging test. But even for a budding programmer,
writing a computer program that explores a maze is a trivial task. However, the
addition of a rather ``not so intelligent" agent to the maze can really make it
delicate.

<P>

<P>
<BR>
There
are many strategies that one can employ while exploring a maze. Marking off the
cells, and carrying a ball of thread are two such strategies. There is yet
another strategy which we call the ``Right Hand Rule". This rule suggests that
the solver keeps the right hand in constant contact with one of the walls as he
proceeds. This method guarantees that if there is an exit, the solver will be
able to reach it, if it is reachable from the cell he started. Otherwise, it
would take him through every cell that is reachable from his starting cell.
This may not be the best idea when one would want to go from a cell to another
cell in the maze. But if we would like to put a programmed agent to keep
exploring the maze, this rule can be quite useful.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10796a.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="left" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10796a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10796a.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
In this
problem, we have one such programmed agent, called ``<B>Agent K</B>", that is
continuously exploring a rectangular maze. <B>Agent K</B> can move in four directions,
<B>UP</B>, <B>DOWN</B>, <B>LEFT</B> and <B>RIGHT</B>, but cannot move through
the walls. <B>K</B> has its right hand in constant contact with the wall.
It goes through the cells of the maze taking one unit time to make a
move. It does not take any time to make a turn in the same cell, though.
It may happen that <B>K</B>
finds an exit from the maze and falls out.
But that does not end <B>K</B>'s
exploration. The moment it falls out,
it is re-spawned in the cell from where
its journey began.

<P>
The
accompanying picture illustrates this scenario. In a <!-- MATH
 $10 \times 10$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">10&#215;10</SPAN> rectangular
maze, Agent <B>K</B> is placed in cell (9,3) facing <B>UP</B>. The
impermeable walls are gray, and the passable cells are white. <B>K</B> follows
the right hand rule and moves along the path in the red line. At time 42,
<B>K</B> is at cell (3,0) - so at time 43, <B>K</B> is supposed to be out
of the maze. But instead of falling out, <B>K</B> reappears at cell (9,2)
at time 43. For some mazes it may happen that <B>K</B> never finds an
exit. In those cases, <B>K</B> will have a closed path, which in which it would loop
forever.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10796b.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="left" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10796a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10796b.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Now your task is to find the shortest path from a given starting cell to a
designated destination cell. You must avoid <B>Agent K</B> at all cost. You may not be in the same cell as <B>K</B> at the same time as him, and you may not walk to a cell if <B>K</B> is walking from that cell to your cell (then you would be caught in the corridor if you and <B>K</B> approach each other from opposite
direction). You can move in the same four directions as <B>K</B>, and you both
make your moves simultaneously. Additionally, you may choose to not move, and
wait one unit of time for agent <B>K</B> to do its next move.

<P>
Let us
illustrate this scenario in the same sample maze. If you are to go from cell (1,1) to cell (9,2) in shortest possible time, one approach could be waiting
at cell (1,1) till time 10 and then start moving along the path
shown in blue. There are of course, other ways to go from (1,1) to (9,2)
but the minimum possible time required remains to be 21. You only need
to compute the minimum time, not the path.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input consists of several test cases. The first
line of the input file contains a single integer, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>T</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le T \le 25$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10796a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>T</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10796a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">25</SPAN>)
indicating the number of test cases. Then <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>T</I></SPAN> test cases follow. The first line
of each of the test case would give you the number of rows, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>R</I></SPAN>
(<!-- MATH
 $1 \le R \le 20$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10796a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>R</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10796a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">20</SPAN>) and the number of columns, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>C</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le C \le 20$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10796a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>C</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10796a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">20</SPAN>)
of the maze. In the next line you would find three pairs of numbers and a
letter. The pairs are given in row, column format representing your starting
cell, destination cell and agent <B>K</B>'s starting cell respectively. The
letter at the end of this line can be `<TT>U</TT>', `<TT>D</TT>', `<TT>L</TT>', or `<TT>R</TT>'
giving you the direction <B>K</B> is facing. So `<TT>1 1 9 2 9 2 U</TT>' would
essentially mean that you are at cell (1,1), you need to go to cell (9,2),
and agent <B>K</B> is at cell (9,2) and is facing <B>UP</B>. It is
guaranteed that there will be a wall to the right hand side of agent <B>K</B>.
In the next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>R</I></SPAN> lines, the maze description is given. A `<TT>#</TT>' in a
cell represents an impermeable wall, whereas a `<TT>.</TT>' would mean that the
cell is passable. Cell (0,0) is the upper left corner of the maze.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The output for each test case starts with the test case
number in the format `<TT>Maze <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I></SPAN>: </TT>' where <!-- MATH
 $1 \le x \le T$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10796a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>x</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10796a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>T</I></SPAN>. Then
there would be exactly one integer denoting the minimum unit time required for
you to reach the destined cell; if it is impossible to reach the destined cell,
output `<TT>-1</TT>' instead.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
3
10 10
1 1 9 2 9 2 U
##########
#........#
#.####.#.#
..#..#.#.#
.....#.#.#
.###.#.#.#
.#.#.#.#.#
.#.#.###.#
.#.#.....#
...#######
5 5
0 0 4 3 4 3 U
.....
##.#.
....#
.##.#
....#
5 5
0 0 2 3 3 3 U
.....
#####
.#..#
.#..#
.####
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
Maze 1: 21
Maze 2: 15
Maze 3: -1
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR>
<hr>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Monirul Hasan<br>
Special Thanks: Jimmy Mårdell, Md. Kamruzzaman
</ADDRESS>

<HR>
<ADDRESS>
Miguel Revilla
2004-12-10
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

10797||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Peaceful Sharing</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Peaceful Sharing">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Peaceful Sharing</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Two neighboring
countries named Fobos and Dimos are in trouble with their natural resources.
All the Gold mines are in Fobos and all the Coal mines are in Dimos and the
Coal mines are always a good source of Diamond. So whenever Fobos needs Diamond
she has to buy it from Dimos and vice versa. The peace loving Presidents (!) of
these two countries meet to find out a way of sharing their resources and they
decide very quickly to draw an <B>Inter Country Mine Line (ICML)</B>, which is a straight-line that divides both the Gold mines and Coal
mines equally. I mean if Fobos has 10 Gold mines and Dimos has 16 Coal mines then there will be 5 (=10/2) Gold mines and 8 (=16/2) Coal mines on one
side of the <B>ICML</B> and the rest of the
mines will be on the other side. Fobos will own the mines on one side of the
line and Dimos will own the mines on the other side. But unfortunately, the
number of both Gold mines and Coal mines are odd so they cannot be equally
shared. Therefore, the Presidents have also decided that one Gold mine and one
Coal mine will be on the <B>ICML</B> and those two special mines will be owned by both the countries. Now
your job is two find these two special mines.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10797.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10797.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10797.eps}">
</DIV>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"></DIV>
<P>
<BR>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><B>Figure: </B>The figure above shows a typical
scenario that is stated in this problem. There are total five Gold mines and
seven Coal mines. So when they are equally divided into two parts then
both sides have two Gold mines and three Coal mines. The <B>ICML</B>
passes through the other Gold and Coal mine. If the total number of each
type of mines is odd and no three mines are on the same line then
<B>ICML</B> is always unique. The goal of this problem is to find the two
mines that are on the <B>ICML</B>.

</DIV>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input fine contains maximum <B>20</B> sets of inputs. The description of each set is given below:

<P>

<P>
<BR>
Each set starts with an even integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $0 < N \le 10000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10797.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10000</SPAN>), which indicates how many mines are there in this case. Each of the next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> lines contains two floating-point numbers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>y</I></SPAN>
(<!-- MATH
 $0 < |x|, |y| < 10000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; | <I>x</I>|,| <I>y</I>| &lt; 10000</SPAN>) and (<!-- MATH
 $|x| \ge 1.0$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">| <I>x</I>|<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10797.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \ge$">1.0</SPAN>), which indicates the location of a mine
in Cartesian coordinate system. The mines on the left side of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>y</I></SPAN>-axis
(negative <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I></SPAN> coordinate) are Gold mines and the mines on the right side
of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>y</I></SPAN>-axis (positive <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I></SPAN> coordinate) are Coal mines. The identifier
for each mine is in the order they appear in the input, starting from zero. But
the identifier series for Gold and Coal mines are different. So the first Gold
mine in the input file has serial <B>0</B>, the second Gold Mine has serial <B>1</B>
and similarly the first Coal mine in the input has serial <B>0</B>, the second
Coal mine has serial <B>1</B> etc. You can assume that no three mines are on
the same line and no two mines are in the same place as mines are always
naturally distributed.

<P>
Input
is terminated by a case where the value of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> is zero. This case should
not be processed.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each set of input produce one line of output. This line contains the
serial of
output followed by two integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>g</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>c</I></SPAN>, where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>g</I></SPAN> is serial
of the Gold mine that is on the <B>ICML</B> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>c</I></SPAN> is the serial of the
Coal mine that is on the <B>ICML</B>.

<P>
Look at the output for sample input for details.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
8
2397.3580 -1218.2430
3882.3760 -1892.8990
5038.0060 110.7790
4151.7250 2203.4090
1244.6460 3047.0100
-2567.4500 4835.3570
2964.6920 1447.6210
3742.6950 -1039.6250
8
3533.6490 -610.2480
-2707.0150 -3010.9940
-3440.8270 4392.1250
-54.2620 2227.8020
90.9070 2297.0630
-3236.5420 2868.4760
-1882.3930 -521.8910
3031.9350 -2618.9450
0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
Case 1: 0 2
Case 2: 3 0
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR>
<hr>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Shahriar Manzoor<br>
Special Thanks: Derek Kisman
</ADDRESS>

<HR>
<ADDRESS>
Miguel Revilla
2004-12-10
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10798||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Be Wary of Roses</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Be Wary of Roses">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Be Wary of Roses</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
You've always been proud of your prize rose garden. However, some
jealous fellow gardeners will stop at nothing to gain an edge over you.
They have kidnapped, blindfolded, and handcuffed you, and dumped you
right in the middle of your
treasured roses! You need to get out, but you're not sure you can do it
without trampling any precious flowers.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10798.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="right" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10798.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10798.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Fortunately,
you have the layout of your garden committed to memory. It is an
<!-- MATH
 $N \times N$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I>&#215;<I>N</I></SPAN> collection of square plots (<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> odd), some containing
roses. You are standing on a square marble plinth in the exact center.
Unfortunately, you are
quite disoriented, and have no idea which direction you're facing! Thanks to
the plinth, you can orient yourself facing one of <B>North</B>, <B>East</B>, <B>South</B>,
or <B>West</B>, but you have no way to know which.

<P>
You must come up with an escape path that tramples the fewest possible roses, no matter which direction you're initially facing. Your path must start in the center, consist only of horizontal and vertical moves, and end by leaving the grid.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Every case begins with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>, the size of grid (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le N \le 21$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10798.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10798.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">21</SPAN>), on a line. <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> lines with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> characters each follow, describing the garden: `<TT>.</TT>' indicates a plot
without any roses, `<TT>R</TT>' indicates the location of a rose, and `<TT>P</TT>' stands for the plinth in the center.

<P>
Input will end on a case where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> = 0</SPAN>. This case should not be processed.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each case, output a line containing the minimum guaranteed number of roses you can step on while escaping.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
5
.RRR.
R.R.R
R.P.R
R.R.R
.RRR.
0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
At most 2 rose(s) trampled.
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR>
<hr>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Derek Kisman<br>
Special Thanks: Md. Kamruzzaman
</ADDRESS>

<HR>
<ADDRESS>
Miguel Revilla
2004-12-10
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

10799||||||false||||||

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>OOPS! They did it Again</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="OOPS! They did it Again">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
OOPS! They did it Again</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
The Aliens of the Planet Muzambaro have re-elected their universally unpopular
leader. After the result was announced the disappointed newspapers of some
other planets had the headline ``OOPS! They did it again." Well now it is party
time in Muzambaro and so they are planning to decorate <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> Skyscrapers of
their city with lights.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10799.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10799.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10799.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
The longest street of planet Muzambaro
is ``The Deaf Street". The properties of this street are stated below:

<P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT>a)</DT>
<DD>There are buildings on only one side of this street.
</DD>
<DT>b)</DT>
<DD>The total number of buildings on this one sidecan be as many as <B>20000000</B> (<B>20</B> Million).
</DD>
<DT>c)</DT>
<DD>The distance between any two consecutive buildings is equal as shown in
the figure above. But if the total number of building is less than three then
this rule is not valid. The size and shape of all the buildings are the same. 
</DD>
<DT>d)</DT>
<DD>The buildings are numbered sequentially. So if the number of the leftmost
building is <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>low</I></SPAN> and the number of the rightmost building is <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>high</I></SPAN>
then there are total (<!-- MATH
 $high-low+1$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>high</I> - <I>low</I> + 1</SPAN>) buildings. 
</DD>
</DL> 

<P>
From these <!-- MATH
 $(high-low+1)$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>high</I> - <I>low</I> + 1)</SPAN> buildings they want to select <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> buildings 
to decorate with lights in the following way:

<P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT>a)</DT>
<DD>Any two consecutive buildings of the selected buildings must
be equidistant. For example if <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I> = 4</SPAN> then buildings 
<B>1</B>, <B>4</B>, <B>7</B> and <B>10</B> of the above picture can be a 
possible choice according to this particular rule. 
</DD>
<DT>b)</DT>
<DD>The sum of the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> building numbers must be divisible by <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>.
For example the choice <B>1</B>, <B>4</B>, <B>7</B> and <B>10</B> is 
not valid according to this particular rule as <!-- MATH
 $(1+4+7+10)= 22$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">(1 + 4 + 7 + 10) = 22</SPAN>, which 
is not divisible by 4. 
</DD>
</DL>

<P>
Now given the value of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>low</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>high</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> the Aliens of Planet Muzambaro wants to determine in how many ways they can choose the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> buildings. They have written a brute
force program to find out the answer but they know that it wont terminate even
in four years!! That is why they are now asking for your help. Can you help them?

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input file contains less than 1001 lines of inputs. The description of each line of input is given below:

<P>

<P>
<BR>
Each line of input describes one particular scenario. There are three 
integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>low</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>high</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $0 < low < high <20000001$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>low</I> &lt; <I>high</I> &lt; 20000001</SPAN>)
and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1 < k \le (high-low+1)$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1 &lt; <I>k</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/107/p10799.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$">(<I>high</I> - <I>low</I> + 1)</SPAN>) in each line. The meaning of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>low</I></SPAN>,
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>high</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> are given in the problem statement above.

<P>
Input is terminated by a case where <!-- MATH
 $low=high=k=0$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>low</I> = <I>high</I> = <I>k</I> = 0</SPAN>
which should not be processed.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each line of input you should produce one line of output. This line
should contain the serial of output followed by an integer, 
which indicates the number of ways they can choose the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> buildings. 
Look at the output for sample input for details.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE> 
1 10 4  
2 10 4
1 48 2
1222 2329228 2
0 0 0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
Case 1: 4
Case 2: 3
Case 3: 552
Case 4: 1354902984009
</PRE> 

<P>

<P>
<BR>
<hr>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Shahriar Manzoor<br>
Special Thanks: Derek Kisman, Syed Monowar Hossain
</ADDRESS>
<HR>
<ADDRESS>
Miguel Revilla
2004-12-10
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

10800||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Not That Kind of Graph</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem ?</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Not That Kind of Graph</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 1 second</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>"You know, it's all very sweet, stealing from the<br>
rich, selling to the poor..."</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Jose Molina, "Firefly."</tt>
</small></p>



<P CLASS="paragraph">
Your task is to graph the price of a stock over time. In one unit
of time, the stock can either <b>R</b>ise, <b>F</b>all or stay
<b>C</b>onstant. The stock's price will be given to you as a string
of R's, F's and C's. You need to graph it using the characters '/'
(slash), '\' (backslash) and '_' (underscore).
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one contains a string of at least
1 and at most 50 upper case characters (R, F or C).
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output the line "Case #<b>x</b>:", where <b>x</b> is the
number of the test case. Then print the graph, as shown in the sample
output, including the x- and y-axes. The x-axis should be one character
longer than the graph, and there should be one space between the y-axis
and the start of the graph. There should be no trailing spaces on any line. 
Do not print unnecessary lines. The x-axis should always appear directly below
the graph. Finally, print an empty line after each test case.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
1
RCRFCRFFCCRRC
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1:
|             _
|  _/\_/\    /
| /      \__/
+---------------

</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10801||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Lift Hopping</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem ?</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Lift Hopping</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 1 second</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
Ted the bellhop: <i>"I'm coming up and if there isn't<br>
a dead body by the time I get there, I'll make one<br>
myself. You!"</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Robert Rodriguez, "Four Rooms."</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
A skyscraper has no more than 100 floors, numbered from 0 to 99.
It has <b>n</b> (1&lt;=<b>n</b>&lt;=5) elevators which travel
up and down at (possibly) different speeds. For each <b>i</b>
in {1, 2,... n}, elevator number <b>i</b> takes
<b>T<sub>i</sub></b> (1&lt;=<b>T<sub>i</sub></b>&lt;=100) seconds
to travel between any two adjacent floors (going up or down).
Elevators do not necessarily stop at every floor. What's worse,
not every floor is necessarily accessible by an elevator.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
You are on floor 0 and would like to get to floor <b>k</b> as
quickly as possible. Assume that you do not need to wait to
board the first elevator you step into and (for simplicity) the
operation of switching an elevator on some floor always takes
exactly a minute. Of course, both elevators have to stop at
that floor. You are forbiden from using the staircase. No one
else is in the elevator with you, so you don't have to stop if
you don't want to. Calculate the minimum number of seconds
required to get from floor 0 to floor <b>k</b> (passing floor
<b>k</b> while inside an elevator that does not stop there does
not count as "getting to floor <b>k</b>").
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The input will consist of a number of test cases. Each test case
will begin with two numbers, <b>n</b> and <b>k</b>, on a line. The
next line will contain the numbers <b>T<sub>1</sub></b>,
<b>T<sub>2</sub></b>,... <b>T<sub>n</sub></b>. Finally, the next
<b>n</b> lines will contain sorted lists of integers - the first
line will list the floors visited by elevator number 1, the next
one will list the floors visited by elevator number 2, etc.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
<p>
For each test case, output one number on a line by itself - the
minimum number of seconds required to get to floor <b>k</b> from
floor 0. If it is impossible to do, print "IMPOSSIBLE" instead.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
2 30
10 5
0 1 3 5 7 9 11 13 15 20 99
4 13 15 19 20 25 30
2 30
10 1
0 5 10 12 14 20 25 30
2 4 6 8 10 12 14 22 25 28 29
3 50
10 50 100
0 10 30 40
0 20 30
0 20 50
1 1
2
0 2 4 6 8 10
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
275
285
3920
IMPOSSIBLE
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Explanation of examples</B></FONT><BR>
<p>
In the first example, take elevator 1 to floor 13 (130 seconds),
wait 60 seconds to switch to elevator 2 and ride it to floor
30 (85 seconds) for a total of 275 seconds.
</p>

<p>
In the second example, take elevator 1 to floor 10, switch to
elevator 2 and ride it until floor 25. There, switch back to
elevator 1 and get off at the 30'th floor. The total time is
<br>10*10 + 60 + 15*1 + 60 + 5*10 = 285 seconds.
</p>

<p>
In example 3, take elevator 1 to floor 30, then elevator 2 to
floor 20 and then elevator 3 to floor 50.
</p>

<p>
In the last example, the one elevator does not stop at floor 1.
</p>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B><br>
<B>Alternate solutions: Stefan Pochmann, Frank Pok Man Chu
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10802||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Lex Smallest Drive</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem ?</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Lex Smallest Drive</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 2 seconds</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>"OK. Let's go right."</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Bartholomew Furrow</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
A <i>graph</i>, G, consists of a finite set of <i>vertices</i>, V, and 
a set of <i>edges</i>, E, where each edge is a set of 2 vertices {u, v}. 
A <i>walk</i> in G is a finite sequence of vertices 
(v<sub>1</sub>, v<sub>2</sub>, ..., v<sub>k</sub>), such that for
each pair (v<sub>i-1</sub>, v<sub>i</sub>) for i in [2, k], 
{v<sub>i-1</sub>, v<sub>i</sub>} is in E. This is called a "walk
from v<sub>1</sub> to v<sub>k</sub>". If V is a set of integers,
then any two walks in G can be compared lexicographically; for
example, the walk (3, 5, 6, 2, 8) is smaller than the walk 
(3, 5, 6, 5, 7). A walk, W, from a to b is <i>lexicographically 
smallest</i> if there is no other walk from a to b in G that is smaller 
than W. A <i>drive</i> is a walk 
(v<sub>1</sub>, v<sub>2</sub>, ..., v<sub>k</sub>), where no edge is
used twice consecutively. That is, for all i from 2 up to k-1, 
v<sub>i-1</sub> is not equal to v<sub>i+1</sub>.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
Given G and a start vertex, <b>s</b>, your task is to find the 
lexicographically smallest drives from <b>s</b> to each vertex in G.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one starts with a line containing
the integers <b>n</b>, <b>m</b> and <b>s</b>.
(0 &lt;= <b>n</b> &lt;= 100, 0 &lt;= <b>m</b> &lt;= 4950).
The next <b>m</b> lines will list the edges of G. V is the set {0, 1,
..., <b>n</b>-1}. <b>s</b> is in V.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output the line "Case #<b>x</b>:", where <b>x</b> is the
number of the test case. Then print <b>n</b> lines, line i listing the
lexicographically smallest drive from <b>s</b> to i using single spaces to
separate consecutive vertices. If there is no such drive, print "No drive."
Put an empty line after each test case.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
2
6 4 5
5 0
2 5
4 0
3 1
4 4 0
0 1
1 2
0 2
0 3
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1:
5 0
No drive.
5 2
No drive.
5 0 4
5

Case #2:
0
0 1
0 1 2
No drive.

</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B><br>
<B>Alternate solutions: Yury Kholondyrev, Bartholomew Furrow</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10803||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Thunder Mountain</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem ?</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Thunder Mountain</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 3 seconds</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>"I mean, some people got guns, and some<br>
people got flashlights, and some people got <br>
batteries. These guys had all three."</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>J. Michael Straczynski, "Jeremiah."</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
Markus is building an army to fight the evil Valhalla Sector, so he
needs to move some supplies between several of the nearby towns. The
woods are full of robbers and other unfriendly folk, so it's dangerous
to travel far. As Thunder Mountain's head of security, Lee thinks that
it is unsafe to carry supplies for more than 10km without visiting a 
town. Markus wants to know how far one would need to travel
to get from one town to another in the worst case.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one starts with a line containing
<b>n</b> (the number of towns, 1&lt;<b>n</b>&lt;101). The next <b>n</b> 
lines will give the xy-locations of each town in km (integers in the range 
[0, 1023]). Assume that the Earth is flat and the whole 1024x1024 grid
is covered by a forest with roads connecting each pair of towns that are
no further than 10km away from each other.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output the line "Case #<b>x</b>:", where <b>x</b> is the
number of the test case. On the next line, print the maximum distance one
has to travel from town A to town B (for some A and B). Round the answer to 4 
decimal places. Every answer will obey the formula<br>
<pre>fabs(ans*1e4 - floor(ans*1e4) - 0.5) > 1e-2</pre><br>
If it is impossible to get from some town to some other town, print
"Send Kurdy" instead.
Put an empty line after each test case.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>

</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
2
5
0 0
10 0
10 10
13 10
13 14
2
0 0
10 1
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1:
25.0000

Case #2:
Send Kurdy

</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
