10840||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Multi-stage Compressor</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem A</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Multi-stage Compressor</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 1 second</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
As part of an engeener team in ACM (Association for Compressors
and Machinery) you're working in an air-condition system for a
plane. As ambient air at 10km over surface is too cold, you have to mix
it with some hot air from the engine.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
To design the system, you need to know the pressure of the hot air at the
bleeding point. You're supposed to bleed the air from one of the stages of
the compressor in the engine. Unfortunately, you don't know pressures at
intermediate stages, you can only measure pressure at the begining of the
compressor. So, in this problem <u>you'll have to calculate pressure at stage
<b>i</b></u>.
</P>

About the compressor, you know:
<blockquote>
	<li>Its global pressure ratio, that is, the pressure at the end of
	the compressor (p<sub>n+1</sub>)divided by the ambient pressure(p<sub>1</sub>). Since you know ambient pressure,
	you can easily 	calculate the pressure at the end of the compressor.
	<li>The air is a perfect gas (that is, parameters c<sub>p</sub> and <img src=p108405.gif> are constant).
	<li>After every stage of the compressor, there is a system that turns air's
	temperature, T<sub>i</sub>, into ambient air temperature, T<sub>1</sub>. We
	suppose there's no pressure loss in this process.
	<li>The compressor has some constant (unknown) parametes: <img src=p108401.gif><sub>i</sub> (efficiency) and
	<img src=p108402.gif> (the mass of air entering in the compressor each second). <img src=p108401.gif><sub>i</sub> is
	defined as:

<p align=center><img src=p108403.gif>

	<li>Compressor's global power needed is <u>minimum</u>. Power for each stage is defined as:

<p align=center><img src=p108404.gif>
</blockquote>

<p CLASS="paragraph">With all these, stage i's representation is as follows:
<p align=center><img src=p108406.gif width=500 height=200>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one is a line containing
<b>n</b> (the number of stages), <b>p<sub>1</sub> (p<sub>1</sub>&gt;0</b>) (ambient pressure),
<b>p<sub>n+1</sub> (p<sub>n+1</sub>&ge; p<sub>1</sub>)</b> (final pressure) and <b>i  (with 1 &le; i &le; n+1)</b> (the stage you bleed air from).
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output one line containing <b>p<sub>i</sub></b>, the pressure at stage <b>i</b>, rounded to 2 decimal digits.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
3
2 1 2 1
2 1 2 2
2 1 2 3
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
1.00
1.41
2.00
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Carlos M. Casas Cuadrado</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10841||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Lift Hopping in the Real World</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem B</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Lift Hopping in the Real World</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 1 second</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>"I think problem descriptions should withstand the<br>
reality check, otherwise they are misleading."</i><br>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>little joey</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
A skyscraper has no more than 100 floors, numbered from 0 to 99.
It has <b>n</b> (1&lt;=<b>n</b>&lt;=50) elevators which travel
up and down at (possibly) different speeds. For each <b>i</b>
in {1, 2,... <b>n</b>}, elevator number <b>i</b> takes
<b>T<sub>i</sub></b> (1&lt;=<b>T<sub>i</sub></b>&lt;=100) seconds
to travel between any two adjacent floors (going up or down).
Elevators do not necessarily stop on every floor. What's worse,
not every floor is necessarily accessible by an elevator.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
You are on floor 0 and would like to get to floor <b>k</b> as
quickly as possible. When you first arrive to floor 0,
each of the <b>n</b> elevators could be parked on any of the
floors accessible by that elevator. You can take any of the
elevators that stop on floor 0 and you can switch elevators
on any floor, f, if both of them stop on floor f. Assume that 
it takes 5 seconds to exit one elevator and push another
elevator's button. You are forbiden from using the 
staircase. No one else is in the building, so you don't have to 
stop if you don't want to, and no one else will request an elevator.
Each elevator has its own button, and the system has built-in
security to prevent abuse by evil teenagers - once you press
the button calling for some elevator E, all the buttons 
calling for other elevators will be disabled until elevator E
arrives at your floor. In other words, you can only call for
one elevator at a time.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
Calculate the number of seconds required to get from floor 0 to floor 
<b>k</b> in the worst case if you do not know the initial positions of 
the elevators. Passing floor <b>k</b> while inside an elevator that does 
not stop there does not count as "getting to floor <b>k</b>". See the 
examples below.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The input will consist of a number of test cases. Each test case
will begin with two numbers, <b>n</b> and <b>k</b>, on a line. The
next line will contain the numbers <b>T<sub>1</sub></b>,
<b>T<sub>2</sub></b>,... <b>T<sub>n</sub></b>. The next
<b>n</b> lines will contain sorted lists of integers - the first
line will list the floors visited by elevator number 1, the next
one - those visited by elevator number 2, etc.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
<p>
For each test case, output one number on a line - the number of seconds 
required to get to floor <b>k</b> from floor 0 in the worst case. If floor
<b>k</b> is inaccessible from floor 0, print "IMPOSSIBLE" instead.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
2 30
10 5
0 1 3 5 7 9 11 13 15 20 99
4 13 15 19 20 25 30
2 30
10 1
0 5 10 12 14 20 25 30
2 4 6 8 10 12 14 22 25 28 29
3 50
10 50 100
0 10 30 40
0 20 30
0 20 50
1 1
2
0 2 4 6 8 10
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
1295
600
8505
IMPOSSIBLE
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Discussion</B></FONT><BR>
<p>
In the first example, the worst case is when elevator 1 is on 
floor 99 and will take 990 seconds to reach floor 0. You will 
then take it to floor 13 in 130 seconds, spend 5 second exiting 
and calling elevator 2, which is on floor 30. It will take 170 
seconds to reach you and 170 seconds to take you to floor 30. 
The total is 1295 seconds.
</p>

<p>
In the second example, the only sensible way to get to floor
30 is to ride the first elevator all the way. Switching to
elevator 2 and then back will only make things worse because 
elevator 1 must take at least 300 seconds to reach floor 30.
In the worst case, elevator 1 starts on floor 30.
</p>

<p>
In example 3, the security system will not allow you to push 
all 3 buttons and see which elevator comes first. Instead, you
should push elevator 2's button. Unfortunately, it is on floor 
30 and takes 1500 seconds to get to you. You board it and it
takes you to floor 20 in 1000 seconds. You spend 5 seconds
pushing the button for elevator 3, which is on floor 50. It
takes 3000 seconds before it reaches floor 20 and 3000 more
seconds to take you to floor 50. The total is 8505 seconds.
If you take elevator 1 first, your worst case time will be
8710 seconds.
</p>

<p>
In the last example, the one elevator does not stop at floor 1.
</p>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B><br>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10842||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Traffic Flow</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem C</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Traffic Flow</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 2 seconds</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>"Arnie Pie in the sky with the morning commute.<br>
Traffic this morning is as bad as it gets. Due to<br>
a fire at the army testing lab a bunch of escaped,<br>
infected mokeys are roaming the expressway. Despite<br>
the swealtering heat, don't unroll your windows<br>
'cause those monkeys seem confused and irritable."</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Arnie Pie, "The Simpsons."</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
A city has <b>n</b> intersections and <b>m</b> bidirectional roads connecting
pairs of intersections. Each road has a certain traffic flow capacity, 
measured in cars per minute. There is a path from every intersection
to every other intersection along some sequence of roads. The road
maintenance department is over budget and needs to close as many roads 
as possible without disconnecting any intersections. They want to
do it in such a way that the minimum capacity among all of the 
remaining roads is as large as possible.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one starts with a line containing
<b>n</b> (0&lt;<b>n</b>&lt;=100) and <b>m</b> (0&lt;<b>m</b>&lt;=10000). 
The next <b>m</b> lines will describe the m roads, each one using 3 
integers, <b>u</b>, <b>v</b> and <b>c</b> (0&lt;=<b>u</b>,<b>v</b>&lt;<b>n</b>), 
(0&lt;<b>c</b>&lt;=1000). <b>u</b> and <b>v</b>
are the endpoints of the road and <b>c</b> is its capacity.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output one line containing "Case #<b>x</b>:"
followed by the capacity of the minimum-capacity remaining road.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
2
2 3
0 1 10
0 1 20
0 0 30
4 5
0 1 1
3 1 2
1 2 3
2 3 4
0 2 5
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1: 20
Case #2: 3
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10843||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Anne's game</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem D</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Anne's game</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 2 seconds</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
Lily: <i>"Chantarelle was part of my exotic phase."</i><br>
Buffy: <i>"It's nice. It's a mushroom."</i><br>
Lily: <i>"It is? That's really embarrassing."</i><br>
Buffy: <i>"Well, it's an exotic mushroom, if that's any comfort."</i><br>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Joss Whedon, "Anne".</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
A little girl whose name is Anne Spetring likes to play the
following game. She draws a circle on paper. Then she draws
another one and connects it to the first cicrle by a line.
Then she draws another and connects it to one of the first 
two circles by a line. She continues this way until she has
<b>n</b> circles drawn and each one connected to one of the
previously drawn circles. Her circles never intersect and
lines never cross. Finally, she numbers the circles from 1
to <b>n</b> in some random order.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
How many different pictures can she draw that contain exactly
<b>n</b> circles? Two pictures are different if one of them has
a line connecting circle number i to circle number j, and the 
other picture does not.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one is a line containing
<b>n</b> (0&lt;<b>n</b>&lt;=100).
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output one line containing "Case #<b>x</b>:" 
followed by X, where X is the remainder after dividing the answer
by 2000000011.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
3
1
2
3
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1: 1
Case #2: 1
Case #3: 3
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10844||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Bloques</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem E</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Bloques</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 2 seconds</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
Little Joan has N blocks,all of them of different sizes. He is playing to build cities in the beach. A city is
just a collection of buildings.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
A single block over the sand can be considered as a building. Then he can construct higher buildings by
putting a block above any other block. At most one block can be put immediately above any other block.
However he can stack several blocks together to construct a building. However, its not allowed to put
bigger blocks on top of smaller ones, since the stack of blocks may fall. A block can be specified by a
natural number that represents its size.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
It doesnt matter the order among buildings. That is:
<pre>
1 3
2 4
</pre>
is the same configuration as:
<pre>
3 1
4 2
</pre>
</P>


<P CLASS="paragraph">
Your problem is to compute the number of possible different cities using N blocks. We say that #(N) gives
the number of different cities of size N. If N=2, for instance, there are only two possible cities:
</P>

<pre>
City #1:
1 2
</pre>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
In this city both blocks of size 1 and 2 are put over the sand.
</P>

<pre>
City #2:
1
2
</pre>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
In this city block of size 1 is over block is size 2, and block
of size 2 is over the sand.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
So, #(2)=2.
</P>


<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
A sequence of non-negative integer numbers, each of one in different line. All of them but the last one are
natural numbers. The last one is 0 and means the end. Each natural number is less than 900.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each natural number I in the input, you must write a line with the pair of numbers I, #(I).</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
2
3
0
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
2, 2
3, 5
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Dr. Mauricio Javier Osorio Galindo</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10845||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>The crusades</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem F</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>The crusades</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 2 seconds</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align=center><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10845.jpg"  width="464" height="205">
<P CLASS="paragraph">
The Pope has commissioned the Holy Roman Empire, ruled by ruthless King Frederick Barbarossa
(Red Beard), and England, lead by brave King Richard the Lionheart, to recover the holy land
of Jerusalem from the moors.
</p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
Both commanders know very well their armies cannot meet on a road, or a
quarrel may break out. They therefore wish to take different paths to get to Jerusalem, which
means no road will be chosen by both king for their troops to march by. Soldiers from both bands
may meet at towns and cities, however, where they will probably not mind each other.
</p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
There is another difficulty: some paths are narrow and a limited number of
soldiers can march across them. To deal with this problem, both commanders are willing to divide
their troops into as many groups as it is needed in order to ensure that the greatest number of
soldiers (no matter which kingdom they belong to) will arrive at Jerusalem to fight the moors.
</p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
Given a map of towns and cities connected by roads which can admit a
certain number of soldiers and the initial position of King Frederick&rsquo;s and King Richard&rsquo;s
troops (which are always different), your task is to determine the largest number of soldiers
that can get to Jerusalem.
</p>


<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input contains the number <strong>t</strong> of test cases (1 &le; <strong>t</strong>
&le; 60). Each test case will begin with a line containing integers <strong>N</strong> and <strong>M</strong>
(5 &le; <strong>N</strong> &le; 12 and 5 &le; <strong>M</strong> &le; 30) corresponding to the number of
towns and the number of roads in the map. Towns will be numbered from 1 to <strong>N</strong>.
<strong>M</strong> lines follow, each containing integers <strong>A</strong>, <strong>B</strong> and
<strong>C</strong> (1 &le; <strong>A</strong>, <strong>B</strong> &le; <strong>N</strong> and 1 &le;
<strong>C</strong> &le; 100), indicating that there is a two-way road from town <strong>A</strong> to
town <strong>B</strong> by which at most <strong>C</strong> soldiers can march. The last line of each
case will contain integers <strong>F</strong>, <strong>R</strong> and <strong>J</strong> (1 &le;
<strong>F</strong>, <strong>R</strong>, <strong>J</strong> &le; <strong>N</strong>) corresponding to
the initial locations of Frederick&rsquo;s army, Richard&rsquo;s army and Jerusalem, which will always
be different.
</p>
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case print on a separate line the largest number of soldiers that can get to Jerusalem.</p>
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
2
6 6
1 3 10
2 3 5
3 4 11
3 5 11
4 6 11
5 6 2
1 2 6
5 6
1 5 9
1 3 10
3 2 10
3 4 9
3 5 10
5 4 100
1 2 4
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
12
28
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Rodrigo Burgos Domínguez</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10846||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Reading time from a clock</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem G</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Reading time from a clock</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 1 second</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
It is the 23rd century. Humans have finally colonized several nearby solar systems and dwell
happily in their planets. Space travel is anyway very expensive and most inhabitants of
extraterrestrial planets never again leave the surface of their planet in their lifetimes.
Thus, upon arrival to an uninhabited planet, the colonizers adjusted the traditional Earth
system of keeping track of time to the specific situation of that planet, in a way it would be
practical for that planet and at the same time similar to what they were accustomed to.
</p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
In most planets, colonizers split the duration of a day into <em><strong>m</strong></em> hours
(of duration similar to that of Earth&rsquo;s hours) and split each of those hours into
<em><strong>n</strong></em> minutes. They read time from clocks in which the hour-hand moves
continuously at a steady rate of one revolution per day, and the minute-hand moves continuously
at a steady rate of one revolution per hour; the day begins at 0h : 0min at which time both hands
are pointing upwards.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
An interstellar clock manufacturer came up with a revolutionary clock design in which both the
hour-hand and the minute-hand are the same size! They figured you could anyway tell the correct
time from the clock. For instance, assume that in a 12-hour clock (like those on Earth) one of
the hands is pointing upwards (to the 12) and the other hand is pointing to the 3: we can be sure
it is 3 o&rsquo;clock because it is impossible that the hour-hand is exactly pointing to the 12
and the minute-hand is not also pointing to the<STRONG></STRONG>12. Therefore we know it is the
hour-hand that is pointing to the 3 and from this we can tell the time.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
However, users from some planets soon complained they were having trouble telling the time from
certain positions of the hands. The clock manufacturer has hired you to write a program to determine
how many times during a certain time period confusion may arise from the position of the clock hands.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
<p> The input consists of several test cases. The first line of 
each case contains three positive integers <EM><STRONG>m</STRONG></EM>, <EM><STRONG>n</STRONG></EM> and <EM><STRONG>nq</STRONG></EM>, where <EM><STRONG>m</STRONG></EM> and <EM><STRONG>n</STRONG></EM> represent the number of hours in a day and the number of minutes in an hour for a certain planet, and <EM><STRONG>nq</STRONG></EM> is the number of queries that follow. You may assume <EM><STRONG>m</STRONG></EM>, <EM><STRONG>n</STRONG></EM>, <EM><STRONG>nq</STRONG></EM> &le; 1000. Each query is contained in a separate line and contains two times of the day, <EM><STRONG>t1</STRONG></EM> and <EM><STRONG>t2</STRONG></EM>, separated by a space. Each time of the day is given in the following format: </p>
<P align=center><EM><STRONG>h</STRONG></EM><SPAN 
class=Estilo7>:</SPAN><EM><STRONG>min</STRONG></EM> <EM><STRONG>num</STRONG></EM><SPAN 
class=Estilo7>/</SPAN><EM><STRONG>den</STRONG></EM></P>
<P>where <EM><STRONG>h</STRONG></EM> is the hours, <EM><STRONG>min</STRONG></EM> is the minutes and <EM><STRONG>num</STRONG></EM>/<EM><STRONG>den</STRONG></EM> is a fraction &lt; 1 which corresponds to a fraction of a minute. For example, in Earth time, <font face="Courier New, Courier, mono">3:30 1/2</font> would correspond to 3 hours, thirty minutes and 30 seconds (half a minute). You may assume that 0 &le; <EM><STRONG>h</STRONG></EM> &lt; <EM><STRONG>m</STRONG></EM>, 0 &le; <EM><STRONG>min</STRONG></EM> &lt; <EM><STRONG>n</STRONG></EM>, 0 &le; <EM><STRONG>num</STRONG></EM>, <EM><STRONG>den</STRONG></EM> &le; 1000 and that <EM><STRONG>t1</STRONG></EM> &le; <EM><STRONG>t2</STRONG></EM> (this means that, within a day, <EM><STRONG>t1</STRONG></EM> does not happen after <EM><STRONG>t2</STRONG></EM> ).</P>
<P>Input is terminated when <EM><STRONG>m</STRONG></EM> = <EM><STRONG>n</STRONG></EM> = <EM><STRONG>nq</STRONG></EM> = 0, this case should not be processed.</P>
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case print the header &ldquo;<SPAN class=Estilo7><font face="Courier New, Courier, mono">Planet i</font>:</SPAN>&rdquo;, without quotes, where <SPAN class=Estilo7>i</SPAN> indicates the test case number (beginning from 1) and then print, for each query, a line with a non-negative integer indicating the number of occasions in which confusion may arise from the position of the clock hands during the time interval (<EM><STRONG>t1</STRONG></EM>, <EM><STRONG>t2</STRONG></EM>]. If there are an infinite number of such occasions, print &ldquo;<SPAN class=Estilo7>Infinity</SPAN>&rdquo;, without quotes, instead of a number. Separate output from different test cases by a blank line.</p>
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
12 60 2
11:0 0/1 11:0 0/1
6:45 1/3 7:1 2/5
0 0 0
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Planet 1:
0
3
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Humberto Montalv&aacute;n G&aacute;mez</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10847||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Basic Tautologies</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem H</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Basic Tautologies</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 1 second</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
  <p >Let <em><strong>A</strong></em> := {<span class="Estilo9">=, -, a, b, c, . . . , z, A, B, C, . . . , Z</span>}.</p>
  <p >We assume that <span class="Estilo9"><strong>*</strong></span> represent the operation of concatenation between strings.</p>
  <P >We define the set of formulas over <em><strong>A</strong></em> recursively as follows:</P>
  <ul>
    <li>If <strong><em>X</em></strong> belongs to <em><strong>A</strong></em> \ {<span class="Estilo9">=, -</span>} then <em><strong>X</strong></em> is formula (variable).</li>
    <li>IF <em><strong>X</strong></em> is a formula, so is <em><strong>X</strong></em><span class="Estilo9">*-</span>.</li>
    <li>If <em><strong>X</strong></em> and <em><strong>Y</strong></em> are formulas, so is: <em><strong>X</strong></em><span class="Estilo9">*</span><em><strong>Y</strong></em><span class="Estilo9">*=</span>.</li>
  </ul>
  <P >These formulas are understood as logical formulas with connectives <span class="Estilo9">-</span> for negation, <span class="Estilo9">=</span> for equivalence and <em><strong>A</strong></em> \ {<span class="Estilo9">=, -</span>} as variables. That is <span class="Estilo9">=</span> and <span class="Estilo9">-</span> are not variables. Also, variables <em><strong>a</strong></em> and <em><strong>A</strong></em> are considered different. Similarly <em><strong>b</strong></em> is different to <em><strong>B</strong></em> and so on.</P>
  <P >Of course our formulas are given in Reverse Polish Notation (RPN). We can evaluate a formula for a given boolean input {0, 1} and the output is either 0 or 1 as usual.</P>
  <P >A formula is a tautology if it evaluates to 1 for every input. For example <span class="Estilo9">aa=</span> is a tautology while <span class="Estilo9">aa=-</span> is not. Note that <span class="Estilo9">aa=</span> represents the formula <span class="Estilo9">a=a</span> in the standard infix notation and <span class="Estilo9">aa=-</span> represents the formula <span class="Estilo9">-[a=a]</span>.</P>

</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line is a natural number <em><strong>N</strong></em> less than 100. Then, there are <em><strong>N</strong></em> lines, each one is a string over <em><strong>A</strong></em>. Every string is of size less than 200 characters.</p>
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
You must display <em><strong>N</strong></em> lines, each one with 3 possible answers: <span class="Estilo9">incorrect</span>, <span class="Estilo9">tautology</span> or <span class="Estilo9">formula</span>. Answer number i gives the output of string number i. The output is &quot;<span class="Estilo9">incorrect</span>&quot; if the input string is not a formula. The output is &quot;<span class="Estilo9">formula</span>&quot; if the input string is a formula that is not a tautology. The output is &quot;<span class="Estilo9">tautology</span>&quot; if the input string is a formula that is a tautology.</p>
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
3
aa=
aa=-
ab
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
tautology
formula
incorrect
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>







    <h2>Note:</h2>
    <p >Perhaps some students have no idea on how to evaluate a formula in RPN form. However I assume that she/he knows how to do it in the standard form, hence I need only to describe how to convert a RPN formula into a standard infix form. We define <strong>f</strong>(<em><strong>X</strong></em>) the translation of a RPN formula <em><strong>X</strong></em> by recursion as follows:</p>
    <p >We assume that <em><strong>X</strong></em>, <em><strong>Y</strong></em>, <em><strong>Z</strong></em> represent formulas.</p>
    <ol>
      <li>If <em><strong>X</strong></em> is a variable then <strong>f</strong>(<em><strong>X</strong></em>) := <em><strong>X</strong></em>.</li>
      <li>If <em><strong>X</strong></em> is of the form <em><strong>Y</strong></em><span class="Estilo9">*-</span> then <strong>f</strong>(<em><strong>X</strong></em>) := [<span class="Estilo9">*-*</span><strong>f</strong>(<strong><em>Y</em></strong>)<span class="Estilo9">*</span>].</li>
      <li>If <em><strong>X</strong></em> is of the form <em><strong>Y</strong></em><span class="Estilo9">*</span><em><strong>Z</strong></em><span class="Estilo9">*=</span> then <strong>f</strong>(<em><strong>X</strong></em>) := [<span class="Estilo9">*</span><strong>f</strong>(<em><strong>Y</strong></em>)<span class="Estilo9">*=*</span><strong>f</strong>(<em><strong>Z</strong></em>)<span class="Estilo9">*</span>].</li>
    </ol>
    <p >where [ and ] are parenthesis symbols (not needed in a RPN formula).</p>
<p>Just in case, I include the truth tables for <span class="Estilo9">=</span> and <span class="Estilo9">-</span>.</p>
<p align="justify">The truth table for <span class="Estilo9">=</span> is:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" bordercolor="#000000">
    <tr bgcolor="#D0D0D0">
      <th width="60"><p align="center"><b>A</b></p></th>
      <th width="60"><p align="center"><b>B</b></p></th>
      <th width="60"><p align="center"><b>A=B</b></p></th>
    </tr>
    <tr><td><p align="center">0</p></td><td><p align="center">0</p></td><td><p align="center">1</p></td></tr>
    <tr><td><p align="center">0</p></td><td><p align="center">1</p></td><td><p align="center">0</p></td></tr>
    <tr><td><p align="center">1</p></td><td><p align="center">0</p></td><td><p align="center">0</p></td></tr>
    <tr><td><p align="center">1</p></td><td><p align="center">1</p></td><td><p align="center">1</p></td></tr>
  </table>
<br>
  
 <p>The truth table for <span class="Estilo9">-</span> is:</p>
    <table border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" bordercolor="#000000">
    <tr bgcolor="#D0D0D0">
      <th width="60"><p align="center"><b>A</b></p></th>
      <th width="60"><p align="center"><b>-A</b></p></th>
    </tr>
    <tr><td><p align="center">0</p></td><td><p align="center">1</p></td></tr>
    <tr><td><p align="center">1</p></td><td><p align="center">0</p></td></tr>
  </table>
<br><p>Good luck!</p><br>





<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Dr. Mauricio Javier Osorio Galindo</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10848||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Make Palindrome Checker</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem I</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Make Palindrome Checker</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 1 second</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<P>
As you all know, Miguel Revilla has been very busy revising the
website for the programming contest. But alas, as things go, he lost
some files in the upgrade. And even worse: as he backups his files as
frequently as most of us, he cannot restore them. He clearly needs
some help.

<p>One of the files lost is the file with the test vectors for "Make
Palindrome", problem 10453 (<a
href="http://acm.uva.es/p/v104/10453.html">http://acm.uva.es/p/v104/10453.html</a>). Miguel
needs a program to test the contributions to this problem. In order to
do this, he first makes a new file from the file with the test inputs
and the file with the outputs of a program: every line consists of the
input to the program and its output, separated by a space. Systematic
as he is, he makes a list of properties every line in this new file
should have:

<ol>
<li>It consists of a first string of lower case characters (length <=
1000), a single space, an integer (>=0, <=1000), a single space, and a
second string of lower case letters (length <=2000), we will call this
property P1.

<li>P1 & the second string is a palindrome.

<li>P1 & all letters of the first string appear in the second string.

<li>P1 & the frequency of every letter in the second string is at
 least the frequency of this letter in the first string.

<li>P1 & the first string can be made out of the second string by
removing 0 or more letters (and leaving the order of the letters
intact).

<li>P1 & the length of the second string is equal to the
length of the first string plus the value of the integer.  

<li>P1 & the value of the integer is smaller than the length of the first string.

</ol>
 
<p>Obviously, the list is not complete, but given the time pressure
Miguel is under and the short nights he has had during the upgrade, we
can easily forgive him.<p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
Every input consists of a concatenation of an input submitted to and
an output computed by a program made to the specification of "Make
Palindrome", separated by a space. Every line contains less than 5000
ASCII characters. Input is terminated by EOF.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
The output consists of the value "T" or "F" (for True and False;
without the quotes) for every property in the list above, and a
statement "The solution is accepted" if all properties are true, and
"The solution is not accepted" otherwise (again, both without the
quotes). There is a single space between the statement and the "T"s
and "F"s; there is none between the "T"s and "F"s.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
abcd 3 abcdcba
aaaa 3 abcdcba
abc 2 abdcba
aab b baab
abababaabababa 0 abababaabababa
pqrsabcdpqrs 9 pqrsabcdpqrqpdcbasrqp
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
TTTTTTT The solution is accepted
TTTFFTT The solution is not accepted
TFTTTFT The solution is not accepted
FFFFFFF The solution is not accepted
TTTTTTT The solution is accepted
TTTTTTT The solution is accepted
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Meine Van der Meulen</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10849||||||false||||||
<html>

<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type"
content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<meta name="description" content="Move the bishop">
<meta name="resource-type" content="document">
<meta name="distribution" content="global">
<title>Move the bishop</title>
</head>

<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" lang="EN">
<div align="center"><center>

<table border="0" bgcolor="#0060F0">
    
    <tr>
        <td><font color="#C0FFFF" size="5"><b>&nbsp;Move the
        bishop</b></font><b>&nbsp;</b></td>
    </tr>
    
</table>
</center></div>

<p class="MsoBodyText">&nbsp;</p>

<p class="MsoBodyText">Consider you have a chess board with <i>NxN</i>
squares, 1 &le; <i>N</i> &le; 100.000.000. There is only a
piece on the board: the bishop. The position of the bishop is
given by a pair of numbers 1 &le; <i>r,c </i>&le; <i>N</i>; <i>r</i>
is the row and <i>c</i> is the column. Position <i>(1,1)</i>
refers to the bottom-left square of the board, while position <i>(N,N)</i>
refers to the up-right square.</p>

<p class="MsoBodyText">The problem consists of calculating the
minimum number of movements that the bishop have to do to reach a
given square of the board, given the position of the bishop and the
position of that square. If this movement is not possible, the
output must be: &#147;no move&#148;. Don´t worry if you don´t
know how to play chess. The only information you need is: the
bishop moves diagonally any number of squares, forwards or
backwards as long as its path is not blocked by other pieces.</p>

<h2><font color="#0070E8">The Input</font></h2>

<p class="MsoBodyText"><a name="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The
input begins with a single integer, <em>C</em>, indicating the
number of test cases following, each of them as described below.
This line is followed by a blank line, and there is also a blank
line between two consecutive test cases.</a></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><a
name="SECTION0001004000000000000000">For each test case, the
first line contains an integer 1 &le; <i>T &le;</i> 100,
indicating the number of tests for that case. The second line
contains an integer 1 &le; <i>N &le; </i>100.000.000, for a
chess board with <i>NxN</i> squares. Then the test lines follow,
and for each one, there are four numbers separated by a single
space. The first two numbers are the row and column where the
bishop is, and the last two numbers are the row and column of the
position of the square that the bishop have to reach.</a></p>

<h2><font color="#0070E8">The Output</font></h2>

<p class="MsoBodyText"><a name="SECTION0001005000000000000000">For
each test line you should produce an output line. This line just
contains a number that indicates the minimum number of movements
for the bishop according to positions described in the input
line, or the message &#147;no move&#148; if the position is not
reachable. </a></p>

<h2><a name="SECTION0001005000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Input</font></a></h2>

<pre>2

3
8
3 6 6 3
4 2 2 3
7 2 1 4

2
6
1 2 6 5
2 3 5 1
</pre>

<h2><a name="SECTION0001006000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Output</font></a></h2>

<pre>1
no move
2
2
no move</pre>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10850||||||false||||||
<html>

<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type"
content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<meta name="description" content="The Gossipy Gossipers Gossip Gossips">
<meta name="resource-type" content="document">
<meta name="distribution" content="global">
<title>The Gossipy Gossipers Gossip Gossips</title>
</head>

<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" lang="EN">
<div align="center"><center>

<table border="0" bgcolor="#0060F0">
<TBODY>    <tr>
        <td><font color="#C0FFFF" size="5"><b>&nbsp;The Gossipy Gossipers Gossip Gossips</b></font><b>&nbsp;</b></td>
    </tr>
</TBODY></table>
</center></div>

<p>

<em>&quot;Gossipy gossiper, what did you get of so much gossiping?<br>
You set your soul into hell. Behold your great achievement!&quot;</em><br>
M.A. Hevia. Mermuradora.
<p>

<h2><a name="SECTION0001001000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">The Problem</font></a></h2>

<p>Gossiping mechanism is quite simple, but effective. Everything starts with a master gossiper (most probably a <em>she</em>), who hears, witnesses, or makes up some extraordinary news. Whenever she meets another person, she tells him the news. As soon as these people meet others, they tell them the news. Soon, everybody is informed of the news, and the process finishes.</p>

<p>Gossipers meet each other daily at the same hours. We have information on when every pair of gossipers meet. For simplicity, days are divided into 100 instants. The first day goes from 0 to 99, the second from 100 to 199, and so on.</p>

<p>Suppose the gossiping process starts at time 0. When will it finish? That is, when will all the people be informed of the news?</p>


<h2><a name="SECTION0001003000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">The
Input</font></a></h2>

<p>The first line of the input contains an integer <em>N</em>, indicating the number of test cases.</p>

<p>For each test case, the first line contains two integers <em>M</em> and <em>K</em>. <em>M</em> indicates the number of people in this case (numbered from 1 to <em>M</em>). The master gossiper is always number 1. <em>K</em> indicates the number of pairs of people who meet.</p>

<p>Next, we have 2<em>K</em> lines (two lines for each pair of people who meet). The first line of each pair contains three integers, <em>G1</em>, <em>G2</em> and <em>V</em>. This line means that gossipers <em>G1</em> and <em>G2</em> meet <em>V</em> times a day. The second line contains <em>V</em> numbers from 1 to 99, that indicate the instants when <em>G1</em> and <em>G2</em> meet daily.</p>

<p>For example, the pair:

<pre>3 7 2
28 88
</pre>

means: person 3 and person 7 meet twice a day, at instants 28 and 88 everyday (that is, at 28, 88, 128, 188, 228, 288, ...).

<p>You can assume that <em>M</em> &le; 20, <em>K</em> &le; <em>M*M</em>, and <em>V</em> &le; 12 </em>.</p>

<h2><a name="SECTION0001004000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">The
Output</font></a></h2>

<p>For each test case, the output should consist of a single integer <em>F</em> in one line, indicating the instant when the process finishes. If the process does not finish (for example, there is some isolated person who will never be informed), the result should be -1.</p> 

<h2><a name="SECTION0001005000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Input</font></a></h2>

<pre>4
4 3
1 2 1
60
2 3 1
40
4 3 1
30
3 2
1 2 1
42
2 3 1
42
5 5
1 3 2
60 70
1 4 3
20 22 24
4 5 1
10
3 5 2
12 80
3 2 2
55 78
8 0
</pre>

<h2><a name="SECTION0001006000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Output</font></a></h2>

<pre>230
42
80
-1
</pre>
</body>
</html>

*Warning: "gossips" have nothing to do with "ghost ships".

______________________________________________________
10851||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>2D Hieroglyphs decoder</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="2D Hieroglyphs decoder">

</HEAD>

<BODY >
<div align="center"><center>
<table border="0" bgcolor="#0060F0">
<TBODY>    <tr>
        <td><font color="#C0FFFF" size="5"><b>&nbsp;2D Hieroglyphs decoder</b></font><b>&nbsp;</b></td>
    </tr>
</TBODY></table>
</center></div>


<h2><a name="SECTION0001001000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">The Problem</font></a></h2>

<P>
Steganography is one of the most famous techniques for hiding
information in different places, including images. Recently, for
example, Xerox announced they were releasing a 2D-hieroglyphs that
were able to codify a message within them. Your task is to decipher a
2D-hieroglyph.

<P>
A 2D hieroglyph is a matrix <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="22" HEIGHT="16" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$ H$"></SPAN> of 10 rows and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="57" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$ M+2$"></SPAN> columns that encode
a message of length <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="25" HEIGHT="16" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$ M$"></SPAN> characters (<!-- MATH
 $c_0, c_1, \ldots, c_{M-1}$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="127" HEIGHT="33" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$ c_0, c_1, \ldots, c_{M-1}$"></SPAN>). The
matrix <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="22" HEIGHT="16" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$ H$"></SPAN> has the following lattice:

<P>
<!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
H_{i,j} =
\left\lbrace \begin{array}{ll}
'/' & \forall i=0, j \in \left(0, 1, \ldots , M+1\right) \\
'/' & \forall i=9, j \in \left(0, 1, \ldots , M+1\right) \\
'/' & \forall j=0, i \in \left(0, 1, \ldots , 9\right) \\
'/' & \forall j=M+1, i \in \left(0, 1, \ldots , 9\right) \\
b(i-1,c_{j-1}) & \forall i \in \left(1, 2, \ldots , 8\right), j \in \left(1, 2, \ldots , M\right)
\end{array} \right.
\end{displaymath}
 -->
<P></P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<IMG
 WIDTH="494" HEIGHT="134" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$\displaystyle H_{i,j} =
\left\lbrace \begin{array}{ll}
'/' &amp; \forall i=0, j \in...
... 2, \ldots , 8\right), j \in \left(1, 2, \ldots , M\right)
\end{array} \right.
$">
</DIV><P></P>

<P>
where

<P>
<!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
b(i,c) =
\left\lbrace \begin{array}{ll}
'/' & \mathrm{if}\ \left( \frac{c}{2^i} \right) \mathrm{mod}\ 2 = 0 \\
'\backslash' & \mathrm{if}\  \left( \frac{c}{2^i} \right) \mathrm{mod}\ 2 = 1\\
\end{array} \right.
\end{displaymath}
 -->
<P></P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<IMG
 WIDTH="285" HEIGHT="65" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$\displaystyle b(i,c) =
\left\lbrace \begin{array}{ll}
'/' &amp; \mathrm{if}\ \left(...
...m{if}\ \left( \frac{c}{2^i} \right) \mathrm{mod}\ 2 = 1\\
\end{array} \right.
$">
</DIV><P></P>

<P>
and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="16" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$ c$"></SPAN> is the ASCII value of the character passed to the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="17" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$ b$"></SPAN>
function.

<P>
Your task is to find the message given the matrix <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="22" HEIGHT="16" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$ H$"></SPAN>.

<h2><a name="SECTION0001003000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">The
Input</font></a></h2>

<P>
The input is composed of a first line with a number <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="22" HEIGHT="16" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$ N$"></SPAN> indicating the
number of messages to decode, followed by <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="22" HEIGHT="16" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$ N$"></SPAN> matrices separated by a
"newline" character. The length of any message will not be more
than&nbsp;80 characters.

<h2><a name="SECTION0001003000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">The
Output</font></a></h2>

<P>
The output must have <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="22" HEIGHT="16" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10851a.png" 
 ALT="$ N$"></SPAN> messages, one per each matrix given in the
input.

<h2><a name="SECTION0001005000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Input</font></a></h2>

<PRE>2
///////////////////////////////////////
//\///\/\\/\//\\/\//\/\\/\/\/\\/\/\//\/
///////\////\/\/\//////\//\////\/\/////
/\//\\\\///\\//\\/\\//\//\\//\///\/\\//
/\//\\//\///\////\\\//////\//\////\\\//
//////\\//////\/\//////\/\/////\/\/////
///\//////\//\///////\//\///\//////////
/\\/\\\\\\/\\/\\\\\\\/\\/\\\/\\\\\\\\\/
///////////////////////////////////////
///////////////////////////////////////

///////////
/\/\/\/\/\/
//\\//\\///
////\\\\///
////////\\/
///////////
/\\\\\\\\\/
/\\\\\\\\\/
///////////
///////////
</PRE>

<h2><a name="SECTION0001005000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Output</font></a></h2>

<PRE>LA LLUVIA EN SEVILLA ES UNA MARAVILLA
abcdefghi
</PRE>


</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10852||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<TITLE>Less Prime</TITLE>
<CENTER>
<TABLE bgColor=#0060f0>
  <TBODY align=center>
  <TR>
    <TD><b><font color="#c0ffff" size="5">Less Prime</font> </b></TR></TBODY></TABLE></CENTER>

<h2><span lang="EN" style="COLOR: #0070e8; mso-ansi-language: EN">The problem<O:P>
</span></h2>
<p>Let n be an integer, 100 &le; n &le; 10000, find the prime number x,  x &le; n, so that  n-p*x
 is maximum, where  p is an integer such that p*x &le; n &lt; (p+1)*x.</o:p>
</p>
<H2><FONT color=#0070e8><A name=SECTION0001003000000000000000>The 
Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P><span lang="EN" style="mso-ansi-language: EN">The first line of the input
contains an integer, <em>M</em>, indicating the number of test cases. For each
test case, there is a line with a number <i>N</i>, 100 &le; <i>N</i> &le; 10000.

<H2><FONT color=#0070e8>The Output</FONT></H2>
<P>For each test case, the output
should consist of one line showing the prime number that verifies
the condition above.
<H2><FONT color=#0070e8>Sample Input</FONT></H2>

<pre>5
4399
614
8201
101
7048
</pre>

<H2><FONT color=#0070e8>Sample Output</FONT></H2>

<pre>2203
311
4111
53
3527
</pre>



</BODY></HTML>

______________________________________________________
10853||||||false||||||
<html>

<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<meta name="description" content="Pablito nailed a nail">
<meta name="resource-type" content="document">
<meta name="autor" content="GinesGM, dedicated to PablitoGC">
<title>Pablito nailed a nail</title>
</head>

<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" lang="EN">
<div align="center"><center>

<table border="0" bgcolor="#0060F0">
<TBODY>    <tr>
        <td><font color="#C0FFFF" size="5"><b>&nbsp;Pablito nailed a nail</b></font><b>&nbsp;</b></td>
    </tr>
</TBODY></table>
</center></div>

<p>


<h2><a name="SECTION0001001000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">The Problem</font></a></h2>

<p>Pablito will give you a birdie if you can beat him in his favorite game: nailing the nail. This game is a pretty mixture of intelligence and brute force. There is a long nail, a bit inserted into a piece of wood. You and Pablito hit the nail in turns with a hammer. The winner is the first player who completely inserts the nail.</p>

<p align="center"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/p10853.gif" ></p>

<p>All measures are given in integer numbers. Depending on his/her strength and ability, each player can push the nail between a minimum, <em>Xmin</em>, and a maximum quantity, <em>Xmax</em>. However, if the current length of the nail is less than <em>Xmin</em>, the player can insert the nail completely and win.</p>

<p>Let's name the players <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. The <strong>optimal strategy</strong> for player <em>A</em> (similarly for <em>B</em>) is defined as follows:

<ul>
<strong>(a)</strong> a hit where <em>A</em> inserts the nail completely is an optimal hit for <em>A</em>,
<br>
<strong>(b)</strong> if (a) is not possible, a hit of <em>A</em> that leads to an optimal hit of <em>A</em> after all possible hits of <em>B</em>, is also an optimal hit of <em>A</em>,
<br>
<strong>(c)</strong> if neither (a) nor (b) are possible, <em>A</em> has no optimal hit, and will insert the nail any valid quantity.
</ul>
</p>

<p>Suppose player <em>A</em> always hits first, and both players use the optimal strategy for them. Who will win the game?</p>


<h2><a name="SECTION0001003000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">The
Input</font></a></h2>

<p>The first line of the input contains an integer <em>N</em>, indicating the number of test cases.</p>

<p>Each test case is described in a single line, containing 5 integers: <em>L Amin Amax Bmin Bmax</em>, indicating the initial length of the nail, the minimum hit of <em>A</em>, the maximum hit of <em>A</em>, the minimum hit of <em>B</em>, and the maximum hit of <em>B</em>, respectively. Assume all numbers are between 1 and 2^30, <em>Amin</em> &le; <em>Amax</em>, and <em>Bmin</em> &le; <em>Bmax</em>.</p>

<h2><a name="SECTION0001004000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">The
Output</font></a></h2>

<p>For each test case, the output should consist of a line with a single letter, <em>A</em> or <em>B</em>, indicating the winner in that case.</p> 

<h2><a name="SECTION0001005000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">Sample Input</font></a></h2>

<pre>4
4 5 7 1 20
5 1 3 1 3
5 2 2 1 3
1000 1 3 1 3
</pre>

<h2><a name="SECTION0001006000000000000000"><font color="#0070E8">Sample Output</font></a></h2>

<pre>A
A
B
B
</pre>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10854||||||false||||||
<html>

<head>
<title>Number of Paths</title>
</head>

<body>
<div align="center"><center>

<table border="0" bgcolor="#0060F0">
<TBODY align="center">    <tr>
        <td><font color="#C0FFFF" size="5"><b>Number of Paths</b></font><b>
        </b></td>
    </tr>
</TBODY></table>
</center></div>

<h2><FONT color=#0070e8>Background</FONT></h2>

<p>Although testing is a technique which does not allow us to
prove the correctness of a program, it is used to assess its
reliability, thus increasing our confidence in its correctness. In
the literature, there are many testing methods to select test
cases which are applied as an input to the program.</p>

<h2><FONT color=#0070e8>The Problem</FONT></h2>

<p>A programmer has the intention of testing a program. With this
aim in mind, he needs to know how many test cases he should
obtain such that each distinct path of execution is covered with
a test case. Your task is to write a program which computes the
number of different paths of execution from the initial sentence
to the final sentence, in a given program <i>P</i>.</p>

<h2><FONT color=#0070e8>The Input</FONT></h2>

<p>The first line of the input contains the number of programs.
Subsequently, each program is listed. Each program consists of a
set of sentences with a keyword per line. The program finishes
with the keyword <em>ENDPROGRAM</em></p>

<p>There are only two types of sentences: conditional and non-conditional.
A non-conditional sentence is represented by means of the
keyword <i>S</i>. A conditional sentence is represented by the
keywords <i>IF</i>, <i>ELSE</i> and <i>END_IF</i>. The condition
of the <i>IF</i> sentence is omitted (i.e., only the <em>IF</em>
keyword appears) and it is supposed that all <em>IF</em>
sentences have a corresponding <em>ELSE</em>. So, for example,
the shortest program with a conditional sentence would be:</p>

<pre>IF
ELSE
END_IF
ENDPROGRAM</pre>

<p>which has 2 paths of execution.</p>

<h2><FONT color=#0070e8>The Output</FONT></h2>

<p>For every program you are to print a line containing the
number <i>N</i> of different paths of execution. It is supposed
that <i>N</i> is never greater than 2^32.</p>

<h2><FONT color=#0070e8>Sample Input</FONT></h2>

<pre>4
IF
ELSE
END_IF
ENDPROGRAM
IF
S
ELSE
END_IF
IF
ELSE
S
END_IF
ENDPROGRAM
S
S
S
ENDPROGRAM
S
IF
S
S
ELSE
IF
IF
S
ELSE
S
END_IF
S
ELSE
S
END_IF
END_IF
S
ENDPROGRAM
</pre>

<h2><FONT color=#0070e8>Sample Output</FONT></h2>

<pre>2
4
1
4
</pre>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10855||||||false||||||
<HTML>

<head>
<META content="text/html; charset=windows-1252" http-equiv=Content-Type>
<META content="Hidden squares" name=description>
<META content=htmlatex name=keywords>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
</head>

<BODY bgColor=#ffffff lang=EN>

<CENTER>
<TABLE bgColor=#0060f0>
  <TBODY align=center>
  <TR>
    <TD><b><font color="#c0ffff" size="5">Rotated squares</font>&nbsp;</b></TR></TBODY></TABLE></CENTER>

<h2><FONT color=#0070e8><A name=SECTION0001003000000000000000>The Problem</A></FONT></h2>

<p>Given a square of N rows and columns of uppercase letters, and another smaller square
of n rows and columns of uppercase letters, we want to
count the number of appearances in the big square of the small square in all the
rotated forms.</p>
<H2><FONT color=#0070e8><A name=SECTION0001003000000000000000>The 
Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>The input will consist of a series of problems, with each problem in a series of
lines. In the first line, the dimension of the two squares, N and n (with 0&lt;n&lt;=N), is indicated
by two integer numbers separated by a space. The N lines of the first square
appear in the following N lines of the input, and then the n lines of the second square appear in the following n lines.
The characters in a line are one after another, without spaces. The end of the
sequence of problems is indicated with a case where N=0 and n=0.
<H2><FONT color=#0070e8><A name=SECTION0001004000000000000000>The 
Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>The solutions of the different problems appear in successive lines. For each
problem the output consists of a line with four integers, which are the number
of times each rotation of the small square appears in the big square.
The first number corresponds to the number of appearances of the small square
without rotations, the second to the appearances of the square rotated 90
degrees (clockwise), the third to the square rotated 180
degrees, and the fourth to the
square rotated 270 degrees.&nbsp;
<H2><FONT color=#0070e8><A name=SECTION0001005000000000000000>Sample 
Input</A></FONT></H2>

<pre>4 2
ABBA
ABBB
BAAA
BABB
AB
BB
6 2
ABCDCD
BCDCBD
BACDDC
DCBDCA
DCBABD
ABCDBA
BC
CD
0 0
</pre>
<H2><FONT color=#0070e8><A name=SECTION0001006000000000000000>Sample 
Output</A></FONT></H2>

<pre>0 1 0 0
1 0 1 0</pre>
</BODY></HTML>

______________________________________________________

	font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:Tahoma;
	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
	font-weight:bold;}
p.jbfont, li.jbfont, div.jbfont
	{mso-style-name:jbfont;
	margin-right:0in;
	mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
	mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
	margin-left:0in;
	text-align:justify;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:13.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";}
p.bigfont, li.bigfont, div.bigfont
	{mso-style-name:bigfont;
	margin-right:0in;
	mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
	mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
	margin-left:0in;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:18.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
	font-weight:bold;}
p.cname, li.cname, div.cname
	{mso-style-name:cname;
	margin-right:0in;
	mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
	mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
	margin-left:0in;
	text-align:center;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:16.0pt;
	font-family:Arial;
	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
	font-weight:bold;}
p.pno, li.pno, div.pno
	{mso-style-name:pno;
	margin-right:0in;
	mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
	mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
	margin-left:0in;
	text-align:center;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:14.0pt;
	font-family:Arial;
	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
	font-weight:bold;}
p.pname, li.pname, div.pname
	{mso-style-name:pname;
	margin-right:0in;
	mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
	mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
	margin-left:0in;
	text-align:center;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:24.0pt;
	font-family:Arial;
	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
	font-weight:bold;}
@page Section1
	{size:8.5in 11.0in;
	margin:1.0in 1.25in 1.0in 1.25in;
	mso-header-margin:.5in;
	mso-footer-margin:.5in;
	mso-paper-source:0;}
div.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
-->
</style>
</head>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
 mso-cellspacing:0in;border:outset 1.5pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
 <tr>
  <td style='border:inset .75pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
  <table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
   mso-cellspacing:0in;border:none;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
   <tr>
    <td width="20%" rowspan=3 style='width:20.0%;border:none;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=cbfont>Input: Standard In<br>
    Output: Standard Out</p>
    </td>
<!--contest name-->
    <td width="60%" style='width:60.0%;border:none;background:silver;
    padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
    style='font-size:16.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Next Generation Contest 1&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
    </td>
    <td width="20%" rowspan=3 style='width:20.0%;border:none;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=cbfont><b>Time Limit: 2 seconds</b></p>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
<!--problem no-->
    <td width="60%" style='width:60.0%;border:none;background:silver;
    padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
    style='font-size:14.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Problem A&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
<!--problem name-->
    <td width="60%" style='width:60.0%;border:none;background:silver;
    padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
    style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Recover Factorial<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </table>
  <p class=MsoNormal><o:p></o:p></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=jbfont><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>Factorial numbers
are expressible as the multiplication of zero or more prime numbers. For
example 4! (Factorial of 4) can be expressed as follows:-<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=cbfont><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>4! = 2 x 2 x 2 x 3
(total number of prime factor is 4)<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=jbfont><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>Given <b>N</b>, the
number of prime factors in <b>X! </b>(Factorial of X)<b>, </b>you have to find
the minimum possible value of <b>X</b>. <span style="mso-spacerun:
yes"> </span><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=bigfont><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>Input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=jbfont><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>There may be at most
<b>1000</b> test cases. Each test case consists of one non-negative integer <b>N&lt;=10000001</b>
in each line. A negative integer marks the end of input, which should not be <span
style="mso-spacerun: yes"> </span>processed by your program.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=bigfont><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>Output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=jbfont><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>For every test case
except last one print either <b>Case #: X!</b> if solution exist or <b>Case
#: Not possible.</b> if no solution exist in each line (without the quotes).
Here # represents serial of test case starting from 1. Look at sample output
for details.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=bigfont><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
 mso-cellspacing:0in;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
 <tr>
  <td style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>4<br>
  240<br>
  241<br>
  -1<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=bigfont><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
 mso-cellspacing:0in;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
 <tr>
  <td style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Case 1: 4!<br>
  Case 2: 101!<br>
  Case 3: Not possible.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>


<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span lang=EN
style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</span></div>


<p class=psetter><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>Problem Setter:
A.N.M Anisur Rahman <o:p></o:p></span></p>

</div>

</body>

</html>

<title>Problem B: Easter Eggs</title>
<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
 mso-cellspacing:0in;border:outset 1.5pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
 <tr>
  <td style='border:inset .75pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
  <table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
   mso-cellspacing:0in;border:none;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
   <tr>
    <td width="20%" rowspan=3 style='width:20.0%;border:none;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=cbfont>Input: Standard In<br>
    Output: Standard Out</p>
    </td>
<!--contest name-->
    <td width="60%" style='width:60.0%;border:none;background:silver;
    padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
    style='font-size:16.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Next Generation Contest 1&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
    </td>
    <td width="20%" rowspan=3 style='width:20.0%;border:none;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=cbfont><b>Time Limit: 8 seconds</b></p>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
<!--problem no-->
    <td width="60%" style='width:60.0%;border:none;background:silver;
    padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
    style='font-size:14.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Problem B&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
<!--problem name-->
    <td width="60%" style='width:60.0%;border:none;background:silver;
    padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
    style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Easter Eggs<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </table>
  <p class=MsoNormal><o:p></o:p></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=jbfont>Easter is here again, and as usual, the Easter Bunny has more things
on his mind than a gnu balancing a dish of exotic fruits on its head. As you
know, one of the Easter Bunnys tasks is to bring Easter eggs containing a
nourishing assortment of carrots and sweets to all the good folks who still
believe in him. The eggs have to be delivered before dawn, and it is already
midnight, so the Easter Bunny is starting to feel the kind of stressed-out
panic that only a little rabbit can feel. It has become blatantly clear to the
Easter Bunny that he will not be able to deliver all the eggs, and hence, he
has asked you to help him minimize the damage by writing a program that helps
him deliver as many eggs as possible.</p>

<p class=jbfont>The Easter Bunny has a (sufficiently large) store of eggs in
his secret underground hideout (where he is currently located), and he wants to
carry one egg to everyone in the world who believes in him. The world, as you
probably know, is flat, and hence we model a location in the world as a point
in a two-dimensional plane. The eggs need to be delivered strictly before
sunrise, as the Easter Bunny mustnt be seen carrying eggs. What complicates
matters is that the sun rises at different times depending on where you are in
the flat world! At coordinate (<b>x, y</b>), the sun rises 720 + <b>x</b>/2000
minutes after midnight. Note that the Easter Bunny only needs to deliver an egg
before the sun rises at the place where the egg should be delivered, and that
it is ok if the sun rises during his journey home. </p>

<p class=jbfont>When traveling between two points in the world, the Easter
Bunny always travels along the straight line between them. Being a furry little
bunny rabbit (rather than, say, a kangaroo), the Easter Bunnys egg carrying
capacity is very limited, and the more eggs he carries, the harder a time he
has keeping his pace up. When not carrying any eggs, the Easter Bunny can move
(jump) at a speed of <b>v</b> meters per second, but each extra egg he carries
makes it twice as hard to keep a decent speed. Hence, when carrying <b>i</b>
eggs, he is able to cover <b>v</b>·2<b><sup>-i</sup></b> meters per second.<br>
<br>
Since we are already running on a tight schedule, we dont bother modeling the
finer nuances of the Easter Bunnys egg delivering. Hence, we assume that
everything but moving from one point to another takes zero time (when, in
practice, the Easter Bunny usually needs a moment or two to e.g. find a good
hiding place for an egg).</p>

<p class=bigfont><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=bigfont>Input</p>

<p class=jbfont>The input consists of less than 32 test cases. The first line
of a test case contains two integers 1 &#8804; <b>n</b> &#8804; 17, 1 &#8804; <b>v</b>
&#8804; 100, where n is the number of eggs to be delivered and v is Easter
Bunnys velocity when he carries zero eggs. Then follow <b>n</b> lines, each
containing two integers <b>x</b> and <b>y</b>, indicating where to deliver the <b>n</b>
eggs. The Easter Bunnys secret hideout is located at <b>x</b> = 0, <b>y</b> =
0. The length unit of the coordinates is meters, and you may assume that all
coordinates have absolute value bounded by 10<sup>6</sup>. There is a blank line
between any two consecutive test cases. Input is terminated by a case where <b>n</b>
= 0 and <b>v</b> = 0, which should not be processed.</p>

<p class=bigfont>Output</p>

<p class=jbfont>For each test case, output a line containing the maximal number
of eggs that the Easter Bunny will be able to place before dawn.</p>

<p class=bigfont>Sample Input</p>

<table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
 mso-cellspacing:0in;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
 <tr>
  <td style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>4 5<br>
  -42000 0<br>
  0 42000<br>
  42000 0<br>
  0 -42000<br>
  <br>
  8 1<br>
  50 8<br>
  -4711 -13<br>
  -4 9<br>
  100 20<br>
  4010 2<br>
  10 5810<br>
  -4 8<br>
  235 -2200<br>
  <br>
  0 0 &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=bigfont>Sample Output</p>

<table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
 mso-cellspacing:0in;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
 <tr>
  <td style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2<br>
  7 &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>


<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>


<p class=psetter>Problem Setter: Per Austrin</p>

</div>

</body>

</html>

<title>Problem C: Unique Factorization</title>
<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>

<style>
<!--
 /* Font Definitions */
@font-face
	{font-family:Tahoma;
	panose-1:2 11 6 4 3 5 4 4 2 4;
	mso-font-charset:0;
	mso-generic-font-family:swiss;
	mso-font-pitch:variable;
	mso-font-signature:1627421319 -2147483648 8 0 66047 0;}
 /* Style Definitions */
p.MsoNormal, li.MsoNormal, div.MsoNormal

	{mso-style-name:pname;

	mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
	margin-left:0in;
	text-align:center;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;

	{size:8.5in 11.0in;

	mso-header-margin:.5in;
	mso-footer-margin:.5in;
	mso-paper-source:0;}
div.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
-->
</style>
</head>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
 mso-cellspacing:0in;border:outset 1.5pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
 <tr>
  <td style='border:inset .75pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
  <table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
   mso-cellspacing:0in;border:none;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
   <tr>
    <td width="20%" rowspan=3 style='width:20.0%;border:none;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=cbfont>Input: Standard In<br>
    Output: Standard Out</p>
    </td>
<!--contest name-->
    <td width="60%" style='width:60.0%;border:none;background:silver;
    padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
    style='font-size:16.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Next Generation Contest 1&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
    </td>
    <td width="20%" rowspan=3 style='width:20.0%;border:none;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=cbfont><b>Time Limit: 2 seconds</b></p>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
<!--problem no-->
    <td width="60%" style='width:60.0%;border:none;background:silver;
    padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
    style='font-size:14.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Problem &nbsp;C<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
<!--problem name-->
    <td width="60%" style='width:60.0%;border:none;background:silver;
    padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
    <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
    style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Unique Factorization<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </table>
  <p class=MsoNormal><o:p></o:p></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=jbfont>Some of you may have heard the joke about a boy who stopped going
to school because he thought that his teacher was crazy. When his parents asked
as to why he felt that way, the boy replied, two days back, my math teacher
said, 12 = 4 X 3, and yesterday she said 12 = 6 X 2. How can I trust a teacher
like this who contradicts her own saying?. His parents explained the situation
to him, so the boy was convinced and continued with his studies. Few years
later, the boy wonders, how many ways are there to factorize a number. He sits
with pen and paper and discovers that the task is getting quite tedious for large
numbers. So he asks you for help. He wants you to write a program to solve his
problem.</p>

<p class=bigfont>Input</p>

<p class=jbfont>The input file will contain at most <b>20</b> cases. Each line
of input contains a positive integer, <b>N&lt;=2000000</b>. The last case is
followed by a value of <b>0</b> for <b>N</b>, which should not be processed. </p>

<p class=bigfont>Output</p>

<p class=jbfont>For every case, there will be one or more lines of output. The
first line of each set of output should contain the number <b>F</b>, where <b>F</b>
is the number of ways to uniquely factorize <b>N</b>. If <b>F&gt; 0</b>, then
the next <b>F</b> lines should contain the Factorizations of <b>N</b>. The
numbers in the factorizations should be sorted in non-decreasing order and
individual factorizations should be sorted in dictionary order. When printing
numbers in a line, there should be a space between each number. See sample
output of <b>N=20</b> for clarification. Permutations of factorization are
considered same. That is,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 12= 4 X 3 is same as 12
= 3 X 4.</p>

<p class=jbfont><b>Note: To limit the answers to finite values, the
factorizations should not contain any 1, and there should be at least two
numbers in the factorizations. So for this problem, 20 = 1 X 20, is not a
factorization of 20.</b></p>

<p class=bigfont>Sample Input</p>

<table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
 mso-cellspacing:0in;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
 <tr>
  <td style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1<br>
  20<br>
  0<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=bigfont>Sample Output</p>

<table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width="100%" style='width:100.0%;
 mso-cellspacing:0in;mso-padding-alt:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
 <tr>
  <td style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>0<br>
  3<br>
  2 2 5<br>
  2 10<br>
  4 5<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>


<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>


<p class=psetter>Problem Setter: Shamim Hafiz<br>
Special Thanks to Sohel Hafiz</p>

</div>

</body>

</html>
