10895||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2002-2-1 (1.71)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>A: Matrix Transpose</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="A: Matrix Transpose">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
A: Matrix Transpose</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
A <EM>matrix</EM> is a rectangular array of elements, most commonly numbers. A matrix with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="20" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$m$"></SPAN> rows and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$n$"></SPAN> columns is said to be an <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="20" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$m$"></SPAN>-by-<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$n$"></SPAN> matrix. For example,
<BR><P></P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
A=\pmatrix{1 & 3 & 2 \cr 0 & 4 & -1 \cr 0 & 0 & 0 \cr 5 & -2 & 11}
\end{displaymath}
 -->

<IMG
 WIDTH="153" HEIGHT="89" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="\begin{displaymath}
A=\pmatrix{1 &amp; 3 &amp; 2 \cr 0 &amp; 4 &amp; -1 \cr 0 &amp; 0 &amp; 0 \cr 5 &amp; -2 &amp; 11}
\end{displaymath}">
</DIV>
<BR CLEAR="ALL">
<P></P>
is a 4-by-3 matrix of integers. 

<P>
The individual elements of a matrix are usually given lowercase symbols and are distinguished by subscripts. The <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="10" HEIGHT="16" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$i$"></SPAN>th row and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="32" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$j$"></SPAN>th column of matrix <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="17" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$A$"></SPAN> is usually referred to as <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="25" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$a_{ij}$"></SPAN>. For example, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="73" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$a_{23}=-1$"></SPAN>. Matrix subscripts are 1-based.

<P>
The <EM>transpose</EM> of a matrix <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="23" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$M$"></SPAN>, denoted <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="34" HEIGHT="18" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$M^T$"></SPAN>, is formed by interchanging the rows and columns of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="23" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$M$"></SPAN>. That is, the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="19" HEIGHT="32" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$ij$"></SPAN>th element of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="34" HEIGHT="18" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$M^T$"></SPAN> is the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="19" HEIGHT="32" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$ji$"></SPAN>th element of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="23" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$M$"></SPAN>. For example, the transpose of matrix <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="17" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$A$"></SPAN> above is:
<BR><P></P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
A^T=\pmatrix{1 & 0 & 0 & 5 \cr 3 & 4 & 0 & -2 \cr 2 & -1 & 0 & 11}
\end{displaymath}
 -->

<IMG
 WIDTH="190" HEIGHT="67" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="\begin{displaymath}
A^T=\pmatrix{1 &amp; 0 &amp; 0 &amp; 5 \cr 3 &amp; 4 &amp; 0 &amp; -2 \cr 2 &amp; -1 &amp; 0 &amp; 11}
\end{displaymath}">
</DIV>
<BR CLEAR="ALL">
<P></P>

<P>
A matrix is said to be <EM>sparse</EM> if there are relatively few non-zero elements. As a <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="20" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$m$"></SPAN>-by-<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$n$"></SPAN> matrix has <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="30" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$mn$"></SPAN> number of elements, storing all elements of a large sparse matrix may be inefficient as there would be many zeroes. There are a number of ways to represent sparse matrices, but essentially they are all the same: store only the non-zero elements of the matrix along with their row and column. 

<P>
You are to write a program to output the transpose of a sparse matrix of integers.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
You are given several sparse matrix in a row, each of them described as follows. The first line of the input corresponds to the dimension of the matrix, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="20" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$m$"></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$n$"></SPAN> (which are the number of rows and columns, respectively, of the matrix). You are then given <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="20" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$m$"></SPAN> sets of numbers, which represent the rows of the matrix. Each set consists of two lines which represents a row of the matrix. The first line of a set starts with the number <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$r$"></SPAN>, which is the number of non-zero elements in that row, followed by <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$r$"></SPAN> numbers which correspond to the column indices of the non-zero elements in that row, in ascending order; the second line has <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$r$"></SPAN> integers which are the matrix elements of that row. For example, matrix <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="17" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10895img1.png" 
 ALT="$A$"></SPAN> above would have the following representation: 

<P>
<PRE>
4 3
3 1 2 3
1 3 2
2 2 3
4 -1
0

3 1 2 3
5 -2 11
</PRE> 

Note that for a row with all zero elements, the corresponding set would just be one number, `<TT>0</TT>', in the first line, followed by a blank line. 

<P>
You may assume:

<P>

<UL>
<LI>the dimension of the sparse matrix would not exceed 10000-by-10000,

<P>
</LI>
<LI>the number of non-zero element would be no more than 1000,

<P>
</LI>
<LI>each element of the matrix would be in the range of -10000 to 10000, and

<P>
</LI>
<LI>each line has no more than 79 characters.
</LI>
</UL>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each input case, the transpose of the given matrix in the same representation.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
4 3
3 1 2 3
1 3 2
2 2 3
4 -1
0

3 1 2 3
5 -2 11
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
3 4
2 1 4
1 5
3 1 2 4
3 4 -2
3 1 2 4
2 -1 11
</PRE> 

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10896||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2002-2-1 (1.71)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>B: Known Plaintext Attack</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="B: Known Plaintext Attack">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
B: Known Plaintext Attack</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
One of the earliest encrypting systems is attributed to Julius Caesar: if the letter to be encrypted is the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="20" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10896img1.png" 
 ALT="$m$"></SPAN>-th letter in the alphabet, replace it with the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="64" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10896img1.png" 
 ALT="$(m+k)$"></SPAN>-th where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="14" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10896img1.png" 
 ALT="$k$"></SPAN> is some fixed integer. Caesar used <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="46" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10896img1.png" 
 ALT="$k=3$"></SPAN>, or 
a <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="22" HEIGHT="17" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10896img1.png" 
 ALT="$\rightarrow$"></SPAN> d, as the key to the encryption. That is, ``a" would be encrypted to ``d", ``b" would be ``e", and so on until ``z" would be ``c". For example, for a <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="22" HEIGHT="17" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10896img1.png" 
 ALT="$\rightarrow$"></SPAN> k, the sentence ``<TT>this is a test</TT>" would become ``<TT>drsc sc k docd</TT>".

<P>
Now you have an encrypted sentence, and you know a decrypted word in that sentence. Your task is to find all the possible keys to the encryption.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input starts with a line containing a number, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10896img1.png" 
 ALT="$n$"></SPAN>, followed by <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10896img1.png" 
 ALT="$n$"></SPAN> sets of encrypted sentence/decrypted word pairs. Each set has two lines, the first line is the encrypted sentence which contains only words separated by a space with no punctuation, the second line contains a word which is one of the decrypted word of the sentence above it. All words are in lowercase letters. You may assume a word is at most 16 characters long, and a line has no more than 70 characters.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The output has <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10896img1.png" 
 ALT="$n$"></SPAN> lines of character(s), corresponding to the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10896img1.png" 
 ALT="$n$"></SPAN> sets of encrypted sentence/decrypted word pairs. The line consists of lowercase letter(s) of possible key(s). That is, if the plaintext ``a" is encrypted to ``x", then ``<TT>x</TT>" would be in the line. Each line of characters must be sorted in alphabetical order.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
2
drsc sc k docd
test
dl ruvd doha hp pz
we
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
k
hl
</PRE> 

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10897||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2002-2-1 (1.71)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>C: Travelling Distance</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="C: Travelling Distance">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
C: Travelling Distance</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
In geography, you have probably learned that locations on Earth are represented by latitude and longitude. Lines of latitude run in the same direction as the Equator. Latitudes start at the Equator, which is <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="21" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$0^{\circ}$"></SPAN>, representing the North-South direction. The range of latitudes is <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="38" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$180^{\circ}$"></SPAN>: from <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="45" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$90^{\circ}N$"></SPAN> (North Pole) to <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="21" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$0^{\circ}$"></SPAN>, and from <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="21" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$0^{\circ}$"></SPAN> to <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="41" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$90^{\circ}S$"></SPAN> (South Pole). Lines of longitude run from North Pole to South Pole. Longitudes start at the meridian of Greenwich, which is <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="21" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$0^{\circ}$"></SPAN>, representing the East-West direction. The range of longitudes is <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="38" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$360^{\circ}$"></SPAN>: from <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="52" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$180^{\circ}E$"></SPAN> to <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="21" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$0^{\circ}$"></SPAN>, and from <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="21" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$0^{\circ}$"></SPAN> to <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="57" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$180^{\circ}W$"></SPAN>. Therefore <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="52" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$180^{\circ}E$"></SPAN> is the same as <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="57" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$180^{\circ}W$"></SPAN>. 

<P>
Latitudes and longitudes use degrees as their unit. Degrees use minutes and seconds instead of plain decimal digits. 1 degree has 60 minutes, and 1 minute has 60 seconds. Only seconds have decimal digits. For example, Kingston, Ontario, is located at <!-- MATH
 $44^{\circ}16'N$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="67" HEIGHT="17" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$44^{\circ}16'N$"></SPAN>, <!-- MATH
 $76^{\circ}30'W$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="70" HEIGHT="17" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$76^{\circ}30'W$"></SPAN>, and Toronto, Ontario, is located at <!-- MATH
 $43^{\circ}41'N$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="67" HEIGHT="17" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$43^{\circ}41'N$"></SPAN>, <!-- MATH
 $79^{\circ}38'W$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="70" HEIGHT="17" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$79^{\circ}38'W$"></SPAN>. 

<P>
Assuming the Earth is a perfect sphere, the mean radius of the Earth is 6371.01 km. If you are given the latitude and longitude of two locations, can you find out the minimum walking distance between the two locations?

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input starts with a line containing a number <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$n$"></SPAN>, which is the number of pairs of locations, followed by <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$n$"></SPAN> lines. Each line consists of the position of the two locations, separated by a space. Positions are in the format of:
<BR><P></P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
a \ b \ c \ X \ d \ e \ f \ Y
\end{displaymath}
 -->

<IMG
 WIDTH="122" HEIGHT="30" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="\begin{displaymath}
a \ b \ c \ X \ d \ e \ f \ Y
\end{displaymath}">
</DIV>
<BR CLEAR="ALL">
<P></P>

<P>
The first four represent the latitude. <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="20" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$X$"></SPAN> is either the character `<TT>N</TT>' or `<TT>S</TT>', and the latitude is <!-- MATH
 $a^{\circ}b'c''X$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="65" HEIGHT="17" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$a^{\circ}b'c''X$"></SPAN> (<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="14" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$a$"></SPAN> degrees, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="12" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$b$"></SPAN> minutes, and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="12" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$c$"></SPAN> seconds). The next four represent the longitude. <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$Y$"></SPAN> is either the character `<TT>E</TT>' or `<TT>W</TT>', and the longitude is <!-- MATH
 $d^{\circ}e'f''Y$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="66" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$d^{\circ}e'f''Y$"></SPAN>. Each is separated by a space. <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="14" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$a$"></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="12" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$b$"></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$d$"></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="12" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$e$"></SPAN> are integers, while <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="12" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$c$"></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="33" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$f$"></SPAN> are floating point numbers with two decimal digits.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The output consists of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10897img1.png" 
 ALT="$n$"></SPAN> lines, each lines contain a number with two decimal digits, in km, the minimum surface distance between the two locations on Earth. Note that you must travel on the surface of the Earth. You can assume that there is no mountain between the two places.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
2
44 16 0.00 N 76 30 0.00 W 43 41 0.00 N 79 38 0.00 W
22 18 12.34 N 114 10 56.78 E 49 11 43.21 N 123 10 7.65 W
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
258.97
10255.47
</PRE> 

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

10898||||||false||||||
