  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>D: Combo Deal</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="D: Combo Deal">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
D: Combo Deal</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
A fast food store offers a series of ``combo meal deals" in addition to individually priced items. For example, the menu at the store may look like this: 

<P>
<PRE><TT>
Hamburger 							 $3.49 
<BR>
Fries 								 $0.99 
<BR>
Pop 								 $1.09 
<BR>
Ice Cream 							 $2.19 
<BR>
Value Meal (1 Hamburger, 1 Fries, 1 Pop) 			 $4.79 
<BR>
Lovers-Only (2 Hamburgers, 2 Fries, 2 Pops, 1 Ice Cream)	 $9.99 
<BR>
</TT></PRE> 
Buying a combo is cheaper than buying its items individually. 

<P>

<P>
<BR>
A parent of many kids (or a coach of many students) face this recurring problem: I need to get, say, 9 hamburgers, 6 fries, and 8 pops. How do I fit this into the menu, using the combo deals optimally, so as to pay as little as possible? Note that I am a conservativist, so I don't buy more food than I need.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input contains several test cases, each of them with a menu and several orders. 

<P>

<OL>
<LI>Menu: Individual items, then combos. 

<P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT>(a)</DT>
<DD>Individual items: number of items <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="45" HEIGHT="32" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10898img1.png" 
 ALT="$I \le 6$"></SPAN>, then their prices (at most $10 each).
</DD>
<DT>(b)</DT>
<DD>Combos: number of combos (at most 8), then for each combo, its composition as an <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10898img1.png" 
 ALT="$I$"></SPAN>-tuple of quantities and its price. 
</DD>
</DL>

<P>
Example: the sample input below encodes the menu above. 

<P>
</LI>
<LI>Orders: number of orders (at most 10), then for each order, an <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="15" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/108/10898img1.png" 
 ALT="$I$"></SPAN>-tuple of the wanted quantities. Each element in the tuples is at most 9. 
</LI>
</OL>

<P>
All prices are integers in cents.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each order of each case, output the minimum payment in cents on its own line.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
4 349 99 109 219
2
1 1 1 0 479
2 2 2 1 999
2
9 6 8 0
9 6 8 5
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
4139
4700
</PRE> 

<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10899||||||false||||||
<title>E: Billiard again </title> 

<h2>E: Billiard again </h2>

In a billiard table with a horizontal side <b>a</b> inches long and a vertical
side <b>b</b> inches long, a ball is launched from the middle of the table
with initial velocity <b>v</b> inches per second and launching
angle <b>A</b> between 0 and 90 degrees measured counter-clockwise from
the horizontal.  Before the first bounce, the ball
increases its distance from the lower left corner of the table.
<p>
What is the shortest distance between the path of the ball and a
point in the billiard table given by planar coordinates <b>x</b> and
<b>y</b>?  Assume, that the lower left corner of the table has coordinates 
&lt;<b>0</b>,<b>0</b>>.  
<p>
Assume that the collisions with a side are elastic (no energy loss),
and thus the velocity component of the ball parallel to each side
remains unchanged after the bounce.  However, due to friction the ball
decelerates at a constant rate and
comes to a full stop after <b>s</b> > 0 seconds.  Assume the ball
has a radius of zero.  Remember that, unlike pool tables, billiard
tables have no pockets.  

<h3>Input</h3> 

Input consists of a sequence of lines, each containing seven nonnegative
integers separated by whitespace.  The seven numbers are: 0 &lt; <b>a</b> &lt;= 100,
0 &lt; <b>b</b> &lt;= 100, 0 &lt; <b>v</b> &lt;= 10, 0 &lt;= <b>A</b> &lt;= 90, 0 &lt; <b>s</b> &lt;= 200,
0 &lt;= <b>x</b> &lt;= <b>a</b>, and 
0 &lt;= <b>y</b> &lt;= <b>b</b>, respectively.
<p>
Input is terminated by a line containing seven zeroes.

<h3>Output</h3>
For each input line except the last, output a line containing one real
number (accurate to two decimal places).
The number is the measure in inches of the shortest distance between
the ball and the point &lt;<b>x</b>,<b>y</b>>.

<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
100 50 10 90 10 0 0
100 50 10 0 40 0 0
100 100 10 45 15 0 0
100 50 10 1 200 0 50
100 50 10 1 200 100 50
100 50 10 45 1000 25 50
100 100 10 30 200 31 48
0 0 0 0 0 0 0
</pre>
<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>
55.90
25.00
70.71
8.42
10.16
0.00
2.04
</pre>

______________________________________________________
10900||||||false||||||
<html><head><title>Problem A: So you want to be a 2&lt;sup&gt;n&lt;/sup&gt;-aire</title></head>

<body>
<img align=right src=p10900.gif></a><h2>Problem A: So you want to be a 2<sup>n</sup>-aire?</h2>

The player starts with a prize of $1, and is asked a sequence of <em>n</em>
questions. For each question, he may

<ul>
<li> quit and keep his prize.
</li><li> answer the question.
    If wrong, he quits with nothing.
    If correct, the prize is doubled, and he continues with the next
    question.
</li></ul>
After the last question, he quits with his prize.
The player wants to maximize his expected prize.
<p>
Once each question is asked, the player is able to assess the
probability <i>p</i> that he will be able to answer it.
For each question, we assume that <i>p</i> is a random variable
uniformly distributed over the range <em>t .. 1</em>.
</p><p>
Input is a number of lines, each with two numbers: an integer
<em>1 &le; n &le; 30</em>, and a real <em>0 &le; t &le; 1</em>.
Input is terminated by a line containing <tt>0 0</tt>.  This line
should not be processed.
</p><p>
For each input <em>n</em> and <em>t</em>, print the player's expected
prize, if he plays the best strategy.  Output should be rounded to 
three fractional digits.

</p><h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>1 0.5
1 0.3
2 0.6
24 0.25
0 0
</pre>


<h3>Output for sample input</h3>
<pre>
1.500
1.357
2.560
230.138
</pre>
<hr>
<em>Don Reble</em>
</body></html>

______________________________________________________
10901||||||false||||||
<html><head><title>Problem B: Ferry Loading III</title></head>

<body><img src=p10901.jpg height=300 width=450 align="right">
<h2>Problem B:  Ferry Loading III</h2>
Before bridges were common, ferries were used to transport cars across
rivers. River ferries, unlike their larger cousins, run on a guide line
and are powered by the river's current. Cars drive onto the ferry from
one end, the ferry crosses the river, and the cars exit from the other
end of the ferry.
<p>
There is a ferry across the river that can take <em>n</em> cars
across the river in <em>t</em> minutes and return in <em>t</em> minutes.  
A car may arrive at either river bank to be transported by the
ferry to the opposite bank.  The ferry travels continuously back and
forth between the banks so long it is carrying a car or there is at 
least one car waiting at either bank.  Whenever the ferry arrives at one of the banks, it unloads
its cargo and loads up to <em>n</em> cars that are waiting to cross.
If there are more than <em>n</em>, those that have been waiting the
longest are loaded.  If there are no cars waiting on either bank,
the ferry waits until one arrives, loads it (if it arrives on the
same bank of the ferry), and crosses the river.
At what time does each car reach the other side of the river?
</p><p>
The first line of input contains <i>c</i>, the number of test cases.
Each test case begins with <i>n, t, m</i>.
<i>m</i> lines follow, each giving the arrival time
for a car (in minutes since the beginning of the day), and the 
bank at which the car arrives ("left" or "right").
For each test case, output one line per car, in the same order as
the input, giving
the time at which that car is unloaded at the opposite bank.
Output an empty line between cases.
</p><p>
You may assume that 0 &lt; n, t, m &le; 10000.  The arrival times for each test
case are strictly increasing.  The ferry is initially on the left bank.
Loading and unloading time may be considered to be 0.
</p><h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>2
2 10 10
0 left
10 left
20 left
30 left
40 left
50 left
60 left
70 left
80 left
90 left
2 10 3
10 right
25 left
40 left
</pre>
<h3>Output for sample input</h3>
<pre>
10
30
30
50
50
70
70
90
90
110

30
40
60
</pre>
<hr>
<i>Gordon V. Cormack</i></body></html>


______________________________________________________
10902||||||false||||||
<html><head><title>Problem C: Pick-up sticks</title></head>

<body>
<img width=220 height=330 align=right src=p10902a.jpg vspace=20 hspace=20>
<h2>Problem C: Pick-up sticks</h2>

<p>
Stan has <em>n</em> sticks of various length.  He throws them one at a
time on the floor in a random way.  After finishing throwing, Stan
tries to find the top sticks, that is these sticks such that
there is no stick on top of them.  Stan has noticed that the last
thrown stick is always on top but he wants to know all the sticks
that are on top.
Stan sticks are very, very thin such that their thickness can be neglected.
<p>
Input consists of a number of cases.  The data for each case start
with <em>1 &le; n &le; 100000</em>, the number of sticks for this
case.  The following <em>n</em> lines contain four numbers each, these
numbers are the planar coordinates of the endpoints of one stick.
The sticks are listed in the order in which Stan has thrown them.  
You may assume that there are no more than 1000 top sticks.  The
input is ended by the case with <em>n=0</em>. This case should not be
processed.
<p>
For each input case, print one line of output listing the top sticks
in the format given in the sample.  The top sticks should be listed in
order in which they were thrown. 
<p>
The picture to the right below illustrates the first case from input.
<p>
<img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10902b.jpg"  align="right" vspace=20 hspace=100>
<h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>
5
1 1 4 2
2 3 3 1
1 -2.0 8 4
1 4 8 2
3 3 6 -2.0
3
0 0 1 1
1 0 2 1
2 0 3 1
0
</pre>
<h3>Output for sample input</h3>
<pre>Top sticks: 2, 4, 5.
Top sticks: 1, 2, 3.
</pre>
<p>
<p><p><p><p><p><p><p><p>
<hr>

<em>Piotr Rudnicki</em></body></html>

______________________________________________________
10903||||||false||||||
<img src=p10903.jpg align=right><h2>Problem D:  Rock-Paper-Scissors Tournament</h2>

Rock-Paper-Scissors is game for two players, A and B,
who each choose, independently of the other, one of
<i>rock, paper,</i> or <i>scissors</i>.  A player
chosing <i>paper</i> wins over a player chosing <i>rock</i>;
a player chosing <i>scissors</i> wins over a player chosing
<i>paper</i>; a player chosing <i>rock</i> wins over a player
chosing <i>scissors</i>.  A player chosing the same thing
as the other player neither wins nor loses.
<p>
A tournament has been organized in which each of <i>n</i>
players plays <i>k</i> rock-scissors-paper games with each
of the other players - <i>k*n*(n-1)/2</i> games in total.
Your job is to compute the <i>win average</i> for each player,
defined as <i>w / (w + l)</i> where <i>w</i> is the number
of games won, and <i>l</i> is the number of games lost, by
the player.
<p>
Input consists of several test cases.
The first line of input for each case contains <i>1 &le; n &le; 100</i>
<i>1 &le; k &le; 100</i> as defined above.  For each game, a line follows
containing p<sub>1</sub>, m<sub>1</sub>, p<sub>2</sub>, m<sub>2</sub>.
1 &le; p<sub>1</sub> &le; <i>n</i> and 1 &le; p<sub>2</sub> &le; <i>n</i>
are distinct integers identifying two players;
m<sub>1</sub> and m<sub>2</sub> are their respective moves
("rock", "scissors", or "paper").  A line containing 0 follows the
last test case.
<p>
Output one line each for player 1, player 2, and so on, through player <i>n</i>,
giving the player's win average rounded to three decimal places.  If the
win average is undefined, output "-".  Output an empty line between cases.
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
2 4
1 rock 2 paper
1 scissors 2 paper
1 rock 2 rock
2 rock 1 scissors
2 1
1 rock 2 paper
0
</pre>
<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
0.333
0.667

0.000
1.000
</pre>
<hr>
Gordon V. Cormack

______________________________________________________
10904||||||false||||||
<img align=right src=p10904.jpg><h2>Problem E: Structural Equivalence</h2>
In programming language design circles, there has been much debate about
the merits of "structural equivalence" vs. "name equivalence" for type
matching.  Pascal purports to have "name equivalence", but it doesn't;
C purports to have structural equivalence, but it doesn't.  Algol 68,
the <i>Latin</i> of programming languages, has pure structural equivalence.
<p>
A simplified syntax for an Algol 68 type definition is as follows:
<pre>
   <i>type_def</i> -> type <i>T</i> = <i>type_expr</i>
   <i>type_expr</i> -> <i>T</i> | int | real | char | struct ( <i>field_defs</i> )
   <i>field_defs</i> -> T | <i>field_defs</i> T
</pre>
<p>
In this syntax, <i>T</i> is a programmer-defined type name (in this problem,
for simplicity, a single upper case letter).  Plain text symbols appear
literally in the input, and zero or more spaces may appear where there
are spaces in the syntax.
<p>
Algol 68 type equivalence say that two types are equivalent if they
are the same primitive type or they are both structures containing
equivalent types in the same order.
<p>
Input consists of several test cases.
Each test case is a sequence of Algol 68 definitions, as described
above, one per line.  A line containing "-" separates test cases. A line containing
"--" follows the last test case.  The output for each case will consist of several lines; each line should contain
a list of type names, all of which represent equivalent types.  Each type
name should appear on exactly one line of output, and the number of output
lines should be minimized.  The names in each list should be in alphabetical
order; the lines of output should also be in alphabetical order.  Output an empty line
between test cases.
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
type A = int
type B = A
type C = int
type X = struct(A B)
type Y = struct(B A)
type Z = struct(A Z)
type S = struct(A S)
type W = struct(B R)
type R = struct(C W)
--
</pre>
<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
A B C
R S W Z
X Y
</pre>
<hr>
<i>Gordon V. Cormack</i>

______________________________________________________
10905||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<title>A - Children&rsquo;s Game</title>
<style>
<!--
.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
-->
</style>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" link=blue vlink=purple class="Normal" lang=EN-US> 
<div class=Section1> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td colspan=2 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'>4<sup>th</sup> </span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
    font-family:Garamond;    '>IIUC</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> </span></i><i><span
    style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;
    '>Inter-University</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> Programming Contest, 2005</span></i></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=14% rowspan=3 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
  style='font-size:60.0pt;font-family:Arial'>A</span></b></p></td> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Childrens Game</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Input: standard input<br> 
          </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Output: standard output</span></b></p> </td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Problemsetter: </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Md.</span></b><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'> Kamruzzaman</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>There are lots of number games for children. These games are pretty easy to play but not so easy to make. We will discuss about an interesting game here. Each player will be given <b>N</b> positive integer. (S)He can make a big integer by appending those integers after one another. Such as if there are 4 integers as 123, 124, 56, 90 then the following integers can be made  1231245690, 1241235690, 5612312490, 9012312456, 9056124123 etc. In fact 24 such integers can be made. But one thing is sure that 9056124123 is the largest possible integer which can be made.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>You may think that its very easy to find out the answer but will it be easy for a child who has just got the idea of number?</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Input</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>Each input starts with a positive integer <b>N</b> (&#8804; 50). In next lines there are <b>N</b> positive integers. Input is terminated by <b>N</b> = 0, which should not be processed.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Output</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>For each input set, you have to print the largest possible integer which can be made by appending all the <b>N</b> integers.</p> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Output for Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>4<br> 
          </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>123 124 56 90<br> 
          </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>5<br> 
          </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>123 124 56 90 9<br> 
          </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>5<br> 
          </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>9 9 9 9 9<br> 
          </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>0</span></b></p></td> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"> <p><strong>9056124123<br>
      </strong><strong>99056124123<br>
      </strong><strong>99999</strong></p>
      </td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
</div> 
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10906||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<title>B - Strange Integration</title>
<style>
<!--
.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
-->
</style>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" link=blue vlink=purple class="Normal" lang=EN-US> 
<div class=Section1> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td colspan=2 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'>4<sup>th</sup> </span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
    font-family:Garamond;    '>IIUC</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> </span></i><i><span
    style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;
    '>Inter-University</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> Programming Contest, 2005</span></i></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=14% rowspan=3 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
  style='font-size:60.0pt;font-family:Arial'>B</span></b></p></td> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
  style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Strange Integration</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Input: standard input<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Output: standard output</span></b></p>         </td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Problemsetter: </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Md.</span></b><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'> Kamruzzaman</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>Do not get perplexed with the name of problem, it has nothing to do with integral calculus. We will concentrate on integration of simple algebraic expressions.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>Complex algebraic expressions consisting of integers, addition and multiplication operators and parentheses can be represented by the following BNF notations </p> 
  <table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=355 valign=top class="Normal"> <p>&lt;expr&gt;   &#8594; &lt;expr&gt; <b>+</b> &lt;term&gt;<br>
        &lt;expr&gt;   &#8594; &lt;term&gt;<br>
        &lt;term&gt;   &#8594; &lt;term&gt; <b>*</b> &lt;factor&gt;<br>
        &lt;term&gt;   &#8594; &lt;factor&gt;<br>
        &lt;factor&gt; &#8594; <b>(</b>&lt;expr&gt;<b>)<br>
        </b>&lt;factor&gt; &#8594; <b>num</b></p>        </td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>According to the above grammar, both operators are left associative and multiplication is given higher precedence. So, 2 + 3*4 is same as 2 + (3*4). Similarly, 2 + 3 + 4 is same as (2+3) + 4. On the other hand, (2 + 3) * 4 is different to 2 + 3 * 4. It may be surprising but 2 + 3 + 4 is different to 2 + (3 + 4) as in this case, the order of evaluation is different.-</p> 
  <table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=168 valign=top class="Normal"> <p>    2 + 3 + 4<br>
        =  5 + 4<br>
        =  9</p>        </td> 
      <td width=180 valign=top class="Normal"> <p>    2 + (3 + 4)<br>
        =  2 + 7<br>
        =  9</p>        </td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p>Consider the expression (2+3)*4 + (2 +3)*5 + 6</p> 
  <p align=center style='text-align:center'><img width=608 height=245
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10906.png"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1025"></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>The above picture depicts two different ways of representing the expression in hand if we follow the given grammar. The left one is known as the AST (Abstract Syntax Tree) and the other one is DAG (common sub-expression is handled once). Such a representation clearly shows the way of evaluating an algebraic expression. Here, each non-leaf node is assigned a <b>unique</b> variable name. As a result, we can have a sequence of simple expressions to evaluate the expression </p> 
  <table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=196 valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:15.0pt;
  '>a = 2 + 3<br>
      </span><span style='font-size:15.0pt;
  '>b = a * 4<br>
      </span><span style='font-size:15.0pt;
  '>c = 2 + 3<br>
      </span><span style='font-size:15.0pt;
  '>d = c * 5<br>
      </span><span style='font-size:15.0pt;
  '>e = b + d<br>
      </span><span style='font-size:15.0pt;
  '>f = e + 6</span></p>        </td> 
      <td width=192 valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:15.0pt;
  '>a = 2 + 3<br>
      </span><span style='font-size:15.0pt;
  '>b = a * 4<br>
      </span><span style='font-size:15.0pt;
  '>d = a * 5<br>
      </span><span style='font-size:15.0pt;
  '>e = b + d<br>
      </span><span style='font-size:15.0pt;
  '>f = e + 6</span></p>        </td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>In both cases, <b>f</b> denotes the original expression (2+3)*4 + (2+3)*5 + 6. Here, you have to integrate a sequence of simple expressions into the original one. A simple expression will always be of the form </p> 
  <p align=center style='text-align:center'><i>variable</i> = (<i>variable</i> | <i>integer</i>)  (<b>+</b> | *)  (<i>variable</i> | <i>integer</i>)</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>For a given sequence of simple expressions, there can be several original expressions. Consider the following cases </p> 
  <table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=240 valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'>a =  2 + 3<br>
        b =  a * 4<br>
        Then <b>b</b> can be - </p>        </td> 
      <td width=240 valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'>b = (2 + 3) * 4<br>
        b = ((2 + 3) * 4)<br>
        b = ((2) + (3)) * 4<br>
        etc.</p>        </td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>We need the first one, i.e. expression having minimum number of literals.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Input</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>The input file will start with an integer, <b>T </b>(<b>1&#8804;T&#8804;100</b>) denoting the number of tests. Each input will start with a positive integer, <b>N (1&#8804;N&#8804;50)</b> which is the number of simple expressions. Subsequent lines will contain the simple expressions defined above. The input will be valid, i.e. it will be always possible to construct a correct expression. Also, variable names will be referenced once they have been assigned. Either variable name or integers can have at most <b>10</b> characters. The integers will be always positive here (no unary minus) and variable names will contain letters only. Spaces will be used to separate numbers, variables and operators.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Output</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>For each input, print Expression #<b>D</b>:  followed by the expression denoted by the last variable in the list of simple expressions. Here <b>D</b> is the test number, starting from 1. The length of any expression will not be greater than <b>5000</b>.</p> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Output for Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"> <p><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>A = 2 + 3<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>B = A + A<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>A = 2 + 3<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>B = A + 4<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>C = B + 5</span></b></p>        </td> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"> <p><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Expression #1: 2+3+(2+3)<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Expression #2: 2+3+4+5</span></b></p>        </td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
</div> 
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10907||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<title>C - Art Gallery</title>
<style>
<!--
.MsoHeader
	{tab-stops:center 216.0pt right 432.0pt;
	font-size:12.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";}
.MsoBodyText
	{font-size:12.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";}
.MsoBodyText2
	{text-align:justify;
	font-size:12.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";}
.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
-->
</style>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" link=blue vlink=purple class="Normal" lang=EN-US> 
<div class=Section1> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td colspan=2 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'>4<sup>th</sup> </span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
    font-family:Garamond;    '>IIUC</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> </span></i><i><span
    style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;
    '>Inter-University</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> Programming Contest, 2005</span></i></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=14% rowspan=3 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
  style='font-size:60.0pt;font-family:Arial'>C</span></b></p></td> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Art Gallery</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Input: standard input<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Output: standard output</span></b></p>         </td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Problemsetter: </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Md.</span></b><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'> Kamruzzaman</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p class=MsoBodyText2>The ancient art gallery is a special one and it is convex in shape. But recently due to the extension, one of its vertex becomes concave ( a vertex which produces an angle greater than 180 degree). Previously, the whole art gallery was visible by the lights. But it may not be the case now. The authority wants to know the area covered by each of the light ( Just turn on one light and keep others off ) now. In the following figure, dark region shows the area covered by the light which is on.</p> 
  <p align=center style='text-align:center'><img width=338 height=328
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10907.png"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1025"></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Input</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>Each dataset will start with a positive integer, <b>N (1 &#8804; N &#8804; 20)</b>. In next few lines there will be <b>N</b> Cartesian coordinates defining the art gallery. The points will be in anti-clockwise order. The coordinates will be integer and their absolute value will not exceed 1000. Then in next line there will be a positive integer <b>L</b>. Following <b>L</b> lines will contain the coordinates of the lights which will also be integers. The lights are guaranteed not to be outside the gallery. Exactly one vertex of the gallery will be concave.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>Input is terminated by EOF.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Output</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>For each set of input print &quot;Gallery #i&quot; where 'i' is the number of gallery to be considered (starting with 1). In next <b>L</b> lines print the area covered by j'th light. Use two digits after decimal point in case of covered area.</p> 
  <br clear=all style='page-break-before:always'> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Output for Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"> <p class=MsoHeader><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>5<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>0 0<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>50 50<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>100 0<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>100 100<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>0 100<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>49 50<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>50 51</span></b></p>        </td> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"> <p><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Gallery #1<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>6250.00<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>7500.00</span></b></p>      </td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
</div> 
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10908||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<title>D - Largest Square</title>
<style>
<!--
.GramE
	{}
.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
.style1 {
	font-family: "Courier New";
	font-weight: bold;
}
-->
</style>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" link=blue vlink=purple class="Normal" lang=EN-US> 
<div class=Section1> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td colspan=2 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'>4<sup>th</sup> </span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
    font-family:Garamond;    '>IIUC</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> </span></i><i><span
    style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;
    '>Inter-University</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> Programming Contest, 2005</span></i></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=14% rowspan=3 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
  style='font-size:60.0pt;font-family:Arial'>D</span></b></p></td> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
  style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Largest Square</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Input: standard input<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Output: standard output</span></b></p>         </td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Problemsetter: </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;  font-family:Arial'>Tanveer Ahsan</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>Given a rectangular grid of characters you have to find out the length of a side of the largest square such that all the characters of the square are same and the center [intersecting point of the two diagonals] of the square is at location <b>(r, c)</b>. The height and width of the grid is <b>M</b> and <b>N</b> respectively. Upper left corner and lower right corner of the grid will be denoted by <b>(0, 0)</b> and <b>(M-1, N-1)</b> respectively. Consider the grid of characters given below. Given the location (1, 2) the length of a side of the largest square is 3.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>abbbaaaaaa<br>
  </span></span><span class=GramE><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>abbbaaaaaa<br>
  </span></span><span class=GramE><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>abbbaaaaaa<br>
  </span></span><span class=GramE><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>aaaaaaaaaa<br>
  </span></span><span class=GramE><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>aaaaaaaaaa<br>
  </span></span><span class=GramE><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>aaccaaaaaa<br>
  </span></span><span class=GramE><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>aaccaaaaaa</span></span></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Input</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>The input starts with a line containing a single integer <b>T (&lt; 21)</b>. This is followed by <b>T</b> test cases. The first line of each of them will contain three integers <b>M</b>, <b>N</b> and <b>Q (&lt; 21)</b> separated by a space where <b>M</b>, <b>N</b> denotes the dimension of the grid. Next follows <b>M</b> lines each containing <b>N</b> characters. Finally, there will be <b>Q</b> lines each containing two <span class=GramE>integers</span> <b>r</b> and <b>c</b>. The value of <b>M</b> and <b>N</b> will be at most <b>100</b>.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Output</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>For each test case in the input produce <b>Q+1</b> lines of output. In the first line print the value of <b>M</b>, <b>N</b> and <b>Q</b> in that order separated by single space. In the next <strong>Q</strong> lines, output the length of a side of the largest square in the corresponding grid for each <b>(r, c)</b> pair in the input.</p> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Output for Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1<br>
      7 10 4<br>
      abbbaaaaaa<br>
      abbbaaaaaa<br>
      abbbaaaaaa<br>
      aaaaaaaaaa<br>
      aaaaaaaaaa<br>
      aaccaaaaaa<br>
      aaccaaaaaa<br>
      1 2<br>
      2 4<br>
      4 6<br>
      </span></b><span class="style1"><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>5 2</span></span></p>        </td> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>7 10 4<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>5<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1</span></b></p>        </td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <br clear=all style='page-break-before:always'> 
</div> 
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10909||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<title>E - Lucky Number</title>
<style>
<!--
.SpellE
	{}
.GramE
	{}
.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
.style2 {
	font-family: "Courier New";
	font-weight: bold;
}
-->
</style>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" link=blue vlink=purple class="Normal" lang=EN-US> 
<div class=Section1> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td colspan=2 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'>4<sup>th</sup> </span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
    font-family:Garamond;    '>IIUC</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> </span></i><i><span
    style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;
    '>Inter-University</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> Programming Contest, 2005</span></i></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=14% rowspan=3 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
  style='font-size:60.0pt;font-family:Arial'>E</span></b></p></td> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
  style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Lucky Number</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Input: standard input<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Output: standard output</span></b></p>         </td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Problemsetter: </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;  font-family:Arial'>Mohammed Shamsul Alam<br>
        Special Thanks: Tanveer Hasan Saaem
      </span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b>Lucky numbers</b> are defined by a variation of the well-known <b>sieve of Eratosthenes</b>. Beginning with the natural numbers <b>strike out all</b> <b>even ones</b>, leaving the odd numbers 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, ... The second number is 3, next <b>strike out every third number</b>, leaving 1, 3, 7, 9, 13, ... The third number is 7, next <b>strike out every seventh number</b> and continue this process infinite number of times. The numbers <b>surviving</b> are called <b>lucky numbers</b>. The <b>first few lucky numbers</b> are:</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>            1, 3, 7, 9, 13, 15, 21, 25, 31, <span class=GramE>33, 
 
</span></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>In this problem your task is to test whether a number can be written as the sum of two lucky numbers.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Input</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>The input file contains at most <b>100000</b> lines of input. Each line contains a single integer <b>n (0 &lt; n &#8804; 2000000)</b>. Input is terminated by end of file.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Output</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify;'>For each line of input produce one line of output. This line should be of one of the following types depending on whether <b>n</b> is expressible as the sum of two lucky numbers.</p> 
  <p><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>     <span class=GramE>n</span> is not the sum of two <span class=SpellE>luckies</span>!<br>
  </span><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>     <span class=GramE>n</span> is the sum of L1 and L2.</span></p> 
  <p>For the second case, always make sure that <b>(L2-L1)</b> is <b>nonnegative</b> and <b>minimized</b>.</p> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Output for Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>11<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>12</span></b></p>        </td> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"><p class="style2">11 is not the sum of two luckies!<br>
        12 is the sum of 3 and 9.</p></td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
</div> 
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10910||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<title>F - Marks Distribution</title>
<style>
<!--
.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
-->
</style>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" link=blue vlink=purple class="Normal" lang=EN-US> 
<div class=Section1> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td colspan=2 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'>4<sup>th</sup> IIUC Inter-University Programming Contest, 2005</span></i></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=14% rowspan=3 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
  style='font-size:60.0pt;font-family:Arial'>F</span></b></p></td> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
  style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Marks Distribution</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Input: standard input<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Output: standard output</span></b></p>         </td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Problemsetter: </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;  font-family:Arial'>Md. Bahlul Haider<br>
        Judge Solution: Tanveer Ahsan
      </span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>In an examination one student appeared in <b>N</b> subjects and has got total <b>T</b> marks. He has passed in all the <b>N</b> subjects where minimum mark for passing in each subject is <b>P</b>. You have to calculate the number of ways the student can get the marks. For example, if <b>N=3</b>, <b>T=34</b> and <b>P=10</b> then the marks in the three subject could be as follows.</p> 
  <table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal">&nbsp; </td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b>Subject 1</b></p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b>Subject 2</b></p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b>Subject 3</b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>1</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>14</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>2</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>13</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>3</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>13</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>4</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>12</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>5</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>12</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>12</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>6</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>12</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>7</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>13</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>8</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>13</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>9</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>14</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>12</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>12</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>12</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>12</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>12</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>12</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>13</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>13</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>14</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>11</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>13</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=30 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>15</p></td> 
      <td width=90 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
      <td width=108 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>14</p></td> 
      <td width=84 valign=top class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'>10</p></td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>So there are 15 solutions. So <b>F (3, 34, 10) = 15</b>.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Input</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>In the first line of the input there will be a single positive integer <b>K</b> followed by <b>K</b> lines each containing a single test case. Each test case contains three positive integers denoting <b>N</b>, <b>T</b> and <b>P</b> respectively. The values of <b>N</b>, <b>T</b> and <b>P</b> will be at most 70. You may assume that the final answer will fit in a standard 32-bit integer.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Output</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>For each input, print in a line the value of <b>F (N, T, P)</b>.</p> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
      <td width=50% valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Output for Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3 34 10<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3 34 10</span></b></p>        </td> 
      <td valign=top class="Normal"> <p><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>15<br>
      </span></b><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>15</span></b></p>        </td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
</div> 
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10911||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<title>G - Forming Quiz Teams</title>
<style>
<!--
.GramE
	{}
.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
.style1 {
	font-family: "Courier New";
	font-weight: bold;
}
-->
</style>
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" link=blue vlink=purple class="Normal" lang=EN-US> 
<div class=Section1> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td colspan=2 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'>4<sup>th</sup> </span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
    font-family:Garamond;    '>IIUC</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> </span></i><i><span
    style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;
    '>Inter-University</span></i><i><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Garamond;'> Programming Contest, 2005</span></i></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=14% rowspan=3 class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
  style='font-size:60.0pt;font-family:Arial'>G</span></b></p></td> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Forming Quiz Teams</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Input: standard input<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Output: standard output</span></b></p>       </td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td class="Normal"> <p><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Problemsetter: </span></b><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;  font-family:Arial'>Sohel Hafiz</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>You have been given the job of forming the quiz teams for the next MCA CPCI Quiz Championship. There are <b>2*N </b>students interested to participate and you have to form <b>N </b>teams, each team consisting of two members. Since the members have to practice together, all the students want their members house as near as possible. Let x1 be the distance between the houses of group 1, x2 be the distance between the houses of group 2 and so on. You have to make sure the summation (x1 + x2 + x3 + 
. + <span
class=GramE>xn</span>) is minimized.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Input</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>There will be many cases in the input file. Each case starts with an integer <b>N (N &#8804; 8). </b>The next <b>2*N </b>lines will given the information of the students. Each line starts with the students name, followed by the <b>x</b> coordinate and then the <b>y</b> coordinate. Both <b>x, y </b>are integers in the range 0 to 1000. Students name will consist of lowercase letters only and the length will be at most 20.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>Input is terminated by a case where <b>N</b> is equal to 0.</p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Output</span></b></p> 
  <p style='text-align:justify'>For each case, output the case number followed by the summation of the distances, rounded to 2 decimal places. Follow the sample for exact format.</p> 
  <table width="100%" border=1 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=308 valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
      <td width=308 valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
  font-family:Arial'>Output for Sample Input</span></b></p></td> 
    </tr> 
    <tr> 
      <td width=308 valign=top class="Normal"> <p style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>5<br>
      sohel 10 10<br>
      mahmud 20 10<br>
      sanny 5 5<br>
      prince 1 1<br>
      per 120 3<br>
      mf 6 6<br>
      kugel 50 60<br>
      joey 3 24<br>
      limon 6 9<br>
      manzoor 0 0<br>
      1<br>
      derek 9 9<br>
      jimmy 10 10<br>
      </span></b><span class="style1"><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>0</span></span></p>        </td> 
      <td width=308 valign=top class="Normal"> <p><b><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Case 1: 118.40<br>
      </span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Case 2: 1.41</span></b></p>        </td> 
    </tr> 
  </table> 
</div> 
</body>
</html>
