</style>
<!--[if gte mso 10]>
<style>
 /* Style Definitions */
 table.MsoNormalTable
	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";
	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;
	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;
	mso-style-noshow:yes;
	mso-style-parent:" ;
	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
	mso-para-margin:0in;
	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-ansi-language:#0400;
	mso-fareast-language:#0400;
	mso-bidi-language:#0400;}
</style>
<![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="4098">
  <o:colormru v:ext="edit" colors="#602000"/>
 </o:shapedefaults></xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->
</head>

<body lang=EN-US link="#6633CC" vlink=purple style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<h1 align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:4.0in'><b><span
style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:
normal'>Problem G</span></b><b><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-fareast-language:ZH-CN;font-style:normal'><o:p></o:p></span></b></h1>

<h1 align=center style='text-align:center'><span class=SpellE><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:20.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
18.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:normal'>Playfair</span></b></span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:20.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
18.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:normal'> Cipher<o:p></o:p></span></b></h1>

<h3><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt'>Input:</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt'> Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-fareast-language:ZH-CN'>Output:</span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-fareast-language:ZH-CN'> Standard Output</span><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'> <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>The Playfair cipher was invented more than
one and a half century ago by Sir Charles Wheatsone, one of the pioneers of the
electric telegraph. It was made popular by Baron <span class=SpellE>Playfair</span>
of <st1:place w:st="on">St Andrews</st1:place>, a friend of Wheatstone, and
used by British <span class=SpellE>gouvernment</span> institutions <span
class=SpellE>upto</span> the <span class=GramE>first world war</span>. The
cipher's main advantages were that it is quite easy to <span class=GramE>use,</span>
both for encryption and decryption, and that it was relatively secure compared
to other ciphers of that age. Nowadays, however, it would stand no chance
against high speed computers, and that is what you are going to prove in this
task.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>To encrypt a message, the text is first
converted to groups of two capitals, called digraphs. This is done as follows: <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<ol start=1 type=1>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
     "Times New Roman"'>Convert all letters in the text to uppercase and omit
     all non-alphabetic characters. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
     "Times New Roman"'>Replace all letters 'J' by 'I'. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
     "Times New Roman"'>Form digraphs, but avoid having twice the same letter
     in a digraph. Insert an extra 'X' between the identical letters if
     necessary. If the repeated letter is an 'X', insert a 'Q' instead. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
     "Times New Roman"'>If the last digraph would be incomplete, append an
     extra 'X' to the text (or a 'Q' if the last letter in the text is an 'X').
     <o:p></o:p></span></li>
</ol>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>Consider the
following message: &quot;Programming in C and Pascal is easy; I will learn Java
next year.&quot; The digraph representation would be: <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:windowtext'>PR OG RA MX MI NG IN CA ND PA SC <st1:State w:st="on"><st1:place
 w:st="on">AL</st1:place></st1:State> IS EA SY IW IL LX LE AR NI AV AN EX TY EA
RX<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>Note the
extra 'X' between the two 'M's of 'programming'. There is no extra 'X' between
the two 'L's of 'will', because they are in different digraphs, but there is
one between 'will' and 'learn'. There is also an extra 'X' at the end of the
message. The 'J' in 'Java' is replaced by an 'I'.<br>
To illustrate the exceptions for the letter 'X' in the original text, consider
the message &quot;I am an ex-xenophobe, attempting to relax!<span class=GramE>&quot;.</span>
This becomes: <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:windowtext'>IA MA NE XQ XE NO PH <st1:place w:st="on">OB</st1:place> EA
TX TE MP TI NG TO RE LA XQ<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>The next stage is the replacement of each
digraph by <span class=GramE>an other</span> digraph according to the following
rules: <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<ul type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo6;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
     "Times New Roman"'>The uppercase letters, 'J' excluded, are placed in a
     5X5 square in some predetermined order. This is the key for the
     encryption. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo6;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
     "Times New Roman"'>If the two letters of the digraph are in the same row
     of the square, replace them by the letters <span class=SpellE>occuring</span>
     at the immediate right of each one. If one of the letters is in the
     rightmost column, replace it by the letter in the first column of the same
     row (wrap around). <o:p></o:p></span></li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo6;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
     "Times New Roman"'>If the two letters of the digraph are in the same
     column of the square, replace them by the letters <span class=SpellE>occuring</span>
     immediately below each one. Wrap around to the same column in the top row
     if one of them is in the bottom row. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo6;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
     "Times New Roman"'>If the letters are neither in the same row nor the same
     column, replace the first letter by the letter in the same row as the
     first letter and the same column as the second letter. Replace the second
     letter by the letter in the same row as the second letter and the same
     column as the first letter. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
</ul>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>The
resulting digraphs form the encrypted code. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>Consider the key:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype id="_x0000_t75"
 coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t" path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe"
 filled="f" stroked="f">
 <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
 <v:formulas>
  <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
 </v:formulas>
 <v:path o:extrusionok="f" gradientshapeok="t" o:connecttype="rect"/>
 <o:lock v:ext="edit" aspectratio="t"/>
</v:shapetype><v:shape id="_x0000_i1025" type="#_x0000_t75" alt="  style='width:135.6pt;
 height:135pt'>
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/g_files/image001.gif"  o:href="../../Archive2005/LJ-play%20fare/playfair.gif"/>
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=181 height=180
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/g_files/image001.gif"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1025"><![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>The first digraph of the first example
above is 'PR'. Since the letters are not in the same row or column, 'P' is
replaced by 'F' and 'R' is replaced by 'V'. The replacement digraph is 'FV'.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>Similarly the following digraphs, 'OG',
'RA', 'MX','MI', 'NG' and 'IN', are replaced by <span class=SpellE>resp</span>.
'CV', 'GE', 'PH', 'PW', 'AS' and 'UX'.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>In the next digraph, 'CA', the letters
occur in the same column, so 'C' is replaced by 'G' and 'A' is replaced by 'L',
resulting in the new digraph 'GL'.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>We also encounter the digraph 'EA' with
letters in the same row. It's converted to 'HE'. Horizontal wrap around is
encountered during the conversion of 'IW', 'IL' and 'EX'. No vertical wrap
around occurs in the example, but the digraph 'BM' would convert to 'HK'.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>The complete encryption of the first
message is: <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:windowtext'>FV CV GE PH PW AS UX GL UY ZX GY LZ UV HE NS UI UQ IA QA EG
XU XG EA HN KC HE VE<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>The second
message encrypts to: <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:windowtext'>LX ZH AH EI NH XY MX KV HE OE RQ PD OQ AS KY EQ ZL EI<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>Decryption is easy once you know the key.
That process is not described here, because I trust you can figure that out for
yourself. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'>In this problem you will implement a so called 'known
plaintext attack'. You have a piece of plain text and you also have <span
class=GramE>it's</span> encrypted code. From that information you will have to
deduce a key and use that key to decode another piece of encrypted text.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<h4><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";font-weight:
normal'>The input contains several cases, the number of which is on the first
line. Every case has three parts. The first part is the plaintext and consists
of one or more lines of ordinary text. The second part is the code that is the
result of encrypting the first part. The third part is code for the text you
are to decrypt. The parts are terminated by a <span class=SpellE>hashmark</span>
('#') on a line by itself. Code parts are printed as uppercase digraphs, 20
digraphs on a line, separated by one space. The last line of a code part can
contain fewer than 20 digraphs. No code part will contain more than 5000
digraphs.<o:p></o:p></span></h4>

<h4><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";font-weight:
normal'><br>
The keys can differ between cases (of course).<o:p></o:p></span></h4>

<h4><span style='font-size:12.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></h4>

<h4>Output</h4>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-layout-grid-align:none;
text-autospace:none'>For each case, first output a line &quot;Case x:&quot;
where x is the case number (starting from 1).<br>
Then output the decrypted code represented as digraphs in the same format as the
code parts in the input. Separate the cases by an empty line.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-layout-grid-align:none;
text-autospace:none'><br>
It is guaranteed that the first two parts of each case contain enough
information to uniquely decode any possible encoded text.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:windowtext'>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h1 align=left style='text-align:left'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:normal'>Sample
Input<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>                             </span><o:p></o:p></span></b></h1>

 style='background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:

font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-style:italic'>Output for Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:normal'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:Arial'>Problemsetter: </span></b><b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>Joachim

class=SpellE>Kisman</span>, EPS</span></b><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:Arial'>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<h2>EPILOGUE (Not required to solve the problem above)</h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>The plaintext for the second example is:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><i><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'>Cryptography is a very fascinating subject
and it has a rich history. If you are interested in the <span class=SpellE>Playfair</span>
ciphers and many more others, I can strongly recommend Simon <span
class=SpellE>Singhs</span> &quot;Code Book&quot; that contains all about the
secret history of codes and code breaking.</span></i><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:windowtext'><br>
<br>
The key was taken from Appendix E that contains the explanation of the <span
class=SpellE>Playfair</span> cipher.<br>
I owe my fascination for cryptography to Simon Singh. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<style>
<!--
 /* Font Definitions */

	{font-family:"Arial Unicode MS";
	panose-1:2 11 6 4 2 2 2 2 2 4;
	mso-font-charset:128;
	mso-generic-font-family:swiss;
	mso-font-pitch:variable;
	mso-font-signature:-1 -369098753 63 0 4129279 0;}

	{font-family:"\@Arial Unicode MS";
	panose-1:2 11 6 4 2 2 2 2 2 4;
	mso-font-charset:128;
	mso-generic-font-family:swiss;
	mso-font-pitch:variable;
	mso-font-signature:-1 -369098753 63 0 4129279 0;}

<!--[if gte mso 10]>
<style>
 /* Style Definitions */
 table.MsoNormalTable
	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";
	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;
	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;
	mso-style-noshow:yes;
	mso-style-parent:" ;
	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
	mso-para-margin:0in;
	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;

	mso-fareast-language:#0400;
	mso-bidi-language:#0400;}
</style>

 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="6146"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->
</head>

<body lang=EN-US link="#6633CC" vlink=purple style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:
Arial'>Problem H</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial'><br>
</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Prime Suspect<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Input: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Output: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;color:windowtext'>Let's
define the function <span class=GramE><i>Suspect(</i></span><i>b, n)</i>, where
<i>b</i> is an integer that is called the base, and <i>n</i> is an odd integer.
It returns one of the <span class=SpellE><span class=GramE>boolean</span></span>
values TRUE or FALSE. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<ul type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>Let <i>t</i>
     be the highest power of 2 so that 2<i><sup>t</sup></i> <span class=SpellE>devides</span>
     <i>n</i>-1 and <i>u</i> <span class=GramE>be</span> the biggest odd
     integer that <span class=SpellE>devides</span> <i>n</i>-1.<br>
     This means we can write <i>n</i>-1 = 2<i><sup>t</sup>u</i>. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>Let <i>x</i><sub>0</sub>
     be <span class=SpellE><i>b<sup>u</sup></i></span> mod <i>n</i>. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>For all <span
     class=SpellE><i>i</i></span> from 1 to <i>t</i>, let <i>x<sub>i</sub></i>
     be (<i>x<sub>i</sub></i><sub>-1</sub>)<sup>2</sup> mod <i>n</i>. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>If, for any <span
     class=SpellE><i>i</i></span> from 1 to <i>t</i>, <i>x<sub>i</sub></i> = 1
     and <i>x<sub>i</sub></i><sub>-1</sub> &lt;&gt; 1 and <i>x<sub>i</sub></i><sub>-1</sub>
     &lt;&gt; <i>n</i>-1, then return FALSE. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span class=GramE><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
     12.0pt'>else</span></span><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>, if <span
     class=SpellE><i>x<sub>t</sub></i></span> &lt;&gt; 1, then return FALSE. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='color:windowtext;mso-margin-top-alt:auto;
     mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'><span class=GramE><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
     12.0pt'>else</span></span><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'> return
     TRUE. <o:p></o:p></span></li>
</ul>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;color:windowtext'>The
<span class=SpellE>connaisseur</span> will recognize this function as the
essential part of the Miller-Rabin <span class=SpellE>primality</span> test,
although it can appear in different forms throughout the literature. In <span
class=SpellE><i>Cormen</i></span><i> <span class=GramE>et</span>. <span
class=GramE>al</span>.</i> Ch. 31 this function is called <i>Witness</i> and
returns the opposite <span class=SpellE>boolean</span> value.<br>
We will call the odd number <i>n</i> <b>suspect in base <i>b</i></b> if the above
function returns TRUE. At the end of this description three examples are given.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;color:windowtext'>It
can be proved that whenever the function <span class=GramE><i>Suspect(</i></span><i>b,
n)</i> returns FALSE for some base <i>b</i> and an odd number <i>n</i> it is <b>sure</b>
that <i>n</i> is not a prime number. The reverse, however, is not the case:
whenever <span class=GramE><i>Suspect(</i></span><i>b, n)</i> returns TRUE,
there is a high probability that <i>n</i> is a prime number, but we can't be
sure. We say that <span class=GramE><i>Suspect(</i></span><i>b, n)</i> <b>fails</b>
if it returns TRUE for an <i>n</i> that is not a prime number.<br>
<span class=SpellE>Upto</span> 1000000 there <span class=GramE>are</span> only
46 failures in base 2, the first three being 2047, 3277 and 4033. In base 3
there are 73 <span class=SpellE>falures</span>, but all of them are different
from the base 2 failures, so for every odd number <i>n</i> &lt; 1000000 we have
that if <i>Suspect(2, n)</i> and <i>Suspect(3, n)</i> we can be sure that <i>n</i>
is a prime number.<br>
<span class=SpellE>Upto</span> 2<sup>32</sup> we only need to <span
class=SpellE>calulate</span> three bases: <span class=GramE><i>Suspect(</i></span><i>2,
n)</i>, <i>Suspect(7, n)</i> and <i>Suspect(61, n)</i>. If all three function
calls return TRUE, it's sure that <i>n</i> is a prime number. This gives us a
very quick <span class=SpellE>primality</span> test for all numbers within the range
of current day integers. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;color:windowtext'>In
this problem we want you to calculate the failures of the function <span
class=GramE><i>Suspect(</i></span><i>b, n)</i> in a certain base and for a
certain range of numbers <i>n. </i><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h5 style='text-align:justify'><span class=StyleArial16pt><span
style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Input</span></span><span
class=StyleArial16pt><span style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Arial Unicode MS"'><o:p></o:p></span></span></h5>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The input consists of several
lines, each containing three integers: <i>Base</i>, <i>Min</i> and <i>Max</i>. <i>Base</i>
is an integer between 2 and 1024 (inclusive)<span class=GramE>,</span> <i>Min</i>
and <i>Max</i> will be between 3 and 4294967295 (inclusive). <i>Max</i> will
not be smaller than <i>Min</i>. <i>Max</i> will be at most 100000 bigger than <i>Min</i>.<br>
A line with three zeroes marks the end of the input; this line should not be
processed.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h4 style='text-align:justify'><span class=StyleArial16pt><span
style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Output
</span></span><span class=StyleArial16pt><span style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></span></h4>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'>For each line
of input, one line of output: &quot;There are NUMBER1 odd non-prime numbers
between NUMBER2 and NUMBER3.<span class=GramE>&quot;.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'>If there are
odd numbers within this range that fail as suspects in the given base, output an
other line: &quot;NUMBER4 suspects fail in base NUMBER5:<span class=GramE>&quot;,</span>
followed by all failures, in ascending order, each on a line by itself. Use the
plural form, even if there is only one failure. <br>
If there are no failures in this range, output the line: &quot;There are no
failures in base NUMBER5.<span class=GramE>&quot;.</span><br>
<span class=GramE>NUMBER1 ..</span> NUMBER5 are to be replaced by the
appropriate values.<br>
Separate the cases by a blank line.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h1><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:
Arial;font-style:normal'>Sample Input<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>                               </span>Output for
Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></h1>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=834
 style='width:6.95in;background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;
 mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=234 valign=top style='width:1.95in;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>186 800000 900000<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>2 4000000000 4000001000<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>3 121 <span class=SpellE>121</span><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <pre style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:8.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>0 <span
  class=SpellE>0</span> <span class=SpellE>0</span></span></b><b><span
  style='font-size:8.0pt'><o:p></o:p></span></b></pre></td>
  <td width=600 valign=top style='width:5.0in;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>There are 42677 odd non-prime numbers between
  800000 and 900000.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>4 suspects fail in base 186:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>821059<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>840781<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>873181<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>876961<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>There are 457 odd non-prime numbers between
  4000000000 and 4000001000.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>There are no failures in base 2.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>There are 1 odd non-prime numbers between 121
  and 121.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>1 suspects fail in base 3:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:
  "Courier New";color:windowtext'>121<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b><span
  style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:windowtext'>Problem setter: Little Joey
(Joachim)<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:windowtext'>Be Ware! This problem has no
alternate solution<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p><i>Suspect(2, 121)</i>:<br>
<i>n</i>-1 = 120 = 8 * 15 = 2<sup>3</sup> * 15, therefore <i>t</i>=3, <i>u</i>=15<br>
<i>x</i><sub>0</sub> = 2<sup>15</sup> mod 121 = 32768 mod 121 = 98<br>
<i>x</i><sub>1</sub> = 98<sup>2</sup> mod 121 = 9604 mod 121 = 45<br>
<i>x</i><sub>2</sub> = 45<sup>2</sup> mod 121 = 2025 mod 121 = 89<br>
<i>x</i><sub>3</sub> = 89<sup>2</sup> mod 121 = 7921 mod 121 = 56<br>
None of the <i>x<sub>i</sub></i> is 1, so the loop test continues until the
end. Since <span class=SpellE><i>x<sub>t</sub></i></span> is not 1, the
function will return FALSE. This is a correct result, since 121 = 11*11 is
composite. </p>

<p><i>Suspect(3, 121)</i>:<br>
<i>n</i>-1 = 120 = 8 * 15 = 2<sup>3</sup> * 15, therefore <i>t</i>=3, <i>u</i>=15<br>
<i>x</i><sub>0</sub> = 3<sup>15</sup> mod 121 = 14348907 mod 121 = 1<br>
<i>x</i><sub>1</sub> = 1<sup>2</sup> mod 121 = 1 mod 121 = 1<br>
<i>x</i><sub>2</sub> = 1<sup>2</sup> mod 121 = 1 mod 121 = 1<br>
<i>x</i><sub>3</sub> = 1<sup>2</sup> mod 121 = 1 mod 121 = 1<br>
All of the <i>x<sub>i</sub></i> are 1, so the loop test continues until the
end. Since <span class=SpellE><i>x<sub>t</sub></i></span> is 1, the function
will return TRUE. This is a failure<span class=GramE>!.</span> </p>

<p><i>Suspect(3, 89)</i>:<br>
<i>n</i>-1 = 88 = 8 * 11 = 2<sup>3</sup> * 11, therefore <i>t</i>=3, <i>u</i>=11<br>
<i>x</i><sub>0</sub> = 3<sup>11</sup> mod 89 = 177147 mod 89 = 37<br>
<i>x</i><sub>1</sub> = 37<sup>2</sup> mod 89 = 1369 mod 89 = 34<br>
<i>x</i><sub>2</sub> = 34<sup>2</sup> mod 89 = 1156 mod 89 = 88<br>
<i>x</i><sub>3</sub> = 88<sup>2</sup> mod 89 = 1 mod 89 = 1<br>
Here we see the loop test again continue to the end. Since <span class=SpellE><i>x<sub>t</sub></i></span>
is 1, the function will return TRUE. This is correct, because 89 is a prime
number. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:windowtext'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

</div>

</body>

</html>

@list l1:level1
	{mso-level-number-format:bullet;
	mso-level-text:\F0B7;
	mso-level-tab-stop:.5in;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	text-indent:-.25in;
	mso-ansi-font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:Symbol;}

</style>
<!--[if gte mso 10]>
<style>
 /* Style Definitions */
 table.MsoNormalTable
	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";
	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;
	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;
	mso-style-noshow:yes;
	mso-style-parent:" ;
	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
	mso-para-margin:0in;
	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-ansi-language:#0400;
	mso-fareast-language:#0400;
	mso-bidi-language:#0400;}
</style>
<![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="4098"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->
</head>

<body lang=EN-US link="#6633CC" vlink=purple style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:
Arial'>Problem H</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial'><br>
</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'>So <span class=SpellE>Doku</span>
Checker<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Input: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Output: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Output <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>The best logical puzzles often are puzzles that
are based on a simple idea. So Doku is one such type of puzzle. Although So
Dokus have been around for some twenty years, in the last few years they
conquered the world exponentially. Hundreds of newspapers and websites are now
publishing them on a daily basis. For those of you unfamiliar with these
puzzles, let me give a brief introduction.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><img width=365
height=365 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10957.jpg" ></p>

<p>The picture above contains an example of a Su <span class=SpellE>Doku</span>
puzzle. As you can see, we have a 9X9 grid filled with single digits from 1 to
9 and empty places. The grid is further divided into nine 3X3 sub-grids,
indicated by the thick lines. To solve the puzzle you have to fill the empty
places with digits according to the following rules:</p>

<ul type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     mso-list:l0 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:list .5in'>Every row should contain the
     digits 1 to 9 exactly once; </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     mso-list:l0 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:list .5in'>Every column should contain
     the digits 1 to 9 exactly once; </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     mso-list:l0 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:list .5in'>Every 3X3 sub-grid should
     contain the digits 1 to 9 exactly once. </li>
</ul>

<p>A well formed Su <span class=SpellE>Doku</span> can be solved with paper and
pencil using logical deduction only. To be well formed it should be legal (no
row, column or sub-grid contains a digit more than once), solvable (the empty
places can all be filled while respecting the rules) and unique (there is only
one solution). This is what your program is going to check.</p>

<h5><span class=StyleArial16pt><span style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
10.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Input</span></span><span
class=StyleArial16pt><span style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Arial Unicode MS"'><o:p></o:p></span></span></h5>

<p style='text-align:justify'>The input contains several (partially) filled
grids, each representing a Su <span class=SpellE>Doku</span> puzzle. For every
puzzle there are 9 lines with 9 digits giving the puzzle in row major order.
Empty places in the puzzle are represented by the digit 0 (zero). Digits on a
line are separated by one space. The grids are separated by one empty line.</p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>The first grid in the sample input represents the
puzzle given in the picture.</p>

<h4><span class=StyleArial16pt><span style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
10.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Output </span></span><span
class=StyleArial16pt><span style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></span></h4>

<p style='text-align:justify'>For every grid in the input, determine one of the
following four verdicts: </p>

<ul type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     text-align:justify;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo6;tab-stops:list .5in'>&quot;Illegal&quot;
     if the puzzle violates one of the three rules; </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     text-align:justify;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo6;tab-stops:list .5in'>&quot;Unique&quot;
     if only one solution exists; </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     text-align:justify;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo6;tab-stops:list .5in'>&quot;Ambiguous&quot;
     if more than one solution exists; </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     text-align:justify;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo6;tab-stops:list .5in'>&quot;Impossible&quot;
     if no solution exists; </li>
</ul>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Print one line per grid, in the <span
class=SpellE>format:&quot;Case</span> &lt;N<span class=GramE>&gt;:</span>
&lt;VERDICT&gt;.&quot;, where N is the case number, starting from 1, and
VERDICT is one of the four words in the list. See the sample output for the
exact format.</p>

<p style='text-align:justify'><b>Note</b>: an &quot;Illegal&quot; puzzle is
also &quot;Impossible&quot;, of course, but your program should print
&quot;Illegal&quot; in that case. Only print &quot;Impossible&quot; if the
input doesn't violate one of the three rules, but the puzzle still can't be
solved.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h1 align=left style='text-align:left'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:normal'>Sample
Input<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>                              
</span>Output for Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></h1>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:
 solid windowtext .5pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=399 valign=top style='width:239.4pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'><pre><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>0 <span class=SpellE>0</span> 3 9 0 <span
  class=SpellE>0</span> 7 6 0<o:p></o:p></b></pre><pre><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:

  class=SpellE>0</span> 7<o:p></o:p></b></pre><pre><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:

  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>3 0 <span class=SpellE>0</span> 2 0 <span

  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>0 4 0 <span class=SpellE>0</span> <span

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Arial;
color:windowtext'>Problem setter: Little Joey (Joachim)<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Arial;
color:windowtext'>Special Thanks: Jimmy </span></b><b><span style='font-family:
Arial'>Mårdell, EPS </span></b><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:Arial;color:windowtext'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Arial;
color:windowtext'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<h2>Epilogue (not required to solve the problem)</h2>

<p>The (unique) solution to the given puzzle is:</p>

<pre><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></pre><pre>1 5 3 9 8 4 7 6 2</pre><pre>8 4 2 7 3 6 1 5 9</pre><pre>6 9 7 5 1 2 8 3 4</pre><pre>2 3 8 6 7 1 4 9 5</pre><pre>9 7 4 3 2 5 6 1 8</pre><pre>5 1 6 8 4 9 3 2 7</pre><pre>7 6 5 4 9 3 2 8 1</pre><pre>3 8 1 2 5 7 9 4 6</pre><pre>4 2 9 1 6 8 5 7 3</pre>

<p style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'>If
you are interested in the fascinating world of Su <span class=SpellE>Dokus</span>
and solving them by hand, Google is a good starting point. Also <span
class=SpellE>Wikipedia</span> has a nice entry on Su <span class=SpellE>Dokus</span>
describing their history and giving some mathematical background. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:windowtext'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

</div>

</body>

<title>Problem H - How Many Solutions?</title>

<body lang=EN-US link="#6633CC" vlink=purple style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:
Arial'>Problem J</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial'><br>
</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'>How Many Solutions?<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Input: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Output: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Output <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Time Limit: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>2 Second</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'>Given the
values of three <span class=GramE>integers</span> m, n, p how many integer solutions
does the following equation have?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:143.25pt'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype
 id="_x0000_t75" coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t"
 path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe" filled="f" stroked="f">
 <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
 <v:formulas>
  <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
 </v:formulas>
 <v:path o:extrusionok="f" gradientshapeok="t" o:connecttype="rect"/>
 <o:lock v:ext="edit" aspectratio="t"/>
</v:shapetype><v:shape id="_x0000_s1027" type="#_x0000_t75" style='position:absolute;
 margin-left:202.2pt;margin-top:0;width:75.6pt;height:43.2pt;z-index:1'>
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/j_files/image002.wmz"  o:title=" />
 <w:wrap type="square" side="right"/>
</v:shape><![if gte mso 9]><o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3"
 ShapeID="_x0000_s1027" DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192094380">
</o:OLEObject>
<![endif]><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=101 height=58
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/j_files/image002.wmz"  align=left hspace=12 v:shapes="_x0000_s1027"><![endif]><br
clear=all>
<span class=StyleArial16pt><span style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
10.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Input</span></span><span
class=StyleArial16pt><span style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Arial Unicode MS"'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<h4 style='text-align:justify'><span class=StyleArial16pt><span
style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";font-weight:
normal'>The input file contains at most </span></span><span
class=StyleArial16pt><span style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>1001</span></span><span class=StyleArial16pt><span
style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";font-weight:
normal'> sets of inputs. Each set of input is given in a single line containing
three integers which denotes the values of m, n and p respectively.<o:p></o:p></span></span></h4>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-fareast-font-family:
"Arial Unicode MS"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-fareast-font-family:
"Arial Unicode MS"'>Input is terminated by a case where the value of <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>m</b>, <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>n</b>
and <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>p (-1000 &#8804; m, n, p</b> <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>&#8804; 1000) </b>is zero.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h4><span class=StyleArial16pt><span style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
10.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Output </span></span><span
class=StyleArial16pt><span style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></span></h4>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'>For each set
of input produce one line of output which contains the serial of output
followed by an integer <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>N</b> which
indicates how many solutions are there for the given value of <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>m</b>, <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>n</b>
and <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>p</b>.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h1 align=left style='text-align:left'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;font-style:normal'>Sample
Input<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>                              
</span>Output for Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></h1>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:
 solid windowtext .5pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=392 valign=top style='width:234.9pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'><pre><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt'>1 2 4<o:p></o:p></span></b></pre><pre><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt'>2 3 4<o:p></o:p></span></b></pre><pre><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt'>0 <span class=SpellE>0</span> <span class=SpellE>0</span><o:p></o:p></span></b></pre></td>
  <td width=379 valign=top style='width:227.35pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;

  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Case 1: 11<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Case 2: 23<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Arial;
color:windowtext'>Problem setter: Shahriar Manzoor, EPS<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Arial;
color:windowtext'>Be ware!! This problem has no alternate solution.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Arial;
color:windowtext'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:windowtext'>Comment:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:Arial;color:windowtext'>The equation corresponding to the first
sample input is: <span style='position:relative;top:14.0pt;mso-text-raise:-14.0pt'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape
 id="_x0000_i1026" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:61.8pt;height:37.8pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/j_files/image002.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=82 height=50
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/j_files/image002.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1026"><![endif]></span><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1026"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192094381">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>and the 11 solutions
corresponding to this equation is:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial;color:windowtext'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:windowtext'>-28 7<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span

<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN">
<!-- saved from url=(0063)http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/node2.html -->
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1-h (September 30, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds --><HTML><HEAD><TITLE>Problem B: The Party, Part I</TITLE>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<META content="The Party, Part I" name=description>
<META content=main name=keywords>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution><LINK href="b_files/main.css" 
rel=STYLESHEET>
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2600.0" name=GENERATOR></HEAD>
<BODY lang=EN>
<H1><A name=SECTION00020000000000000000>Problem B: The Party, Part I</A></H1>
<P>Don Giovanni likes to dance--especially with girls! And everyone else in the 
party enjoyed the dance, too. Getting a chance to dance with the host (that is 
Don Giovanni) is the greatest honour; failing that, dancing with someone who has 
danced with the host or will dance with the host is the second greatest honour. 
This can go further. Define the Giovanni number of a person as follows, at the 
time after the party is over and therefore who has danced with whom is 
completely known and fixed: 
<OL>
  <LI>No one has a negative Giovanni number. 
  <LI>The Giovanni number of Don Giovanni is 0. 
  <LI>If a person <I>p</I> is not Don Giovanni himself, and has danced with 
  someone with Giovanni number <I>n</I>, and has not danced with anyone with a 
  Giovanni number smaller than <I>n</I>, then <I>p</I> has Giovanni number 
  <I>n</I>+1. 
  <LI>If a person's Giovanni number cannot be determined from the above rules 
  (he/she has not danced with anyone with a finite Giovanni number), his/her 
  Giovanni number is <IMG height=8 alt=tex2html_wrap_inline98 
  src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10959a.gif"  width=15 align=bottom>. Fortunately, you will not need 
  this rule in this problem. </LI></OL>Your job is to write a program to compute 
Giovanni numbers. 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00021000000000000000>Input</A></H2>
<b>
The input begins with a single positive integer on a line by itself indicating
the number of the cases following, each of them as described below.
This line is followed by a blank line, and there is also a blank line between
two consecutive inputs.
</b>
<p>
<p>
<P>The first line has two numbers <I>P</I> and <I>D</I>; this means there are 
<I>P</I> persons in the party (including Don Giovanni) and <I>D</I> dancing 
couples (P &le; 1000
<!--IMG height=26 alt=tex2html_wrap_inline108 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10959a.gif"  
width=63 align=middle--> and <IMG height=29 alt=tex2html_wrap_inline110 
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10959a.gif"  width=129 align=middle>.) Then <I>D</I> lines follow, 
each containing two distinct persons, meaning the two persons has danced. 
Persons are represented by numbers between 0 and <I>P</I>-1; Don Giovanni is 
represented by 0. 
<P>As noted, we design the input so that you will not need the <IMG height=8 
alt=tex2html_wrap_inline98 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10959a.gif"  width=15 align=bottom> rule in 
computing Giovanni numbers. 
<P>We have made our best effort to eliminate duplications in listing the dancing 
couples, e.g., if there is a line ``4 7'' among the <I>D</I> lines, then this is 
the only occurrence of ``4 7'', and there is no occurrence of ``7 4''. But just 
in case you see a duplication, you can ignore it (the duplication, not the first 
occurrence). 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00022000000000000000>Output</A></H2>
<b>
For each test case, the output must follow the description below.
The outputs of two consecutive cases will be separated by a blank line.
</b>
<p>
<p>
<P>Output <I>P</I>-1 lines. Line <I>i</I> is the Giovanni number of person 
<I>i</I>, for <IMG height=26 alt=tex2html_wrap_inline126 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10959a.gif"  
width=106 align=middle>. Note that it is <I>P</I>-1 because we skip Don Giovanni 
in the output. 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00023000000000000000>Sample Input</A></H2>
<P><PRE>
1

5 6
0 1
0 2
3 2
2 4
4 3
1 2
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00024000000000000000>Sample Output</A></H2>
<P><PRE>
1
1
2
2
</PRE>
<P><BR>

Input 1</A>/<A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/dance.1.out">Test

<!-- saved from url=(0063)http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/node3.html -->
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1-h (September 30, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds --><HTML><HEAD><TITLE>Problem C: The Party, Part II</TITLE>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<META content="The Party, Part II" name=description>
<META content=main name=keywords>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution><LINK href="c_files/main.css" 
rel=STYLESHEET>
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2600.0" name=GENERATOR></HEAD>
<BODY lang=EN>
<H1><A name=SECTION00030000000000000000>Problem C: The Party, Part II</A></H1>
<P>In the middle of the party, Donna Anna, Donna Elvira, and Don Ottavio arrive 
masked, and intent to confront Don Giovanni when they find him. You, as a guest 
of the party, know what they want to do. You want to stay out of trouble, so you 
would like to keep away from them. But they mask themselves along with other 
guests, and you have trouble identifying them. Fortunately, you have collected a 
set of clues from other guests. You have to analyse them and find out who is 
who. 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00031000000000000000>Input</A></H2>
<b>
The input begins with a single positive integer on a line by itself indicating
the number of the cases following, each of them as described below.
This line is followed by a blank line, and there is also a blank line between
two consecutive inputs.
</b>
<p>
<p>
 
<P>The input starts with a line with 4 positive numbers, <I>n</I>, <I>i</I>, 
<I>c</I>, and <I>u</I>, separated by a space. <I>n</I> is the number of people 
in the set of clues, <I>i</I> is the number of items (such as shoes, masks, 
clothes, etc.) that can be identified by colours, <I>c</I> is the number of 
possible colours. 
<P>The rest of input consists of <I>u</I> lines of clues. There are three types 
of clues: 
<OL>
  <LI><TT>Same colour of item</TT> <I>X</I> <TT>=</TT> <IMG height=27 
  alt=tex2html_wrap_inline148 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10960a.gif"  width=145 align=middle> 
  <LI><TT>Colour</TT> <I>Y</I> <TT>for item</TT> <I>X</I> <TT>=</TT> <IMG 
  height=27 alt=tex2html_wrap_inline148 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10960a.gif"  width=145 
  align=middle> 
  <LI><TT>Not colour</TT> <I>Y</I> <TT>for item</TT> <I>X</I> <TT>=</TT> <IMG 
  height=27 alt=tex2html_wrap_inline148 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10960a.gif"  width=145 
  align=middle></LI></OL>
<P>The first clue means that the listed people have the same colour for item 
<I>X</I>; the second clue means that colour of item <I>X</I> for the listed 
people is <I>Y</I>; the last clue means that the colour of item <I>X</I> for the 
listed people is not <I>Y</I>. 
<P><I>X</I> is a number from 0 to <I>i</I>-1 inclusive, indicating the item 
number. <I>Y</I> is a number from 0 to <I>c</I>-1 inclusive, indicating the 
colour number. <IMG height=27 alt=tex2html_wrap_inline148 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10960a.gif"  
width=145 align=middle> is a list of capital letters in alphabetical order, 
indicating the list of people that belongs to that clue. All words/letters in a 
line are separated by a space. 
<P>There are at most 26 people (from A to Z), 10 items and 10 colours (from 0 to 
9). 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00032000000000000000>Output</A></H2>
<b>
For each test case, the output must follow the description below.
The outputs of two consecutive cases will be separated by a blank line.
</b>
<p>
<p>

<P>If the clues are inconsistent, or there is a contradiction, then output the 
line ``Contradiction'', otherwise output <I>n</I> lines, indicating the <I>n</I> 
people, in alphabetical order, the colour of their items in increasing order: 
<BR><IMG height=16 alt=displaymath182 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10960a.gif"  width=320 
align=bottom><BR>for the person represented by letter <I>P</I>, where the colour 
number of item 0 is <IMG height=27 alt=tex2html_wrap_inline190 
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10960a.gif"  width=18 align=middle>, the colour number of item 1 is 
<IMG height=27 alt=tex2html_wrap_inline192 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10960a.gif"  width=17 
align=middle>, etc., all separated by a space. If the colour of an item cannot 
be determined, output ``?'' for the colour number. 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00033000000000000000>Sample Input</A></H2>
<P><PRE>
2

4 2 3 6
Same colour of item 0 = A B D
Colour 2 for item 0 = B
Not colour 2 for item 1 = C
Not colour 1 for item 1 = C
Same colour of item 1 = C D
Same colour of item 1 = A D

4 2 3 7
Same colour of item 0 = A B D
Colour 2 for item 0 = B
Not colour 2 for item 1 = C
Not colour 1 for item 1 = C
Same colour of item 1 = C D
Same colour of item 1 = A D
Colour 1 for item 0 = D
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00034000000000000000>Sample Output</A></H2>
<P><PRE>
A 2 0
B 2 ?
C ? 0
D 2 0

Contradiction
</PRE>

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1-h (September 30, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds --><HTML><HEAD><TITLE>Problem D: Chasing After Don Giovanni</TITLE>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<META content="Chasing After Don Giovanni" name=description>
<META content=main name=keywords>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution><LINK href="d_files/main.css" 
rel=STYLESHEET>
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2600.0" name=GENERATOR></HEAD>
<BODY lang=EN>
<H1><A name=SECTION00040000000000000000>Problem D: Chasing After Don Giovanni</A></H1>
<P>In Act II, Masetto is leading a group of villagers to chase after Don 
Giovanni. Giovanni, who has just exchanged his clothes with Leporello and is 
disguising as him, is asked by Masetto about where ``his master'' has gone. To 
avoid trouble, ``Leporello'' (disguised by Giovanni) wants to mislead the 
villagers so that they cannot find ``Don Giovanni'' (disguised by Leporello). 
Giovanni knows the route that Leporello is taking, and he has a safe route (a 
route that the villagers would not meet Leporello) in mind. He wants to make 
sure that the route he has is safe indeed. 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00041000000000000000>Input</A></H2>
<b>
The input begins with a single positive integer on a line by itself indicating
the number of the cases following, each of them as described below.
This line is followed by a blank line, and there is also a blank line between
two consecutive inputs.
</b>
<p>
<p>
 
<P>You are given the current location of Don Giovanni (which is also the 
location of Masetto and the villagers), and the current location of Leporello, 
in two separate lines. Each line has two numbers: the Street number and the 
Avenue number. You can assume that the roads are regular square grids, with rows 
as streets numbered from one starting from the northmost, and columns as avenues 
numbered from one starting from the westmost. Therefore the distance between 
adjacent streets and avenues is always the same. 
<P>The rest of the input has two sets of routes, with the first set being 
Leporello's and the second being the route that Giovanni is going to tell the 
others. Each set starts with a number indicating the number of stops in the 
route, followed by the list of stops. Each stop is specified as a location, 
where Leporello may change direction. Between stops there is always a straight 
line in the direction of parallel to either streets or avenues, which Leporello 
and the villagers are going to travel. 
<P>Leporello travels in the same speed as the villagers. You may assume the 
maximum street/avenue number is 1000000, and there are at most 100 stops. 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00042000000000000000>Output</A></H2>
<b>
For each test case, the output must follow the description below.
The outputs of two consecutive cases will be separated by a blank line.
</b>
<p>
<p>

<P>The output consists of a line saying ``Yes'' or ``No'', indicating whether 
the route that Giovanni is telling the villagers is a safe route. Remember that 
a route is not safe only if the villagers can meet Leporello in the same place 
at the same time; a route is safe even if the villagers meet Leporello at the 
destination (because his mission is accomplished). 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00043000000000000000>Sample Input</A></H2>
<P><PRE>
2

2 3
5 2
3
5 4
3 4
3 6
4
4 3
4 5
5 5
5 6

2 2
4 2
3
6 2
6 3
3 3
3
2 4
5 4
5 6
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00044000000000000000>Sample Output</A></H2>
<P><PRE>
No

Yes
</PRE>

href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/chasing.8.in">Test

Output 8</A><BR><A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/chasing.8b.in">Test 
Input 8b</A>/<A

Output 8b</A><BR><A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/chasing.9.in">Test

10962||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN">
<!-- saved from url=(0063)http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/node5.html -->

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1-h (September 30, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds --><HTML><HEAD><TITLE>Problem E: Don Giovanni's Last Dinner</TITLE>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<META content="Don Giovanni's Last Dinner" name=description>
<META content=main name=keywords>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution><LINK href="e_files/main.css" 
rel=STYLESHEET>
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2600.0" name=GENERATOR></HEAD>
<BODY lang=EN>
<H1><A name=SECTION00050000000000000000>Problem E: Don Giovanni's Last Dinner</A></H1>
<P>Don Giovanni eats large dishes--a lot of them. Leporello cannot help but 
drool over. Whenever Don Giovanni gives up a dish, Leporello has a chance: he 
can have what remains on the dish behind the back of the master, and surely he 
starts consuming it immediately. But he is a servant, and he has to answer to 
demands from his master. It is going to be embarrassing if he is mouthful when 
the master asks him questions. 
<P>Write a program to determine if Leporello is mouthful every time Don Giovanni 
calls him. 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00051000000000000000>Input</A></H2>
<b>
The input begins with a single positive integer on a line by itself indicating
the number of the cases following, each of them as described below.
This line is followed by a blank line, and there is also a blank line between
two consecutive inputs.
</b>
<p>
<p>
 
<P>The first line of the input contains Don Giovanni's eating rate <I>R</I>, 
Leporello's eating rate <I>r</I>, the number of dishes <I>N</I>, and the number 
of calls <I>C</I>. 
<P>Then there are <I>N</I> lines, each for a dish. Each line contains two 
numbers <I>s</I> and <I>g</I> with <I>s</I> &gt; <I>g</I> &gt; 0: <I>s</I> is 
the amount of food on the dish, and <I>g</I> is the amount Don Giovanni 
consumes. Don Giovanni will eat the dishes sequentially in the same order given 
by these <I>n</I> lines. As soon as Don Giovanni stops eating a dish, it is 
handed to Leporello, and Don Giovanni starts the next dish right away. Leporello 
eats as long as (and as soon as) there is food for him, and if you want to know, 
he eats the dishes sequentially in the same order too. 
<P>Then there are <I>C</I> lines, each for a call. Each line contains a number 
<I>t</I> for a time when Don Giovanni calls Leporello. (Amazingly, these calls 
do not slow down Don Giovanni's eating.) The sequence of call times is 
increasing. 
<P>All input numbers are positive integers and at most 2000. 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00052000000000000000>Output</A></H2>
<b>
For each test case, the output must follow the description below.
The outputs of two consecutive cases will be separated by a blank line.
</b>
<p>
<p>

<P>For each call, output a line <PRE>full</PRE>if Leporello is eating at the time of the call, and <PRE>clear</PRE>otherwise. 
<P>Boundary case: What if Leporello is just about to start or stop eating at a 
call time? E.g., he receives food at 20, he finishes eating at 40, and at both 
times he gets called. In both cases, answer ``full''. (This also nicely handles 
the case when he finishes a dish at 35, he receives another dish at 35, and he 
gets called at 35.) 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00053000000000000000>Sample Input</A></H2>
<P><PRE>
1

10 7 5 4
60 30
150 125
55 35
70 40
42 38
2
10
19
23
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00054000000000000000>Sample Output</A></H2>
<P><PRE>
clear
clear
full
full
</PRE>
<P><BR>
<!--HR>
<A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/Dinner.hs">Solution 
in Haskell</A> (not used in contest)<BR><A

10963||||||false||||||

<!-- saved from url=(0063)http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/node6.html -->
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1-h (September 30, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds --><HTML><HEAD><TITLE>Problem F: The Swallowing Ground</TITLE>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">
<META content="The Swallowing Ground" name=description>
<META content=main name=keywords>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution><LINK href="f_files/main.css" 
rel=STYLESHEET>
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2600.0" name=GENERATOR></HEAD>
<BODY lang=EN>
<H1><A name=SECTION00060000000000000000>Problem F: The Swallowing Ground</A></H1>
<P>Now that the wicked is punished, there is still work to do. For example, the 
ground needs to seal itself up. (Otherwise, good people will accidentally fall 
into Hell, which is not good.) 
<P>The ground swallowed Don Giovanni by collapsing: Part of the ground 
collapsed--fell off to Hell--and this created a gap that swallowed Don Giovanni. 
The only way the ground can be fixed is by sliding landmasses to close up the 
gap. Here is an example. The left diagram shows the ground with a ravine. Assume 
that the ground extends infinitely to the north and to the south, and there are 
seams on the east and west ends; so the northern block can slide southward, and 
the southern block can slide northward. The right diagram shows the gap closed. 
<DIV align=center>
<P align=center><IMG height=112 alt=tex2html_wrap220 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10963a.gif"  
width=243 align=bottom></P></DIV>Here is another example. The ravine in the left 
diagram cannot be closed perfectly by sliding the ground northward and 
southward. The right diagram shows the result of the best effort: there is still 
a hole. 
<DIV align=center>
<P align=center><IMG height=112 alt=tex2html_wrap222 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10963a.gif"  
width=243 align=bottom></P></DIV>
<P>Write a program to determine if the gap can be closed. The ground is a grid 
with rows (a row runs east-west) and columns (a column runs north-south). Holes 
are cells on the grid, and the gap consists of holes. 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00061000000000000000>Input</A></H2>
<b>
The input begins with a single positive integer on a line by itself indicating
the number of the cases following, each of them as described below.
This line is followed by a blank line, and there is also a blank line between
two consecutive inputs.
</b>
<p>
<p>

<P>The first line contains the number of columns <I>W</I> of the ground to be 
considered. Then <I>W</I> lines follow, specifying the boundary of the gap by 
columns: a line represents a column, and the order of the lines follows the 
east-to-west order. Each line contains <IMG height=17 
alt=tex2html_wrap_inline228 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10963a.gif"  width=13 align=middle>, the 
north-most row of the gap in this column, and <IMG height=17 
alt=tex2html_wrap_inline230 src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10963a.gif"  width=13 align=middle>, the 
south-most row of the gap in this column. Row numbers are integers between -100 
and 100 inclusive. 
<P>The input specifies a valid gap: the holes separate the ground into exactly a 
northern block and a southern block. There are no holes embedded inside a block. 
There are no islands.

<P>
<b>Note:</b>The sample input below corresponds to the first diagram. 

<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00062000000000000000>Output</A></H2>
<b>
For each test case, the output must follow the description below.
The outputs of two consecutive cases will be separated by a blank line.
</b>
<p>
<p>

<P>Output the line <PRE>yes</PRE>if the gap can be closed by sliding blocks north and south; and <PRE>no</PRE>otherwise. 
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00063000000000000000>Sample Input</A></H2>
<PRE>
1

5
2 1
0 -1
1 0
1 0
2 1
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><A name=SECTION00064000000000000000>Sample Output</A></H2>
<P><PRE>
yes
</PRE>
<P><BR>
<!--HR>
<A href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.c">Solution 
in C</A><BR><A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.java">Solution 
in Java</A><BR><A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.0.in">Test 
Input 0</A>/<A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.0.out">Test 
Output 0</A><BR><A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.1.in">Test 
Input 1</A>/<A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.1.out">Test 
Output 1</A><BR><A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.2.in">Test 
Input 2</A>/<A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.2.out">Test 
Output 2</A><BR><A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.3.in">Test 
Input 3</A>/<A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.3.out">Test 
Output 3</A><BR><A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.4.in">Test 
Input 4</A>/<A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.4.out">Test 
Output 4</A><BR><A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.5.in">Test 
Input 5</A>/<A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.5.out">Test 
Output 5</A><BR><A 
href="http://www.cs.queensu.ca/~acmteam/qipc/2002/problems/ground.6.in">Test
