 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="2050"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->
</head>

<body lang=EN-US vlink=purple style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in'><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt'>Problem J<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;
margin-bottom:6.0pt;margin-left:0in;text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:14.0pt'>Triangle Counting<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>Having
a simple undirected <span class=GramE>graph </span><sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype
 id="_x0000_t75" coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t"
 path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe" filled="f" stroked="f">
 <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
 <v:formulas>
  <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
 </v:formulas>
 <v:path o:extrusionok="f" gradientshapeok="t" o:connecttype="rect"/>
 <o:lock v:ext="edit" aspectratio="t"/>
</v:shapetype><v:shape id="_x0000_i1025" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:45.75pt;
 height:15pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=61 height=20
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1025"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1025"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912655">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]-->, a triangle is defined as a triple <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape
 id="_x0000_i1026" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:45.75pt;height:15pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=61 height=20
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1026"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1026"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912656">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>where <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape
 id="_x0000_i1027" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:54.75pt;height:15pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=73 height=20
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1027"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1027"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912657">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>and <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape
 id="_x0000_i1028" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:48.75pt;height:17.25pt'
 o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=65 height=23
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1028"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1028"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912658">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>for all <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape
 id="_x0000_i1029" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:42pt;height:14.25pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=56 height=19
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1029"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1029"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912659">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>and <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape
 id="_x0000_i1030" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:23.25pt;height:14.25pt'
 o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=31 height=19
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1030"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1030"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912660">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]-->. In this problem, you are given an undirected graph and
asked to count all the triangles in this graph. You are assured that there is
no edge in this graph that is the member of more than 2 triangles.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b>The Input <o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>The
first line of input contains an <span class=GramE>integer </span><sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape
 id="_x0000_i1031" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:36pt;height:12pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=48 height=16
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1031"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1031"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912661">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]-->, which is the number of test cases. Each test case begins
with a line containing two integers <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape id="_x0000_i1032"
 type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:53.25pt;height:12pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=71 height=16
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1032"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1032"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912662">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]-->and <i>m</i> which are the number of vertices and the number
of edges in the graph respectively. The next <i>m</i> lines contain two
integers <sub><span style='position:relative;top:5.0pt;mso-text-raise:-5.0pt'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape
 id="_x0000_i1035" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:59.25pt;height:14.25pt'
 o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=79 height=19
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1035"><![endif]></span></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1035"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912663">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>indicating that there
is an edge between vertex <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape id="_x0000_i1033"
 type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:6.75pt;height:12pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=9 height=16
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1033"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1033"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912664">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>and <span class=GramE>vertex
</span><sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape id="_x0000_i1034" type="#_x0000_t75"
 style='width:9pt;height:14.25pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=12 height=19
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p9_files/image001.wmz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1034"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1034"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912665">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]-->. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>Tip
for C++ Programmers:</span></b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'> Any attempt to
use </span><span class=SpellE><b><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:
"Courier New"'>ifstream</span></b></span><span style='font-size:10.0pt'> to
read the input will exceed the time limit for this problem. Use </span><span
class=SpellE><b><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>scanf</span></b></span><span
style='font-size:10.0pt'> instead.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b>The Output <o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>Output
for each test case consists of one line containing the number of triangles in
the specified graph of the test case.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>1<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>4 6<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>1 2<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>2 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>3 1<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>1 4<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>2 4<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>3 4<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>4<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

</div>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='color:black'>
Amirkabir University of Technology - Local Contest - Round #2
</span></b><span
style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

</body>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in'><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt'>Problem K<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;
margin-bottom:6.0pt;margin-left:0in;text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:14.0pt'>The Ridiculous Game<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>Mohammad
likes playing with scissors and papers. Recently, he has found a ridiculous
geometric game in one of the ancient books of the Barareh city. He should start
with a simple polygon paper and cut it with scissors along a specified
direction. Finally, he should specify the shape of the resulted pieces of
papers. The polygon shown in figure 1 is a polygon which is cut into 4 pieces. But,
Mohammad thinks that this game is very ridiculous and boring, as after cutting
the paper, you can see the resulted pieces!!! Therefore, he decided to make it a
little bit amazing. Now, he wants to write a computer program to find the shape
of the resulted pieces without actually cutting the paper. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>After
reading previous problems, you probably know that Mohammad is very lazy and he
needs your help to accomplish this task.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
style='font-size:10.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
style='font-size:10.0pt'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype id="_x0000_t75"
 coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t" path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe"
 filled="f" stroked="f">
 <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
 <v:formulas>
  <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
 </v:formulas>
 <v:path o:extrusionok="f" gradientshapeok="t" o:connecttype="rect"/>
 <o:lock v:ext="edit" aspectratio="t"/>
</v:shapetype><v:shape id="_x0000_i1025" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:235.5pt;
 height:252.75pt'>
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p10_files/image001.emz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=314 height=337
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p10_files/image001.emz"  alt="Adobe Systems" v:shapes="_x0000_i1025"><![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
style='font-size:10.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span class=GramE><b><span
style='font-size:10.0pt'>Figure 1.</span></b></span><span style='font-size:
10.0pt'> A polygon cut into 4 pieces<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in'><b>The Input<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>The
input consists of several test cases. The first line of each test case contains
a single <span class=GramE>integer </span><sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape
 id="_x0000_i1026" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:54pt;height:12.75pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p10_files/image001.emz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=72 height=17
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p10_files/image001.emz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1026"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1026"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912679">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]-->, the number of vertices of polygon. Next <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape
 id="_x0000_i1027" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:9pt;height:9.75pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p10_files/image001.emz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=12 height=13
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p10_files/image001.emz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1027"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1027"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912680">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>lines each contain two
real numbers. These numbers indicate the coordinates of vertices of the polygon
in counter-clockwise order. The last line of each test case contains four real
numbers <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape id="_x0000_i1028" type="#_x0000_t75"
 style='width:56.25pt;height:15pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p10_files/image001.emz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=75 height=20
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p10_files/image001.emz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1028"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1028"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912681">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>which indicate two
distinct points of the cutting line. The input will be terminated by a test
case with <i>n</i> equal to 0.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in'><b>The Output<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>For
each test case, your program must output a line containing the phrase </span><span
style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Test Case #k</span><span
style='font-size:10.0pt'>, in which <i>k</i> shows the index of current test case,
starting from 1. In next line, the program must output an integer <i>P</i>,<i> </i>the
number of resulted polygons after cutting. The next <i>P</i> lines each should describe
the coordinates of a resulting polygon with each two consecutive numbers separated by exactly one space character.
The vertices of each polygon should be printed
in counter-clockwise order with the first vertex being the vertex with the lowest
and leftmost (among the vertices with the lowest) coordinates. Also considering the output for each polygon as a sequence of floating-point numbers, the polygons should be output lexicographically i.e. the polygon having a lexicographically smaller sequence of floating-point numbers should be output first and so on. There should be
a blank line between the outputs of two consecutive test-cases.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>For this problem please note
that:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1;
tab-stops:list .5in'><![if !supportLists]><span style='font-size:10.0pt'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>1-<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span dir=LTR><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>Two
floating-point numbers are considered equal if their absolute difference is
less than<sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape id="_x0000_i1029" type="#_x0000_t75"
 style='width:36.75pt;height:15pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p10_files/image001.emz"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=49 height=20
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/images/p10_files/image001.emz"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1029"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1029"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912682">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]-->.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1;
tab-stops:list .5in'><![if !supportLists]><span style='font-size:10.0pt'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>2-<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span dir=LTR><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>Each
number should be printed with exactly 5 digits after the fraction point.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1;
tab-stops:list .5in'><![if !supportLists]><span style='font-size:10.0pt'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>3-<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span dir=LTR><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>The polygons appearing in the output should not have any 3 consecutive vertices that are colinear.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1;
tab-stops:list .5in'><![if !supportLists]><span style='font-size:10.0pt'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>4-<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span dir=LTR><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>The
given cutting line, can lay on edges of the given polygon.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in'><b>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>7<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>10
0<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>10
6<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>8
10<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>5 6<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>2.5
11<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0 6<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0 <span
class=SpellE>0</span><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>10
6 -10 6<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in'><b>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Test
Case #1<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>3<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0.00000
 0.00000 10.00000 0.00000 10.00000 6.00000  0.00000 6.00000 <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0.00000
6.00000 5.00000 6.00000 2.50000 11.00000<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>5.00000
6.00000 10.00000 6.00000 8.00000 10.00000<o:p></o:p></span></p>

</div>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='color:black'>
Amirkabir University of Technology - Local Contest - Round #2
</span></b><span
style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

</body>

</html>

	margin-left:62.4pt;
	text-indent:-.7in;}
@list l0:level6
	{mso-level-text:"%1\.%2\.%3\.%4\.%5\.%6";
	mso-level-tab-stop:69.6pt;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	margin-left:69.6pt;
	text-indent:-.8in;}
@list l0:level7
	{mso-level-text:"%1\.%2\.%3\.%4\.%5\.%6\.%7";
	mso-level-tab-stop:76.8pt;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	margin-left:76.8pt;
	text-indent:-.9in;}
@list l0:level8
	{mso-level-text:"%1\.%2\.%3\.%4\.%5\.%6\.%7\.%8";
	mso-level-tab-stop:84.0pt;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	margin-left:84.0pt;
	text-indent:-1.0in;}
@list l0:level9
	{mso-level-text:"%1\.%2\.%3\.%4\.%5\.%6\.%7\.%8\.%9";
	mso-level-tab-stop:91.2pt;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	margin-left:91.2pt;
	text-indent:-1.1in;}

	{mso-list-id:962617138;
	mso-list-template-ids:829818234;}

	{mso-level-style-link:"\0633\0631\0641\0635\0644 1";

	text-indent:-.4in;
	mso-bidi-font-size:16.0pt;

	mso-bidi-font-style:normal;}

	{mso-level-suffix:space;

	mso-level-number-position:left;

<!--[if gte mso 10]>

 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="2050"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->
</head>

<body lang=EN-US vlink=purple style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in'><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt'>Problem L<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;
margin-bottom:6.0pt;margin-left:0in;text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:14.0pt'>Dueues Quiz<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><i><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>Hesam
Dueue Bararie</span></i><span style='font-size:10.0pt'> is the showman of a
very popular TV quiz: Bararian Nights. In this quiz, there is a big table of
letters with some words hidden in it among diagonal, vertical or horizontal directions.
During the quiz, Dueue tells each one of the contestants a word and they must
find the total number of occurrences of that word in the table.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>Recently,
Milk-Farhaad has decided to participate in this TV quiz and because cheating is
permitted during this quiz (!), he wants you to help him by writing a computer
program.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>By
the way, Milk-Farhaad has bought the whole dictionary and configurations of the
table from Dueue. All he need is a computer program which calculates the total
number of occurrences for each word of the dictionary in the table.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>You
can see one sample of this table in figure 1. All occurrences of the word
hello are circled in that. Also, the total number of occurrences of the word
madam is equal to 2 because it must be counted twice: one from left to right
and the other one from right to left.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<div align=center>
<img align="center" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10975e.jpg" ></img>
</div>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
style='color:#3366FF'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Figure 1.</span></b><span style='color:black'> Dueues
Table<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b>The Input </b><b><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>The
first line of the input file is an integer <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype
 id="_x0000_t75" coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t"
 path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe" filled="f" stroked="f">
 <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
 <v:formulas>
  <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
 </v:formulas>
 <v:path o:extrusionok="f" gradientshapeok="t" o:connecttype="rect"/>
 <o:lock v:ext="edit" aspectratio="t"/>
</v:shapetype><v:shape id="_x0000_i1025" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:42.75pt;
 height:12pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10975e.jpg"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=57 height=16
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10975e.jpg"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1025"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1025"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912740">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]-->which is the number of test cases. The first line of each
test case is an integer <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape id="_x0000_i1026"
 type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:60.75pt;height:12.75pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10975e.jpg"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=81 height=17
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10975e.jpg"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1026"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1026"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912741">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>which is the number of
words in the dictionary that should be used for this test case. <span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>After that, comes <i>D </i><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>lines each of which containing a word, having
length of no more than 1000 characters, in the dictionary. Words are all
constructed from lowercase letters: </span><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>a
z</span><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>Then,
comes a line containing an integer <sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape id="_x0000_i1027"
 type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:48.75pt;height:14.25pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10975e.jpg"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=65 height=19
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10975e.jpg"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1027"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1027"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912742">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]-->, the total number of queries for the test case. For each
query, there will be two integers<sub><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape id="_x0000_i1028"
 type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:63.75pt;height:12.75pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10975e.jpg"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=85 height=17
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10975e.jpg"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1028"><![endif]></sub><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1028"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1192912743">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--> which are the number of rows and the number of columns of the
table respectively. Next, there are <i>M</i> lines each one containing <i>N</i>
characters representing the configuration of each table of the quiz.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b>The Output</b><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'> </b><b><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>For
each test case, your program should write a line with the phrase </span><span
style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Test Case #i</span><span
style='font-size:10.0pt'> in which </span><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>i</span><span style='font-size:10.0pt'> is the index
of the current test case starting from 1. Then comes the answer for each query
in that test case. The answer to each query starts with a line containing the
phrase </span><span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Query
#j</span><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>. Then, all the words from dictionary which
actually occurred in the table of that query should be listed one in each line
(or each in one line!) together with their total number of occurrences in the
given table. These words must be sorted in alphabetical order. There should be
an empty line after the output for each test case.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>1<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>4<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>hello<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>bye<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>one<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>two<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>2<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>3 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>bye<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>okk<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>res<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>3 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>one<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>wzq<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>too<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:6.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in;text-align:justify'><b>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>Test Case #1<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>Query #1<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>bye 1<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>Query #2<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>one 1<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>two 1<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

</div>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='color:black'>
Amirkabir University of Technology - Local Contest - Round #2
</span></b><span
style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

10976||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Fractions Again?! - Return of the Newbies 2005</TITLE>
<META content="Fractions Again?!" name=description>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>
</HEAD>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#006666">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>Problem
				A: Fractions Again?!</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#006666">
				<P ALIGN=RIGHT><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=3>Time
				limit: 1 second</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>

<BODY>

<p><!--img align=right src='p10976c.jpg'-->

<font size=6>I</font>t is easy to see that for every fraction in the form <img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10976a.gif" > (<b><i>k</i></b> > 0), we can always find two positive integers
<b><i>x</i></b> and <b><i>y</i></b>, <b><i>x</i></b> &ge; <b><i>y</i></b>, such that:
<br><blockquote><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10976a.gif" >.</blockquote>

<p>Now our question is: can you write a program that counts how many such pairs of <b><i>x</i></b> and <b><i>y</i></b> there are for any given <b><i>k</i></b>?

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Input</FONT></A></H2>
<P>Input contains no more than 100 lines, each giving a value of <b><i>k</i></b> (0 < <b><i>k</i></b> &le; 10000).

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00002000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Output</FONT></A></H2>
<P>For each <b><i>k</i></b>, output the number of corresponding (<b><i>x</i></b>, <b><i>y</i></b>) pairs, followed by a sorted list of the values of <b><i>x</i></b> and <b><i>y</i></b>, as shown in the sample output.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00003000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>
<PRE>
2
12
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>
<PRE>
2
1/2 = 1/6 + 1/3
1/2 = 1/4 + 1/4
8
1/12 = 1/156 + 1/13
1/12 = 1/84 + 1/14
1/12 = 1/60 + 1/15
1/12 = 1/48 + 1/16
1/12 = 1/36 + 1/18
1/12 = 1/30 + 1/20
1/12 = 1/28 + 1/21
1/12 = 1/24 + 1/24
</PRE>

<P><HR><ADDRESS><I>Problemsetter: Mak Yan Kei</I></ADDRESS></BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10977||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD><TITLE>Enchanted Forest - Return of the Newbies 2005</TITLE>
<META content="Enchanted Forest" name=description>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>

<BODY>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#006666">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>Problem
				B: Enchanted Forest</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#006666">
				<P ALIGN=RIGHT><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=3>Time
				limit: 3 seconds</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>

<P><font size=6>Y</font>ou are Ash, the famous Pokemon trainer. To become the greatest Pokemon master, you travel through regions battling against gym leaders and entering Pokemon League competitions. With your well-trained Pikachu, Squirtle and Bulbasaur, you have already captured six badges! What a marvellous performance!

<p>Now, you are walking through the <b>Enchanted Forest</b>, where the most powerful Pokemons live... No, not those giant dragons; we are actually talking about <b>Jigglypuffs</b>. A Jigglypuff is a normal-type Balloon Pokemon, with a round, balloon-like body, a tuft of fur on its forehead, and stubby arms and legs. What's so powerful of them? Well, Jigglypuff has a well-regarded singing voice, and its most popular attack is to sing its opponent to sleep! Therefore, it is always a good idea to find a route avoiding places wherever you might hear the Jigglypuffs' lullaby.

<p>Let us model the situation as follows: we shall treat the forest as a rectangular grid formed by paths which are 1 unit apart. Your starting position is at the top left corner of the grid <b>(1, 1)</b>, and you will leave the forest at the lower right corner <b>(R, C)</b>. There might be blocked areas which you are not allowed to trespass through. Jigglypuffs might be present at some intersections. The loudness <b>L</b> of each Jigglypuff is given, which means that places whose Euclidean distance is no more than <b>L</b> units away from the Jigglypuff are considered "dangerous" and should be avoided.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Input</FONT></A></H2>

<p>Input consists of several test cases. Each test begins with two integers <b>R</b> and <b>C</b> (1 &le; <b>R, C</b> &le; 200), the number of rows and columns in the grid map. Then comes an integer <b>m</b>, followed by <b>m</b> lines each giving the coordinates of a blocked position. Next there is an integer <b>n</b> (0 &le; <b>n</b> &le; 100),  the number of Jigglypuffs in the forest. The following <b>n</b> lines each gives the position of a Jigglypuff and its loudness <b>L</b> (1 &le; <b>L</b> &le; 100).

<p>Input ends with a test case where <b>R=0</b> and <b>C=0</b>. You must not process this test case.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00002000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Output</FONT></A></H2>

<p>For each case, if some "dangerous" places are unavoidable, print "<b>Impossible.</b>" Otherwise, give the length of the shortest path to get out of the forest safely.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
5 5
5
1 2
1 3
1 4
1 5
2 5
1
4 3 1
0 0
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
8
</PRE>

<P><HR>
<address>Problemsetter: Mak Yan Kei</address>
</BODY>
</HTML>
______________________________________________________
10978||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD><TITLE>Let's Play Magic! - Return of the Newbies 2005</TITLE>
<META content="Let's Play Magic!" name=description>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>

<BODY>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#006666">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>Problem
				C: Let's Play Magic!</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#006666">
				<P ALIGN=RIGHT><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=3>Time
				limit: 1 second</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>

<P><font size=6>Y</font>ou have seen a card magic trick named "<b>Spelling Bee</b>". The process goes as follows:

<ol>
<li>The magician first arranges 13 cards in a circle, as shown in the figure below.</li>
<li>Starting from the marked position, he counts the cards clockwisely, saying "<i>A--C--E</i>".</li>
<li>He turns the card at the "<i>E</i>" position, and... it is an Ace!</li>
<li>Next, he takes away the Ace and continues to count the cards, saying "<i>T--W--O</i>".</li>
<li>He turns over the card at position "<i>O</i>"... it is a Two!!</li>
<li>He continues to do this with the rest of the cards from Three to King. :-)</li>
</ol>

<P><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10978.png" >

<p>Now, how does the magician arrange the cards?

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Input</FONT></A></H2>

<p>Input consists of several test cases. Each case begins with an integer <b>N</b> (1 &le; <b>N</b> &le; 52), the number of cards to be used in the magic trick.
   The following <b>N</b> lines show the order of the turning-over of the cards and the words to be spelt. None of the words will have more than 20 characters. The format for each card is a string with two characters: first the value, and second the suit.

<p>Input ends with a test case where <b>N=0</b>. This test case should not be processed.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00002000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Output</FONT></A></H2>

<p>For each case, your program should output the initial arrangement of the cards.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
13
AS ACE
2S TWO
3S THREE
4C FOUR
5C FIVE
6C SIX
7D SEVEN
8D EIGHT
9D NINE
TH TEN
JH JACK
QH QUEEN
KH KING
0
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
QH 4C AS 8D KH 2S 7D 5C TH JH 3S 6C 9D
</PRE>

<P><HR>
<address>Problemsetter: Mak Yan Kei</address>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10979||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD><TITLE>How many triangles? - Return of the Newbies 2005</TITLE>
<META content="How many triangles?" name=description>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>

<BODY>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#006666">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>Problem
				D: How many triangles?</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#006666">
				<P ALIGN=RIGHT><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=3>Time
				limit: 3 seconds</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>


<P><font size=6>H</font>ow many triangles are there in the following figure?

<p><center><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/109/p10979.png" ></center>

<p>... ding! Time's up. The answer is 29.

<p>Given at most 10 line segments, you are to <b>write a program</b> that counts the number of triangles bounded by them. Note that three colinear points do <i>not</i> make a triangle.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Input</FONT></A></H2>

<p>Input consists of several test cases. Each case begins with a line containing an integer <b>N</b> (3 &le; <b>N</b> &le; 10). The following <b>N</b> lines each gives four integers,
   <b>x1</b>, <b>y1</b>, <b>x2</b> and <b>y2</b>, meaning that you draw a straight line segment from (<b>x1</b>, <b>y1</b>) to (<b>x2</b>, <b>y2</b>). All the coordinates given have their absolute values no greater than 100.

<p>Input is terminated by EOF.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00002000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Output</FONT></A></H2>

<p>For each case, output the number of triangles bounded by the <b>N</b> lines.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
10
-5 4 5 -4
-5 4 -6 -1
-5 -3 -1 4
-5 -3 5 3
-5 -3 7 0
-1 4 6 -2
0 0 6 -2
6 -2 5 3
7 0 5 -4
-6 -1 3 -1
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
29
</PRE>

<P><HR>
<address>Problemsetter: Mak Yan Kei</address>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10980||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD><TITLE>Lowest Price in Town - Return of the Newbies 2005</TITLE>
<META content="Problem 3" name=description>
<META content=1036 name=keywords>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>
<META http-equiv=Content-Style-Type content=text/css><LINK 
href="trainingtask.css" rel=STYLESHEET></HEAD>


<BODY>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=128*>
	<COL WIDTH=128*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#003300">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>Problem
				E: Lowest Price in Town</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#003300">
				<P ALIGN=RIGHT><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=3>Time
				limit: 1 second</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>

<P><font size=6>I</font>t is sometimes tricky to figure out the <i>cheapest</i> way to buy things, even in the supermarket where the price of all goods are listed clearly. Just consider what I saw last Saturday about the price of cooking oil:
   (notice the difference in the sizes of the two price tags)

<p align=center><img src='p10980b.png'>

<p>Having a sharp mind (a consequence of regularly taking part in online programming contests), you should have no problem in seeing that the 'buy-1-get-1-free' scheme is preferable. But what about your Mum? It is your responsibility as her son/daughter to
   <b>write her a program</b> that computes the lowest price to buy things in the supermarket, thus helps her to save money.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#003300>Input and Output</FONT></A></H2>

<p>The input consists of more than a hundred test cases, each concerning a different item. The first line of each case gives the unit price of buying an item, then a non-negative integer <b>M</b> (&le; 20). This is followed by
   <b>M</b> lines each containing two numbers <b>N</b> and <b>P</b> (1 < <b>N</b> &le; 100), which means that you can buy <b>N</b> such items for $<b>P</b>. Finally there is a line containing a list of positive integers <b>K</b> (&le; 100); for each of them your program should
   print the lowest price you need to get <b>K</b> items. Note that you do <i>not</i> have to buy <i>exactly</i> <b>K</b> items; you may consider buying more than <b>K</b> items, and giving the unneeded items to your dear neighbours, if you can save money in this way.

<P>Note that all prices <b>P</b> given in the input are floating-point numbers in exactly 2 decimal places, with 0 < <b>P</b> < 1000.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#003300>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
22.00 2
2 22.00
4 60.00
2 4
25.00 2
2 48.00
2 46.00
2
22.00 2
2 22.00
4 40.00
1 2 3
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#003300>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
Case 1:
Buy 2 for $22.00
Buy 4 for $44.00
Case 2:
Buy 2 for $46.00
Case 3:
Buy 1 for $22.00
Buy 2 for $22.00
Buy 3 for $40.00
</PRE>

<P><HR><ADDRESS><I>Problemsetter: Mak Yan Kei</I></ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10981||||||false||||||
<HTML>


<HEAD>
<TITLE>String Morphing - Return of the Newbies 2005</TITLE>

<META content="String Morphing" name=description>

<META content=1036 name=keywords>

<META content=document name=resource-type>

<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">

<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>

</HEAD>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#006666">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>Problem
				F: String Morphing</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#006666">
				<P ALIGN=RIGHT><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=3>Time
				limit: 2 seconds</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>

<BODY>
 

<p><font size=6>T</font>here is a special multiplication operator such that

<p><center><img src='p10981.jpg'>
<br><font size=2><b><i>Table of special multiplication operation</i></b></font></center>
Thus <b><i>ab = b</i></b>, <b><i>ba = c</i></b>, <b><i>bc = a</i></b>, <b><i>cb = c</i></b>, ...

<p>For example, you are given the string <b><i>bbbba</i></b> and the character <b><i>a</i></b>,
<pre>	(b(bb))(ba) = (bb)(ba)	[as bb = b]
		    = b(ba)	[as bb = b]
		    = bc	[as ba = c]
		    = a		[as bc = a] </pre>
<p>By adding suitable brackets, <b><i>bbbba</i></b> can produce <b><i>a</i></b> according to the above multiplication table.

<p>You are asked to <b>write a program</b> to show the morphing steps of a string into an expected character, or otherwise, output "<b>None exist!</b>" if the given string cannot be morphed as expected.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Input</FONT></A></H2>

<P>The first line of the input file gives the number of test cases. Each case consists of two lines. The first line is the starting string which has at most 100 characters. The second line is the target character. All characters in the input are within the range of <b>a</b>-<b>c</b>.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00002000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Output</FONT></A></H2>

<P>For each test case, your output should consist several lines, showing the morphing steps of a string into the character. In case there are more than one solution, always try to start the morphing from the left. Print a blank line between consecutive sets of output.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00003000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
2
bbbba
a
bbbba
a
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#006666>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>


<PRE>
bbbba
bbba
bba
bc
a

bbbba
bbba
bba
bc
a
</PRE>

<P><HR><ADDRESS><I>Problemsetter: Raymond Chun (Idea from "Adding Brackets", HKOI 99)</I><br>
<I>Special Thanks to: Liu Chi Man (aka cx)</I>
</ADDRESS></BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10982||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Troublemakers</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem A</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Troublemakers</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 1 second</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
[after seeing that the room is on fire; Ted has a needle<br>
in his hand while holding the leg of a dead woman; Sara<br>
has a bottle of champagne in her hand, and Juancho is smoking]<br>
Man: <i>Did they misbehave?</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Robert Rodrigues</tt>, <i>"The Misbehavers."</i>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
Every school class has its troublemakers - those kids who can make
the teacher's life miserable. On his own, a troublemaker is manageable,
but when you put certain pairs of troublemakers together in the same room,
teaching a class becomes very hard. There are <b>n</b> kids in Mrs. Shaida's
math class, and there are <b>m</b> pairs of troublemakers among them.
The situation has gotten so bad that Mrs. Shaida has decided to split
the class into two classes. Help her do it in such a way that the
number of troublemaker pairs is reduced by at least a half.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one starts with a line containing
<b>n</b> <nobr>(0&lt;=<b>n</b>&lt;=100)</nobr> and <b>m</b> <nobr>(0&lt;<b>m</b>&lt;5000)</nobr>.
The next <b>m</b> lines will contain a pair of integers <b>u</b> and
<b>v</b> meaning that when kids <b>u</b> and <b>v</b> are in the same
room, they make a troublemaker pair. Kids are numbered from 1 to <b>n</b>.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output one line containing "Case #<b>x</b>:"
followed by <b>L</b> - the number of kids who will be moved to a
different class (in a different room). The next line should list
those kids. The total number of troublemaker pairs in the two rooms
must be at most <nobr><b>m</b>/2</nobr>. If that is impossible, print
"Impossible." instead of <b>L</b> and an empty line afterwards.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
2
4 3
1 2
2 3
3 4
4 6
1 2
1 3
1 4
2 3
2 4
3 4
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1: 3
1 3 4
Case #2: 2
1 2
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10983||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Buy one, get the rest free.</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem B</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Buy one, get the rest free.</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 3 seconds</FONT><BR>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>"Whoa! It feels like I'm flying!"</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Lrrr</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
It's year 2258, and the age of airplanes is coming to an end. Everyone is
using teleporters now. In an effort to stay competitive, the last remaining
air travel company, GetsJo, is offering the following deal to its customers.
Instead of buying one plane ticket, you can rent a whole flight from A to B.
Each flight can carry a certain number of people and costs a certain amount
of money. If you do that, then you can rent all of the other flights of equal
or lesser cost for free!
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
For example, if there are 4 flights with costs $10000, $25000, $30000 and $40000,
and you rent the $30000 flight, then you get the $10000 and $25000 flights for
free. The total cost to rent these 3 flights is $30000.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
You want to organize a large programming competition and would like to invite
all of the participants to city <b>n</b>, where the competition will be held.
Being a nice person, you decide to pay for everyone's airplane tickets. Given
the locations of the participants and the list of available flights between
now and the day of the competition, what is the cost of renting enough flights
to get all of the participants to city <b>n</b> in the next <b>d</b> days?
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>. <b>N</b> test
cases follow. Each one starts with a line containing the number of cities
(1&lt;=<b>n</b>&lt;=30), the number of days (1&lt;=<b>d</b>&lt;=10) until
the competition and the number of flights (0&lt;=<b>m</b>&lt;=1000). <b>m</b>
lines follow, each one containing 5 integers: <b>u</b>, <b>v</b>, <b>c</b>,
<b>p</b> and <b>e</b> (1&lt;=<b>u</b>,<b>v</b>&lt;=<b>n</b>,
1&lt;=<b>c</b>&lt;=100, 0&lt;=<b>e</b>&lt;<b>d</b>). This means that a
flight that can carry <b>c</b> passengers and costs <b>p</b> dollars leaves
city <b>u</b> on day <b>e</b> in the evening and arrives next day in the
morning to city <b>v</b>. Day 0 is today, and all of the participants need
to be in city <b>n</b> in the evening of day <b>e</b>. Finally, <b>n</b>
integers (<b>z<sub>1</sub></b>, <b>z<sub>2</sub></b>, ..., <b>z<sub>n</sub></b>)
follow, meaning that there are <b>z<sub>i</sub></b> participants in city <b>i</b>
on day 0 (0&lt;=<b>z<sub>i</sub></b>&lt;=100). The maximum cost of a flight
is 100000. There will never be two flights with the same <b>u</b>, <b>v</b> and
<b>e</b> values.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output one line containing "Case #<b>x</b>:"
followed by the minimum required cost of flying all of the participants
to city <b>n</b> before the end of day <b>d</b>. If no amount of money is
enough, print "Impossible" instead.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
2
5 4 5
1 5 100 30000 0
2 4 10 10000 0
2 4 10 10000 1
4 5 25 25000 2
2 5 100 40000 3
1 20 0 5 100
2 1 1
1 2 99 10400 0
100 0
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1: 30000
Case #2: Impossible
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B><br>
<B>Alternate solution: Yury Kholondyrev</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10984||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Double NP-hard</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem C</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Double NP-hard</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 2 second</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>
"Name and Class Year:<br>
Course to be Covered: (Course Number and Title)<br>
Reason for covering the course independently:"</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Hamilton College Application for Independent<br>
Coverage of Course Work</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Definitions</B></FONT><BR>
In this problem, a <i>graph</i> is a set of <b>n</b> vertices together
with a set of <b>m</b> edges, where an <i>edge</i> is an unordered
pair of different vertices (edges are undirected). The two vertices
that comprise an edge are said to be that edge's <i>endpoints</i>.
A <i>vertex cover</i> of a given graph G is a subset C of its vertices,
such that each edge of G has at least one of its endpoints in C. An
<i>independent set</i> of a given graph G is a subset S of its vertices,
such that no edge of G has both of its endpoints in S.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
The problem of finding a <i>minimum vertex cover</i> (that is, a vertex cover
of the smallest possible size) for any graph is NP-hard.
The problem of finding a <i>maximum independent set</i> of any graph is also
NP-hard. That is a formal way of saying that no one knows whether there
exists an algorithm that runs in time polynomial in <b>n</b> and solves
any one of the two problems.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
We want to define a class of problems that are even harder than the NP-hard
problems. We are going to call them "Double NP-hard"! Your job is to solve
the first Double NP-hard problem.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Problem</B></FONT><BR>
Given a graph G, find a subset C of its vertices that is both a minimum
vertex cover and a maximum independent set.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one starts with two lines containing
<b>n</b> <nbsp>(0&lt;=<b>n</b>&lt;=1000)</nbsp> and <b>m</b> <nbsp>(0&lt;=<b>m</b>&lt;=100000)</nbsp>
as above. The next <b>m</b> lines will each describe an edge of G as a
pair of different vertices, which are numbered from 1 to <b>n</b>.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output one line containing "Case #<b>x</b>:"
followed by either "Impossible" if there is no answer or the size <b>k</b> of
the set C. In the latter case, on the next line, print the <b>k</b> vertices
of C in increasing order, separated by spaces. If there are multiple answers,
print the lexicographically smallest one.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
4
2
1
1 2
0
0
10
0
4
4
1 2
2 3
3 4
4 1
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1: 1
1
Case #2: 0

Case #3: Impossible
Case #4: 2
1 3
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B><br>
<B>Special thanks: Wladek Kwasnicki, Frank Chu</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>


______________________________________________________
10985||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Rings'n'Ropes</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem D</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Rings'n'Ropes</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 3 seconds</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>"Well, that seems to be the situation. But,<br>
I don't want that, and you don't want that,<br>
and Ringo here definitely doesn't want that."</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Jules Winnfield</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
I have <b>n</b> tiny rings made of steel. I also have <b>m</b>
pieces of rope, all of exactly the same length. The two ends
of each piece of rope are tied to two different rings.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
I am going to take one of the rings, <b>L</b>, into my left hand,
and another ring, <b>R</b> into my right hand. Then I will pull
the whole structure apart as hard as I can. Some of the ropes
will be streched horizontally because of this. Others will hang
down or bend out of shape. If I want the number of horizontally
stretched ropes to be as large as possible, which <b>L</b> and
<b>R</b> should I pick?
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
Assume that the stretching of ropes in negligible, they all
have negligible thickness and are free to slide around
the rings that they are tied to. The thickness and radius of
each ring is negligible, too.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one starts with two lines containing
<b>n</b> (<nobr>2&lt;=<b>n</b>&lt;=120</nobr>) and <b>m</b> 
(<nobr>0&lt;=<b>m</b>&lt;=<b>n</b>(<b>n</b>-1)/2</nobr>).
The next <b>m</b> lines will each contain a pair of different 
rings (integers in the range [0, <b>n</b>-1]). Each pair of rings will
be connected by at most one rope.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output the line containing "Case #<b>x</b>:", followed
by the largest number of ropes that I can stretch horizontally
by picking a pair of rings, <b>L</b> and <b>R</b>.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
4
2 
1
0 1
3
3
0 1
1 2
2 0
6
6
0 1
0 5
1 3
5 4
3 2
4 2
6
7
0 1
0 5
1 3
1 4
5 4
3 2
4 2
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1: 1
Case #2: 1
Case #3: 6
Case #4: 7
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10986||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Sending email</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem E</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sending email</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 3 seconds</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>"A new internet watchdog is creating a stir in<br>
Springfield. Mr. X, if that is his real name, has<br>
come up with a sensational scoop."</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Kent Brockman</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
There are <b>n</b> SMTP servers connected by network cables.
Each of the <b>m</b> cables connects two computers and has a
certain latency measured in milliseconds required to send an
email message. What is the shortest time required to send a
message from server <b>S</b> to server <b>T</b> along a 
sequence of cables? Assume that there is no delay incurred
at any of the servers.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one starts with a line containing
<b>n</b> (2&lt;=<b>n</b>&lt;20000), <b>m</b> (0&lt;=<b>m</b>&lt;50000),
<b>S</b> (0&lt;=<b>S</b>&lt;<b>n</b>) and <b>T</b> 
(0&lt;=<b>T</b>&lt;<b>n</b>). <b>S</b>!=<b>T</b>. The next <b>m</b> lines will each 
contain 3 integers: 2 different servers (in the range [0, <b>n</b>-1]) 
that are connected by a bidirectional cable and
the latency, <b>w</b>, along this cable (0&lt;=<b>w</b>&lt;=10000).
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output the line "Case #<b>x</b>:" followed by the
number of milliseconds required to send a message from <b>S</b> to
<b>T</b>. Print "unreachable" if there is no route from <b>S</b> to
<b>T</b>.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
3
2 1 0 1
0 1 100
3 3 2 0
0 1 100
0 2 200
1 2 50
2 0 0 1
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1: 100
Case #2: 150
Case #3: unreachable
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10987||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>AntiFloyd</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem F</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>AntiFloyd</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 2 seconds</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>"There is nothing new under the sun but<br>
there are lots of old things we don't know."</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Ambrose Bierce</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
You have been hired as a systems administrator for a large company. The
company head office has <b>n</b> computers connected by a network of
<b>m</b> cables. Each cable connects two different computers, and there
is at most one cable connecting any given pair of computers. Each cable
has a latency, measured in micro-seconds, that determines how long it
takes for a message to travel along that cable. The network protocol is
set up in a smart way, so that when sending a message from computer A to
computer B, the message will travel along the path that has the smallest
total latency, so that it arrives at B as soon as possible. The
cables are bi-directional and have the same latency in both directions.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
As your first order of business, you need to determine which computers
are connected to each other, and what the latency is along each of the
<b>m</b> cables. You soon discover that this is a difficult task because
the building has many floors, and the cables are hidden inside walls. So
here is what you decide to do. You will send a message from every computer
A to every other computer B and measure the latency. This will give you
<nobr><b>n</b>(<b>n</b>-1)/2</nobr> measurements. From this data, you will
determine which computers are connected by cables, and what the latency
along each cable is. You would like your model to be simple, so you want
to use as few cables as possible.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b> (at most 20).
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one starts with a line containing
<b>n</b> (0&lt;<b>n</b>&lt;100). The next <nobr><b>n</b>-1</nobr> lines will
contain the message latency measurements. Line <b>i</b> will contain <b>i</b>
integers in the range <nobr>[1, 10000]</nobr>. Integer <b>j</b> is the amount
of time it takes to send a message from computer <nobr><b>i</b>+1</nobr> to
computer <b>j</b> (or back).
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output a line containing "Case #<b>x</b>:". The next
line should contain <b>m</b> - the number of cables. The next <b>m</b> lines
should contain 3 integers each: <b>u</b>, <b>v</b> and <b>w</b>, meaning
that there is a cable between computers <b>u</b> and <b>v</b>, and it has
latency <b>w</b>. Lines should be sorted first by <b>u</b>, then by <b>v</b>,
with <nobr><b>u</b>&lt;<b>v</b></nobr>. If there are multiple answers, any
one will do. If the situation is impossible, print "Need better measurements."
Print an empty line after each test case.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
2
3
100
200 100
3
100
300 100
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1:
2
1 2 100
2 3 100

Case #2:
Need better measurements.

</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk<br>
Alternate solution: Frank Chu</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10988||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>From G to H and back</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem G</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>From G to H and back</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 3 seconds</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>"All right, I'm stumped... and I think I'm supposed to be."</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Dana Scully</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
There is a funny transformation that you can do with a graph.
We start with an undirected graph, G, and build a new graph, H.
G has <b>n</b> vertices and <b>m</b> edges. For each edge in G,
we create a vertex in H. Two vertices in H are connected by an
edge if and only if their corresponding edges in G share a vertex.
H will have <b>m</b> vertices and <b>p</b> edges.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
That's easy. But what about reconstructing G, given H?
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one starts with two lines containing
<b>m</b> (at most 320) and <b>p</b>. <b>p</b> lines follow, each containing
two different vertices (numbered from 1 to <b>m</b>) in H which are
connected by an edge.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output one line containing "Case #<b>x</b>:" 
followed by either "yes" or "no", depending on whether there exists some
graph G that produces the given graph H.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
2
3
3
1 2
2 3
3 1
4
3
1 2
1 3
1 4
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1: yes
Case #2: no
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10989||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
    <title>Bomb, Divide and Conquer</title>
</head>

<body>
<BASEFONT FACE="ARIAL">
<P>
<CENTER>
<FONT SIZE="6"><B>Problem H</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Bomb, Divide and Conquer</B></FONT><BR>
<FONT SIZE="4">Time Limit: 3 seconds</FONT>
</CENTER>
</P>

<p align="right">
<table border=0><tr><td><small>
<i>"War is God's way of teaching Americans geography."</i>
</td></tr></table>
<tt>Ambrose Bierce (1842 - <u>1914</u>)</tt>
</small></p>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
The enemy has <b>n</b> cities connected by <b>m</b> roads. We have
bombers that can destroy roads. The Bomb, Divide and Conquer strategy
dictates that if we separate the enemy's cities from each other, then
the two (or more) pieces will be easier to secure. Bombing a road has
a cost (fuel, risk factor, etc.) What is the minimum total cost of
bombing enough roads to ensure that there is some pair of cities
that have no path between them? A path is a sequence of connected roads.
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Input</B></FONT><BR>
The first line of input gives the number of cases, <b>N</b>.
<b>N</b> test cases follow. Each one starts with two lines containing
<b>n</b> <nobr>(2&lt;=<b>n</b>&lt;=150)</nobr> and <b>m</b>
<nobr>(0&lt;=<b>m</b>&lt;=<b>n</b>(<b>n</b>-1)/2)</nobr>. The next
<b>m</b> lines contain <b>m</b> triples of integers
denoting two different cities (between 1 and <b>n</b>) that are connected by a
road and the cost of destroying that road (between 1 and 1000).
</P>

<P CLASS="paragraph">
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Output</B></FONT><BR>
For each test case, output one line containing "Case #<b>x</b>:" 
followed by the total cost of disconnecting a pair of cities.
</P>

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" CELLSPACING=0 BORDERCOLOR=black BORDER=1 CELLPADDING=5>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Input</B></FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT SIZE="5"><B>Sample Output</B></FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#D0D0D0" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD>
<PRE>
4
5
4
1 2 100
2 3 299
3 5 400
5 4 99
3
3
1 2 10
2 3 20
1 3 40
4
5
1 2 10
2 3 100
3 4 10
4 1 100
1 3 10
3
1
1 2 1000
</PRE>
</TD>
<TD>
<PRE>
Case #1: 99
Case #2: 30
Case #3: 30
Case #4: 0
</PRE>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P>
<HR>
<B>Problemsetter: Igor Naverniouk</B>
</P>

</td></tr></table>
</body>
</html>
